PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law and Child Support Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That serious injustices are occurring daily due to the operations of the Family Law Act and the Child Support Act.

Your petitioners therefore humbly ask that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to call as a matter of urgency for a comprehensive inquiry into the Family Law Act and the Child Support Act.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Directory: Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Since the introduction of three (3) regional West Australian telephone directories there has been a constant demand from users to revert to a consolidated country directory which is convenient to all users.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled urge the Minister for Communications to direct Telecom to recognise the requirement of rural West Australians and revert to a single consolidated country telephone directory.

PETITION.TITLE: National Health Act
PETITION.PARA: The draft Charter of Residents' Rights and Responsibilities and the draft Agreement to be entered into between the Proprietors of Nursing Homes and their Residents which have been tabled in the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia by the Honourable Peter Staples, Minister for Housing and Aged Care on 18 September 1990.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the above draft Charter and Agreement are designed to require Proprietors of Nursing Homes to act in a manner contrary to proper moral standards and to incur obligations that are likely to lead to unnecessary expense and litigation.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament amend the said Draft Charter and Agreement in such ways as are necessary:
1. To preserve the Proprietor's rights to ensure that providers of Health Care Services to Residents comply with the Philosophy of the Proprietor in relation to such services.

2. To ensure that the Agreement can be offered to Residents of Nursing Homes without offending the conscience of Proprietors and Staff who have moral objections to the grant to any person of a right to indulge in extramarital sexual intercourse in their Nursing Homes.
3. To eliminate vague and uncertain language.

4. To remove from the Draft Agreement the provisions which impose on Proprietors and Staff onerous responsibilities that will increase demands on the human and material resources of the Nursing Homes without securing any essential benefit to the Residents.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition, by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said ``The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth and as stated in our Federal Constitution-``Relying on the Blessings of Almighty God . . .''
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
1. The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem-``God Bless Australia'' to the tune of ``Waltzing Matilda''.
2. The adoption of a Christian National Motto-``One Nation Under God'', for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
3. The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.

4. The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament. The retention of ``God Save the Queen'' for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
5. The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
6. Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wealth Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That in Australia, the rich are getting richer while poverty is increasing, as shown by recent research that 10% of the population own 50% of the wealth while people in poverty have increased from 1.5 million in 1982 to 2.1 million in 1986.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Request the Australian Government-
to establish a Wealth Inquiry as a first and essential step to the achievement of a more just society;
and that this Inquiry should seek to establish-
the current distribution of wealth, how it has changed over time and the causes of these changes
the effectiveness of the Australian taxation system in raising revenue at all levels of taxpayers' income and assets
the measures which should be taken to achieve a more just society

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Messages from His Excellency the Governor-General were reported, informing the Senate that His Excellency had, in the name of Her Majesty, assented to the following laws:
Arts, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Act 1990 (Act No. 88 of 1990)
First Home Owners Amendment Act 1990 (Act No. 89 of 1990)
Australian National Maritime Museum Act 1990 (Act No. 90 of 1990)
Consideration resumed from 26 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the report of Estimates Committee E be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering proposed expenditure for the Department of Transport and Communications.

—I am wondering whether the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) has come prepared with the information that he promised for today that I asked him for last night, about the consumer bodies.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, with great respect, I was very precise about what I said yesterday to the Committee. I said that I would be unable to get the information this morning but I would undertake to try to get it by close of business this afternoon, and I will.

—Could the Minister please respond to the last question that I asked last night. I will remind him of it. I asked the Minister whether it is a fact that a reading of the recommendations by Janet Strickland will indicate that material on this new opt-in service will be far more degrading of women than material about which there has been a current public outcry.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave a response to similar earlier questions yesterday. It will be the committee that determines these matters, not Janet Strickland unilaterally. I explained that. She will be one of seven people. It will be the committee acting as a committee that lays down those standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have hit the nub of it now. That was not the question that I asked. We should bear in mind that this is a report which was done by Janet Strickland at the request of Telecom Australia. I have asked Telecom about a number of things concerning this report. I asked Telecom through the Minister certain questions about the 0055 service following the Estimates committee hearings. I am asking the Minister whether it is a fact that a reading of the recommendations by Janet Strickland will indicate that material on the new opt-in service will be far more degrading of women than material that is currently the subject of public outcry.
—The answer to Senator Harradine's question is no.

—Obviously the Minister has not read the recommendations. I ask him why not. The recommendations show on pages 7 and 8 that there will be a binding philosophy which will bind the committee that is established by Telecom. Janet Strickland described the philosophy-it used to be called a principle; she now calls it a philosophy-by saying that adults should have the maximum freedom to impart and receive information and ideas and children should not be exposed to messages which are harmful to them and that the public at large should be protected from advertising which, inter alia, is misleading, false or grossly offensive.

SPEECH.PARA: When it comes to the question of who sets the standards, there is established a seven-member committee. But that seven-member committee will be bound, as per page 12 of the recommendations, to give expression to the philosophy contained in recommendation 2. As I have mentioned, recommendation 2 establishes a philosophy that adults be free to choose what they view.

As I said last night, that is a specious argument. Adults are not free to hear any anti-female propaganda of the porn merchants unless it is published. The real issue is whether the Federal Government should permit Telecom to act in effect as a publisher of this material for the `sexploiters'. That is the question that I want to go to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said yesterday-and I will say it again today-we are simply going over the same ground again and again. I do not, frankly, understand Senator Harradine's point that adults would be able to see this material only if it were published. People cannot read the Encyclopaedia Britannica or the Bible unless they are published. I do not understand the point. To get to what I think is the point, I reiterate that the committee will go through what I imagine will be a very complex process of setting the standards. In so doing, obviously it will have mind to the recommendations-and that is all they are-of Janet Strickland's report. The committee will not be bound by recommendation 2 or any other recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not particularly want to turn the Estimates committee process into an endless debate on the question of censorship, but I make no bones about my own position on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not interested in your position, your personal opinion.
—I will sit down then; I will accommodate you. Senator Harradine was interested.
—I want to follow that through. Is the Minister now saying that Telecom Australia has not accepted the recommendations of Janet Strickland's report?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —No. If I could be permitted to express an opinion, that is not the case. I am saying that Senator Harradine should look at the words. I am perfectly comfortable with Janet Strickland's recommendation 2. It happens to be very largely my view, as opposed to the honourable senator's, about the proper role for Telecom to play in monitoring what happens on its telephone lines. I want to ensure that people are not under any misapprehensions about this. One would think from listening to this debate that the Discovery service was set up for people to go to the extraordinary trouble of getting a personal computer and paying a subscription fee, a service fee, purely for the purpose of exchanging sexual conversation, which seems to be a rather complicated way of doing it.

SPEECH.PARA: Discovery is nothing of the sort. I have no doubt personally that the people who would use this extremely useful service would do so to access the mass of information which is available about advertising and promotion, accommodation, travel, computer courses, banking and finance and, indeed, gambling and gaming services. I know that Senator Harradine has a close personal interest in the racing industry. I think he is probably a net loser, like most people associated with that industry. I think he owns the leg of a horse-or the tail or an ear. I do not like gambling, I confess. I have an antipathy towards it. I have seen enough at first hand of the damage it does to people. But I would not suggest for a minute that Telecom should monitor what goes on on its telephone lines in respect of the Discovery service on gaming. I would not want Telecom to remove that service, as distasteful as I find it, because I do not think that is Telecom's function.

Recommendation 2 refers to the maximum access. It does not say-and Senator Harradine and I, and a number of other senators, have been over this debate at length before-and I am not silly enough to suggest that we live in a world where everything is black and white and where there is no censorship. I have never taken that position and Senator Harradine knows it. It is purely a question of judgment about where to draw the line.

For example, some years ago the Government decided that it would not allow bestiality or child pornography to be portrayed in the X-rated videos now sold in Australia. So Senator Harradine is perfectly correct that it is simply not true to say that there is no censorship or, indeed, that I or the Government supports a position that there should be no censorship. I do not take that purist view, but in accordance with these recommendations-I say again to Senator Harradine-the seven person committee will determine finally the standards that are acceptable or not acceptable, no doubt mindful of these recommendations which have been accepted. But the recommendations are not binding; they are to be used as a guide. That is the precise answer to Senator Harradine's question. I imagine that at the time when the Committee makes the determination and publishes its guidelines Senator Harradine will have an opportunity to canvass whether or not he agrees with those guidelines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister to page 10 of the Strickland report. It has this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is believed that an `opt-in' system for `adult' Telephone Information Service messages would allay public concerns about ready access of `adult' material to children; would give the customer more control over the services which he/she wishes to have delivered; would restore the quality of existing OO55 services; and would give adults a wider choice of services, as well as a greater freedom of expression.

Does that or does that not mean that the material on that new service would be far more degrading of women than material about which there is a current public outcry? Why would Janet Strickland make that statement about giving adults a wider choice of service?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am again at a total loss to understand why Senator Harradine would immediately leap to the conclusion that a desire to provide adults with a wider choice of services would automatically result in something degrading to women. I am just astonished by that leap into space. The answer to the question again is that no absolute determination can be made from what I consider to be a very sensible statement. I believe the opt-in approach to this service is the desirable way to go. I happen to support this particular recommendation. I hope that it is adopted by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: There is some sort of impression created that there is an on-screen X-rated video service available through this Discovery service; that is simply not correct. The kind of free expression that Janet Strickland is talking about is only in respect of the one-to-one communication which electronic mail provides. Again, I happen to be a great advocate of electronic mail. It makes maximum use of the advantages that computers can offer to people; it is on a one-to-one basis. The only people who receive it are the people who want to receive it.

The electronic mail service that operates through Discovery where people can send on a one-to-one basis to mailboxes-the numbers of which are only given to people who want the mail-is exactly the same as if I bought a People magazine, or wherever the adult mature media group advertise, took a telephone number from that magazine, rang John Lark's enterprise in Canberra and ordered a video tape over that service. Alternatively, if I was desperate to do it-and I am not at the moment, I am delighted to say-I can have access to the same magazines which regularly have columns and columns of dirty phone call services where people who feel the need can ring and hear 10 minutes of heavy breathing at great cost, if that is what turns them on. Telecom has as little right, in my view, to interfere with that one-to-one communication on Discovery as it has to interfere with what transpires between a person who picks up a telephone and talks privately to another person. As far as I am concerned, in this country people can say what they like.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I make one brief point? I am sure the Minister will, on reading his comments, see that he is off the beam completely. Janet Strickland made no recommendations as to Discovery at all. In fact, the answers I have from the Estimates Committee indicate that she has nothing to do with Discovery; it is on 0055. I thought that is what we were talking about at this stage. If the Minister wants to get on to Discovery, I will oblige him.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has to try to understand that he is committing this Government to a situation where I am sure, in the ultimate, the Government will rue the day that the Minister made certain statements as he has done today. If one looks at the Discovery situation, the answers that I received to the questions that I placed on notice for Estimates Committee E show perfectly clearly that what is happening in the Discovery service is the establishment of what is known as the publishing model for Telecom. Senator Collins is now saying that people are entitled to have Telecom send into private homes material which is degrading to women.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—That is what the Minister has said. He is talking about--
—You have an extraordinarily twisted view of the world, Senator.

—I understood Senator Collins to say a moment ago that, so far as he was concerned, the so-called philosophy that has been put forward by Janet Strickland ought to be observed in this case; in other words, Telecom should be able to act as agent and publisher for the material which is provided by the sexploit profiteers and undermines the status of women. That is what the Minister is saying. That is what Discovery is saying. Discovery says that Telecom will not be the moral arbiter in these particular cases. What we are talking about is the use of Telecom lines by sexploiters to undermine the status of women in Australia, not individual phone calls or communications between individuals. We are talking about Discovery. In answer to my questions on standards, Discovery indicates clearly that it intends to adopt what is legally the case for published material.

SPEECH.PARA: That begs the question as to whether what goes onto television sets or onto computer screens in Australian homes should be the same as what applies in the Australian Capital Territory for pornographic videos. That goes to the question of whether what is being done here is pre-empting any decision in future as to whether pay television will be based on the publishing model or on the broadcast model. That is what this is all about. Those are the precedents that are being established here. Apparently, the Minister supports that sort of precedent.

It is a very important issue that we are discussing at this present stage because Telecom wants to be a player in pay television. Now Telecom is setting this up through Discovery. The board of directors of Telecom has not done this. I appreciate that the Minister has said that he is going to ask the board of directors, through Mr Beazley, for its view and also ask Mr Beazley for his view, but Discovery has established a precedent that the publishing model will be used for the transmission of material from porn merchants onto screens, at this stage computer screens, in the private homes of subscribers.

What is the difference, if we accept that, when the same group-the Mature Media Group-says, `We want to engage in this service'? It has indicated that it wants to be involved in the supply of this material for the purpose of pay television. It is on record as saying that. Unless the board of directors overturns what is happening and unless the Minister directs Telecom to have another look at it, a principle has been established which then provides for the publishing model to be the basis for pay television, and not the broadcast model.

But let us get to what we were dealing with, that is, the question of the Janet Strickland report and the responses that were given to me on 0055 numbers. The Minister indicates that the recommendations will not mean that the pornographers will be able to provide material which is worse than the current material that is available. That is what the Minister is saying.

The Minister shakes his head. Is he not saying that? I thought that that was what he said. I asked the deliberate question as to whether a reading of the recommendations of Strickland would indicate that the material on the new opt-in service-that is, the specific 0055 service-would be far more degrading to women than the material about which there is a current outcry. I thought that his answer was no. The Minister shakes his head now.

TALK.START.PARA: —When you sit down I will respond.
—I do not know whether that means yes or no. I ask the Minister to turn to page 15 of the report, which makes this comment:

SPEECH.PARA: Bearing in mind that the Australian telephone information service industry is small, that the number of public complaints about the current system are relatively minor and that, as recommended, adult messages will only be accessible on an opt-in basis, the number of complaints received or disputes arising about the content of telephone information service messages are unlikely to be substantial, although complaints about advertisements for the adult telephone information service messages may increase.
If the material content is not going to be worse, why would there be potentially more complaints in the advertising field?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very difficult to sort out one piece of nonsense from another in terms of what has just been delivered. I really wish that Senator Harradine, if he reads the Hansard transcript afterwards, will simply take the English meaning of what I say rather than taking these giant leaps into space and ascribing meanings to what I say that are not there.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine asked me, as he said quite correctly, whether I agreed that an interpretation of recommendation 2 of Janet Strickland about the opt-in service-that is, that adults should have as a basic principle the maximum opportunity to read, see and hear what they want, provided that it is not unsolicited and provided that children do not have access to it and so on-would mean of necessity that the material would be degrading to women. That was the question. My answer to that question was no. I think that is an extraordinary assumption to make, and I say no again. It is absolutely nonsense to suggest, as Senator Harradine just did-and the Hansard record will show it; I noted his comments-that I was advocating that Telecom would have the opportunity to send pornographic material unsolicited into people's homes. That is just nonsense.

Recommendation 2 says that adults, as a general principle, should have the right to be able to see and hear in private what they want, that people should be protected from receiving unsolicited information-that is, information they do not want-and that children should be protected. I have no difficulty in asserting that, quite distinct from Senator Harradine's view, this Government has no difficulty in living with a principle like that. It is one that I strongly support.

I will say again for the fifth or sixth time-and I know that Senator Harradine has a job to do and, fair enough, he is doing it-that there are absolutely no grounds on which Senator Harradine or anyone else can make an assumption that, by having regard to Janet Strickland's recommendation 2, material is going to be degrading of women.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why isn't Telecom doing it?
—The seven-person committee, for the fifth or sixth time--
—Senator Collins, I suggest that you ignore the interjections, and I ask Senator Newman to stop interjecting.
—I will do so, as I should have yesterday. The fact is that Senator Harradine has a particular view of the world which I do not share.
—Thank goodness.

—Indeed, and Senator Walters has a particular view of the world that I am about 15 quantum leaps away from, thank God. The fact is that we are once again debating how many angels can dance on the head of a pin. It is a question of Senator Harradine's interpretation of recommendation 2 or mine. Both of them, I would suggest, are probably from our respective points of view equally valid. All I am saying -and I say it again-is that there are no grounds to simply assert as a matter of fact that, if the Committee does have regard to recommendation 2, the material that is then transmitted over a telephone line will be of necessity degrading to women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, may I correct Senator Collins for his mishearing of what I said. The record will show that I never said that the material would be going unsolicited into homes. I was talking in the context of the opt-in service. I think that that sort of red herring is unnecessary. However, Senator Collins has not answered the question that I asked. If the material is not going to be worse than currently is the case, why then does Janet Strickland in her report indicate that complaints about advertisements for the new adult telephone information services may increase? Why would complaints about the advertising of the new service increase if it were not going to be more offensive to people who may see it advertised in various places?

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody knows, except presumably the Minister, that the material is going to be worse. Ask Telecom about that. The committee that is being established, we are told, is going to have a minister of religion or two on it. It matters not whether ministers comprise the whole committee, it is tied hand and foot to observe this specious principle and this specious argument. It comes back to the question as to whether Telecom is going to be used for that purpose. I would like to know why Janet Strickland has said that there are likely to be more complaints about advertisements for the new service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just add to Senator Harradine's question and ask the Minister whether he can tell us how they will differ from the present ones.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is becoming bizarre now. Mr Chairman, how could I make that judgment in advance of the committee even being formed? The question is nonsense. The committee not only has not yet determined whether or how it will be different; the committee has not even been established. How can I answer that question? It is a stupid question.

—If that is the case, then everything the Minister has been saying is a lot of rubbish because he would not know. He cannot tell whether what is proposed is going to be more offensive to women or more detrimental. It just points to the fact that he does not have a clue what he is talking about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose we cannot get the information now because the Minister has said that he will ask the board of directors, but I will be very interested to hear what the board of directors says and I will also be very interested to hear what the Minister says. But what is happening in the meantime in respect of these services? These are the sorts of questions that I would like to have posed at the Estimates Committee. I understand that there is a problem in doing it here, because it is better to do it across the table with the officers of Telecom Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: But I feel that certain questions I have raised have not been answered. Perhaps the following in particular could be taken on notice. Have any service providers breached any of the operational requirements relating to message or advertising standards-that is, the current message and advertising standards-contained in the operational requirements which are part and parcel of the contract of a service which a service provider must pay? Telecom answered that partially on page 5 of the answers that it has given us. In respect of those particular matters, was a determination made under clause 8(4) of the contract? Given the fact that Telecom officers in their answer to me have indicated that certain action is being taken about on-disc connections and the fact that these breaches have taken place, is there any problem with wiping indecent material off 0055 now? Why can Telecom not just wipe the material from 0055?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the first part of Senator Harradine's question, he has of course already been provided, in the answers that have been provided to questions on notice, with a list of complaints where there have been breaches and where the action that Telecom took in respect of each case was disconnection of the service. I would assume-and I just ask for clarification from Senator Harradine here-that what he is seeking further to this is a list of all breaches where disconnection was not the action.
—Yes, and why.
—I am happy to take that question on notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise an associated matter that has arisen in Senator Collins's electorate and my own with regard to the areas of obscene and unwanted phone calls. This issue has its derivation not as the 0055 numbers but rather the international publications that use phone numbers from another country which, when they cross the STD codes of Australia, are now causing major concern. For example, one of my constituents has written to me-and I will make a copy of this representation available to the Minister-concerning various numbers in a company switchboard that is now deriving from a British magazine called Electric Blue which then lists a number of what I would call kinky and very unusual types of phone calls. The phone numbers listed against each of the services start with the number 089, followed by a series of numbers. Well, 089 is the STD prefix for the Northern Territory and, as these magazines are widely distributed in newsagencies around Australia and are generally available, it is causing concern to the Telecom subscriber in the Northern Territory who is now receiving unsolicited and unwanted calls which actually derive from a British sales campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very interested and, whilst I would certainly support the comments of both Senator Harradine and Senator Newman as to the need for legislation in this total regard, there is obviously a need for close attention to this expanding problem and as to how it will also arise in the administration of Telecom.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that Senator Tambling appreciates that this is an entirely different matter, where it is simply a problem with the wrong numbers being called. I am not personally familiar with the problem, but of course it does not relate in any way to the 0055 matter that we are now discussing; it is simply a question of overseas numbers duplicating numbers in Australia. I am certainly happy to have a look at the problem but, if the magazine is an overseas magazine, if it is publishing British telephone numbers which are genuine for that service which simply happen to duplicate similar telephone numbers in Australia, on the face of it it would be very difficult, I would think, for any sensible action to be taken about it. But I am certainly happy, if I receive the correspondence, to act on it.
—Senator Tambling, I would point out to you that this matter is a bit out of the scope of the Estimates, but I am being a little liberal.
—I will be very brief, Mr Chairman. I hope that Telecom will make the appropriate arrangements to address this problem and will arrange for the change of phone numbers, if necessary.
—I will do that.
—I just ask the Minister the simple question: is Telecom happy that all the sexual messages, invitations and communications, et cetera, on 0055 are suitable for young children to have access to?
—Of course not.
—Then, I ask: why does not Telecom immediately-because children have access to them-do something about it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would suggest that, if Senator Walters has particular instances of where children have been accessing these adult services, she should provide them to Telecom.
—Can the Minister guarantee me that, if I give that immediate verification, Telecom will immediately alter the whole of that particular 0055 area and take it off the air?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I will not give any such foolish guarantee sight unseen. Frankly, I am amazed-knowing Senator Walters's views on this subject-that if she has this information she would wait until this matter simply came up in the dying moments of the Estimates process even to raise it. I am astonished if she has got information-and I can assure Senator Walters that this particular matter is one I take very seriously-that she has not already approached Telecom with it.
—Is the Minister saying that Telecom believes-I am not concerned about the Minister's view on this-that children do not use that number? Is that what the Minister is trying to tell me?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Mr Chairman. What I am is saying is that I have learnt in the brief time that I have been here to discount by about 99 per cent everything Senator Walters says. What I am very sensibly suggesting to Senator Walters is that rather than simply canvassing in broad terms a specific complaint she has got and expecting me to give a Government commitment on the basis of it-which is an extraordinary proposition-if she has got specific concerns and can in fact produce evidence that children have been accessing services which are not designed for them, I prevail upon her to please provide it at the earliest opportunity to Telecom.

—The Minister has already made it very clear that he does not mind his young children doing that. But there are a lot of parents who do object and who have very grave concerns that this does occur. I can assure the Minister that it does occur and if he wants it chapter and verse, we will do so. But is Telecom suggesting for one minute that it believes young children will not avail themselves of this facility? That is a question I would like answered by Telecom officers. Do they believe that children do not avail themselves? Are they expecting the politicians to bring them proof before they accept that children--
—You said you had it.

—That is right. Are they expecting politicians to bring them proof that children will access this or are they just sitting back and saying, `No, children do not do it'? I would be most interested in Telecom's answer to that very simple question. If, as the Minister has said, Telecom is not happy with children accessing it, why is it available for children to use?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The only thing on which I am in agreement with Senator Walters is that it certainly was a very simple question. But the fact is that children do not have access to it. The services are access barred.
—I am sorry, that is not true.

—Senator Walters is talking about two different things. She again misquoted what I said yesterday. She talked about what I said in respect of the sexual advice services-and I must say that in my view they are excellent-that are available on 0055. I specified the ones I was talking about. We are talking about two different things. Advice on masturbation, impotence, frigidity or other common sexual problems is available on 0055. My own family doctor tells me that as far as he is aware it is accurate advice. I might add that it is entirely uncontroversial.

SPEECH.PARA: What I said yesterday, and I stand by it, is that I would have no difficulty with my 12 year-old son wanting to hear over a telephone, rather than from me, any advice that he needs-which he probably would need at this age of his life-on areas such as masturbation, impotence, frigidity or any of these other things. I must say that, here again, it is just a question of one's personal view of the world. At the age of 12 or 13, as a child is approaching sexual maturity, parents have got an obligation to provide this advice. I can assure Senator Walters, having accessed these particular numbers she is talking about, that we are talking about different things entirely. Senator Walters is taking the very simple approach that anything that has got sex attached to it has all got to be lumped into one big pot and it is all dirty.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's nonsense.

—It is nonsense, I agree-absolute nonsense. We are talking about two different services. Senator Walters is talking about services where clinically correct advice-and I must say fairly sympathetic advice-on these problems is given by a very pleasant lady with, I think, an American accent. Of course, it also contains the very sensible advice that if what she says does not answer the problems that a person has, that person should seek further advice from the counsellors that exist. The advice is so innocuous that I would have no difficulty in my 12 year-old son having access to it. But what we are talking about is the sexually explicit material which is access barred.
—It is not.
—Hang on.
—You are wrong.
—Well, as I said before, if Senator Walters has evidence that children are getting access to material that in her view they should not be getting access to, please provide it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night during the Committee of the Whole debate, I gave the Minister a very clear example of the problem that constituents in my State were having in lodging complaints with Telecom on this very issue. I know there have been a number of complaints. I asked the Minister whether that was a typical problem that people were having right around Australia. It is not good enough for him to come in here now and say that members of parliament should be giving examples. I can tell him, for example, of a 14 year-old boy that ran up a telephone bill of $37 over two or three months. His mother could not understand why the phone bill was like that. It was only after I gave some publicity to this matter that she realised what the problem was and had a talk to her son. It is not good enough for the Minister to hide behind the sorts of things he has been saying.

SPEECH.PARA: The 0055 numbers are all accessible to children no matter what kind of information is being purveyed. What is he going to do about it? Why is Telecom not taking any action although it recognises what is happening? I understand the United States Congress has stopped this sort of stuff going over American telephones because children were using it. Senator Walters has asked a pretty fair question. I want to make sure that Senator Collins understands that children can and do have access to it. Telecom is aware of complaints. It would be aware of a lot more complaints if the system for lodging complaints was made simpler, instead of people being told to write to their local newspaper and having to be very pushy in order to get Telecom actually to record a complaint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe the Minister is now getting the information he was lacking before, because he is totally incorrect when he talks about 0055 being barred.
—I wasn't talking about that.
—Yes, you were.
—That is what you said. You said it twice.
—No, it is not.

—It will be interesting to read Hansard because fortunately Hansard takes it down. I asked him a very simple question and he acknowledged that it was a pretty simple question. I asked: was Telecom happy that all the sexual messages, communications and invitations on 0055 are suitable for young children? He said no. Then he said that the ones he was talking about, that he thought were all right for his children, were totally different from what I was talking about. He said the ones I was talking about were barred.
—Access barred.
—They are not access barred at all. If Senator Collins leans over to listen to his officer, I think he will be told that he is wrong.
—I don't want to lean over to the officer.
—For heaven's sake, Senator Collins should get it straight before he gives misinformation to this Committee. They are not access barred.
—Unless on request.
—Unless the parents want them access barred; unless the parents ring Telecom and say, `Please bar my telephone'. The majority of parents do not have a clue that it is even available.
—Don't they read their telephone accounts?
—No; they do not read the telephone book and are not au fait with what--
—The accounts, I said.

—He says, `Wait until it's too late. Wait until they get $37 worth of telephone calls put on their bill and then ring and ask for it to be barred'. My point is that the Government's philosophy-we have been told by the Minister umpteen times today-is that adults ought to be able to see, read and hear whatever they like, so long as children are protected, bearing in mind certain restrictions, such as child pornography, et cetera. But he stresses that children should be protected. At the moment Telecom is making-I do not know how much; I will come to that a bit later-perhaps millions of dollars. It is hauling in all this money and allowing access by children to all this 0055 information. The Minister tells us not to worry and says it is barred access. Well, it is not barred access; the Minister is totally wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister once again: If Telecom is opposed to this and if it does not believe that those messages are suitable for young children, why does it not do something about it? Why does it not take these messages off and therefore protect the children, which the Minister tells us is the philosophy of the Government?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue was canvassed at length not only during the Committee hearing but also yesterday, but I will again go over it. The access-barred services to which I referred are services which undoubtedly contain messages that are sexually explicit and not suitable for children. There is no question about it. That is the one-to-one service that can be accessed through the mailboxes of this service. However, there are services such as the ones that Senator Walters--
—I am talking about 0055 and you know it.

—Senator Walters should let me finish. However, there are services, such as the ones that Senator Walters is now discussing, that are not access barred and which, as I said yesterday, having accessed them myself, I consider to be innocuous. However, as I also said yesterday, I had concerns about the service being provided with no opt-out facility available. When 0055 was first put in I approached Telecom. As I said yesterday, it responded by providing a free opt-out service. This means that anyone who wants to get out of the system can do so at no cost and all charges are separately identified on an account.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I also conceded to Senator Harradine yesterday-he has acknowledged it twice today and I have confirmed that acknowledgment-that there are concerns about this service which I consider to be legitimate, and yesterday I said so. All I can do is reiterate the commitment I gave yesterday, which was confirmed again this morning to Senator Harradine when he raised it, and assure the Committee and Senator Walters that, in respect of all the matters that have been raised-in particular, and I mentioned it again this morning, the suggestion for having an opt-in approach rather than an opt-out approach to 0055 is probably worthy of consideration-I will ensure that they are brought to the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley). I will ask the Minister to ensure that they are discussed. Now that the service has been operating and now that this discussion has been generated, it is appropriate that these matters be discussed by the board of Telecom. I will ensure that that happens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Telecom is not even enforcing its own operational requirements. What the Minister said this morning and yesterday is contrary to Telecom's operational requirements for message standard. The Telecom board has never agreed to this specious argument about adults being free to read and view what they wish. That specious argument allows Telecom to act as a publisher for the sexploit merchants. But we are talking about message content, message standards. These are operational requirements that are part and parcel of the contract which Telecom enters into with the service providers. Therefore, the service providers are bound by that contract. Message standard 1.1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) This standard has been prepared with regard to the following principle:-
That all persons calling any 0055 Information Service are entitled to protection from exposure to messages of an indecent, obscene or sexually suggestive nature.

The Service Provider will not provide ``knowingly or negligently'' on any 0055 number allocated to it, any information which, in any way, may be interpreted as indecent, obscene, offensive or sexually titillating or denoting sexual suggestion or sexual fantasy.
I ask the Minister: why does Telecom not enforce those operational requirements? The answer provided to my question 12, which related to this, states:
Telecom's position is that message content should conform to the standard as specified in Operational Requirements 1.1-
I have just read that. The answer continues:
There has been no change to policy since the issuing of paper No. 3 dated 31st January 1990.

Why is Telecom not enforcing that? Why was it necessary to get Janet Strickland in to push for the lines to be opened up so that worse material could be included on them? That is pretty plain. I ask honourable senators to consider the current message standards for 0055. Clearly, Telecom is not enforcing that. Why does it not do so immediately? As Senator Walters said, it has legal contracts with the service providers; it can enforce them overnight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said at some tedious length in this debate, what judgment one makes on the content of those messages very much depends on where one sits in the world. In my view, Telecom is behaving in an extremely responsible manner. Senator Harradine's views on Janet Strickland are well known; I am extremely familiar with them, and he is entitled to them. But I do not see anything wrong with Telecom's judgment in setting up what I found to be a comprehensive and useful set of recommendations by Janet Strickland, who, because of her background, has significant and considerable experience in the area of censorship. Again, the approach that Telecom is taking to set up a committee to establish standards, with direct community input, despite sniggering from those opposite, is the appropriate way to go. That is what Telecom is doing. When those standards and guidelines are established-the committee will be set up within a month-then it will be appropriate for that matter to be canvassed, as no doubt it will be, in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: In the meantime I have given an undertaking, which I reiterate, to bring the concerns-and I think I will certainly give proper expression to them-that have been raised in this debate, principally by Senator Newman and Senator Harradine, to the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications and ensure that they are brought to the attention of the Telecom board.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Minister is doing that, I ask: what is wrong with these standards? Could the Minister take that on board too and ask both the Minister for Transport and Communications and the Telecom board what is wrong with their current standards?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope I do not have to say it again. What I said, and I meant it, was that I will take all of the concerns--
—That is a specific question.

—I will take all of the concerns. Please accept that in the simple English meaning of the word: `all' means `all'. I will take all of the concerns that have been raised by Senator Newman and, indeed, other honourable senators during this debate and discuss them with Minister Beazley, who is the responsible Minister. I will ask him to consider bringing these matters to the attention of the Telecom board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just cannot believe what is going on here. We cannot account for or explain the difference between our standards and those of the Minister, nor can we explain the difference between our standards and those of the female senators on the Australian Labor Party side, who profess to champion the causes of feminism and the rights of women. They profess to protect all of those things, yet last night, when the Minister swore in this chamber, one of his colleagues, who has just now left the chamber, sat there and laughed because we took offence at the remark. They now react in the same way to our taking offence at things that are in this phone book readily accessible by all people. Examples include: `Abortion. Who can help?'; `Condoms and Safe Sex'; `Contraception'. Why should not those seeking advice on these matters go to a doctor? Why does the Minister insist that all of this must be on telephone lines?

SPEECH.PARA: There is a thing called an `Insult Line'. One does not need a telephone line for that. All we have to do is stand up in the Senate and ask the Minister a question. We get enough insults to last a lifetime. We found that out last night. Members of the public who were tuned in to the AM radio program would have found it out this morning, when the Minister's pearls of wisdom were dropped all around Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does this have to do with the estimates?

—I inform the Minister that this has a lot to do with the estimates. It has to do with his intransigence in this area. He thinks that it is quite all right for children and adults alike, for perverts or whoever, to ring any number they like in this telephone book.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the question that I put on notice to the Minister on 18 September this year, and to which he responded in his usual most flippant way. I asked what it cost for Janet Strickland to do this review or whatever it was that she was asked to do-heaven only knows-and the Minister said that it was commercial confidentiality between Telecom and Janet Strickland and Associates. Because it was an arrangement between Telecom and Janet Strickland, is it not taxpayers' money that has paid for that review? If so, are we not entitled as taxpayers, and the public of Australia, to know how much that cost? I ask three questions. First, is it taxpayers' money? Secondly, how much did that review cost? Thirdly, how much is Janet Strickland going to be paid for becoming the Telecom arbitrator?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that any honourable senators on the Opposition side who really want to canvass the subject of parliamentary behaviour-and I am talking about even in very recent times-would be on very thin ice indeed, if I could say that with respect.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the other matters raised by the honourable senator, I have no doubt that the consultancy would have been paid by Telecom from its revenue, which it gains from the provision of services. It is a net contributor to the public wealth in this country, not a mendicant organisation that relies on taxpayers' money; in fact, it provides a considerable flow of revenue to the public purse the other way. But one of the reasons that these organisations are set up a step distance from government is to provide them with the flexibility of taking commercial decisions. The Telecom board has entered into an arrangement with Janet Strickland, as no doubt it enters into arrangements with a whole lot of other people, which quite properly are considered to be commercially confidential. There is no question about their right to do that.

Senator Knowles talked about people being able to ring up and get advice on things like safe sex and condoms. I have to say again that I personally would have preferred to have lived in a world where I could have chosen the time when I wanted to talk to my children about condoms. I make no bones about that. I did not particularly like being in a situation where, a few years ago, at the height of the AIDS scare, I went to the Darwin show--

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not give a continental what you would have liked.

—If that is so, why did the honourable senator raise it in debate? A few years ago when I went to the Darwin show, I was approached by Condo the Clown, who was handing out free condoms and safe sex information, not over the telephone line but wandering around a showground doing it. The thing is, I cannot take particular exception to that any more because I frankly do not want my son to die.
—Why don't you teach him? Why don't you take your responsibility?

—I do. All I am saying is that I am afraid that the world we live in today forces us, as parents, to make this advice available in a different and more open way than that in which parents previously had to make it available. The circumstances, regrettably, force it upon us.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, it is just a matter of subjective judgment as to whether one finds these services offensive or not offensive, and there will always be a never-ending debate on that. At the end of the day, it is a question of judgment. All I can say again is that I take seriously the concerns that have been raised in this debate, as I take seriously the concerns that are raised in any debate. I have a reputation--

TALK.START.PARA: —You could have fooled us.

—If I could be allowed to finish: although I am referring specifically to the Estimates committee process, I do not think that the Opposition will be able to find that I have given a commitment either in the Committee of the Whole or indeed the Senate committees proper that has not been discharged to the best of my ability. When honourable senators have wanted from officers briefings of a detailed nature, they have been provided. If they have wanted questions chased up, they have been chased up and answered promptly, as will the questions from yesterday be chased up.

SPEECH.PARA: All I can say in conclusion is that in respect of the matters that Senator Knowles raised, I do not know why she complained. The Insult Line is just a joke service, as the honourable senator would find out if she used it-and it is quite funny too. In respect of the safe sex line--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you run it?
—Yes, I have rung the Insult Line. I have rung the daily joke line and the weekly joke line.
—I never said `rung', I said `run it'.

—Some of the jokes are quite funny. In fact, ringing that line is a hoot compared with being in here and engaging in this debate, I can assure the honourable senator. All I can say is that I give Senator Knowles a commitment to take to Minister Beazley all of the concerns that have been raised, in particular, that about access, which I consider to be an important one. I will request Minister Beazley to advise me of his position on it-and I will respond to the chamber when I have that advice-and to request the Telecom board to consider it.
—I ask the Minister: is Telecom a public utility?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a statutory corporation. I do not have to define Telecom; Senator Knowles knows what it is.

—If that is the case, why on earth can the Minister not disclose how much money Janet Strickland was paid and is to be paid? I believe the subscribers of Telecom have every right in the world to know why their telephone charges and costs are continuing to escalate when Telecom is spending money and for some reason or another the Minister is not prepared to disclose the amount. No-one can tell me or anybody else that it is straight out commercial confidentiality. It is obviously a very, very substantial amount for this charade to go on.
—It is a monopoly.

—It is a total and utter monopoly, as Senator Newman just said. Telecom does not have to advertise. What else can we do? If we want to make a phone call, who, other than Telecom, are we to use? Here we have a situation in which money has been squandered and the Minister does not have the courage to tell us how much has been squandered. The people of Australia are entitled to know. Does the Minister think the people of Australia, the Telecom subscribers, are entitled to know how much Telecom is wasting on this exercise?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I dare say it is commercially confidential for the same reason as that which applied for 10 years in the Northern Territory Parliament when I consistently asked questions of the Northern Territory Government about the myriad consultancies it appointed--
—I am not interested in the Northern Territory position.

—They are the conservative colleagues of Senator Knowles. I received precisely the same response: these were commercially confidential matters that were really none of my business. Telecom has the right to enter into contracts; it has a board which runs the organisation. Telecom has a right to enter into contracts that are of a commercially confidential nature. It has done so on this occasion; it is able to do so.
—Do subscribers have a right to know how much money Telecom is spending on it?

—The honourable senator has already alluded to the fact that that answer has been given, not only twice now this morning but also in writing on notice. However, I will again bring this concern to the attention of the Minister, and if a response can be provided it will be.
—Why do the Commonwealth guidelines say that the cost of all consultancies must be listed in the annual report, and yet the annual report of Telecom does not contain that answer?
—For the fifth time, I will obtain an answer from the Minister responsible for Telecom and provide it to the honourable senator.

—My question is in respect of Discovery. In the standards set out for classification, under the heading `Refused Entry', reference is made to all text describing sexual activity involving a non-consenting person-for example, gratuitous descriptions of rape or torture. Can the Minister say why the word `gratuitous' is there? In other words, are normal texts describing rape-not gratuitous, but rape-permitted? Why is the word `gratuitous' included? There must be a reason for it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with Senator Walters, I was a member of a committee which spent about 95 hours, from memory, discussing the interpretation of the word `gratuitous'. That committee never resolved the meaning of `gratuitous', and no doubt its meaning will not be resolved here.

—That is wrong, because every member of the committee understood what `gratuitous' meant. I am surprised that Senator Collins now claims that members of the committee did not. I am quite sure Senator Collins is the only member of that committee who does not understand what `gratuitous' means. I asked a question of the Minister which he did not answer: are all texts which describe sexual activity involving non-consenting persons refused entry if they describe rape-not gratuitous, but rape?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an absolute prohibition on violence. Rape is probably the most extreme form of violence against a person one could imagine, and there would be no question about that being prohibited material.

—In respect of the video industry, I agree with the Minister that it would be one of the most violent depictions of sexual activity. I agree with the Minister wholeheartedly, but his Government of course allows that sort of thing to be shown throughout Australia. In respect of the `R' category, we have depictions of rape in many videos. I wonder why the Government allows that, but it does. My question on Telecom is tied in with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two questions. The first one is in respect of a question quite validly raised by Senator Knowles. She raised it a long time before I did and she raised it as a question on notice; I raised it on notice following the Estimates Committee. It is in respect of payments made to Janet Strickland and Associates Pty Ltd by Telecom. Senator Collins said to me, in a voice loaded with inference, `Oh, I know your views about Janet Strickland.' I have met Janet Strickland; she is quite a pleasant person. However, we are dealing with what is, as the Minister conceded, a very important issue. It is the question of who is to make the decision about where to draw the line. In order to have a paper prepared to bomb Telecom's own current standards-which I read out a moment ago; I wonder why they were not okay-Telecom appointed Janet Strickland. Last night I asked whether Telecom knew Janet Strickland, prior to her appointment for this purpose, was an advocate for the Film and Video Coalition, that part of her consultancy was to oppose moves to tighten censorship guidelines and that she is on the record as being opposed to the tightening of guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: It was-it should have been-important for Telecom to know the views of the person it was appointing. Janet Strickland has brought out a report which recommends the establishment of a committee to determine standards, but that committee will be bound by the `philosophy' that adults are free to read and view what they wish. As I have indicated before, that is a specious argument because adults are not free to view anti-female propaganda unless it is published by Telecom on their computers or they hear it over the telephone. The question is whether the Government is prepared to allow Telecom to act, in effect, as a publisher and agent for the sexploiters. That standards committee will be bound by the Strickland philosophy.
Janet Strickland then recommended the appointment of a Telecom service arbitrator to receive complaints from the public about content and advertising. On page 15 of her report, Janet Strickland says:

. . . `adult' messages will only be accessible on an `opt-in' basis, the number of complaints received or disputes arising about the content of the Telephone Information Service messages are unlikely to be substantial.

The reason for that presumably is that open access will not be available to them. Nevertheless, the same type of material which has the same mediating effect on the minds of listeners and viewers to Discovery and the listeners of 0055 will be there-that is, the same anti-female propaganda will be going over.

Janet Strickland does say that complaints about advertisements for adult telephone information service messages may increase. She recommends the appointment of an arbitrator. Telecom has accepted that recommendation and appointed her as the arbitrator. There was no consultation at all-none with the Minister, none with the Parliament, and none with the public-about the appointment of Janet Strickland as the arbitrator. I want answers to the following questions: how much was Janet Strickland and Associates Pty Ltd paid for reporting on the 0055 service? How much will she be paid as arbitrator, to do a job which she herself concedes will not amount to much? I think this is important, because we have had discussions about Telecom's pay rates before in this chamber going back many years, as a matter of fact; I think it all started in 1981.

It is important that we know what Telecom has paid for this consultancy and what it proposes to pay for the appointment of Janet Strickland. I remind the Committee that that appointment was undertaken by Telecom without advertising the job, without consultation with the community, without consultation with the Parliament, and without consultation with the Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I really can add nothing to the precise answers which I gave to the same question yesterday and again this morning; that is, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) has provided written answers to questions on notice on this very matter. I will advise the Minister that the answers he has provided are not satisfactory to some honourable senators and I will ask him to consider providing further information. I have said that before and I will say it again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My final question concerns Austel. Could the Minister please refer this question to Mr Beazley or answer it himself: what role should Austel play in this particular area, given the fact that there will be another player in the area of telecommunications services? At present we are talking about Telecom Australia but, as we all know, there will be another player.

SPEECH.PARA: From a reading of Janet Strickland's report, it appears to me that Austel has just washed its hands of everything. I cannot understand why that is the case because, when we were dealing with the Austel legislation here, the impression was given by the Government that Austel would be overviewing the services that are provided by Telecom and presumably by other players who might enter into the field. The Austel Act requires Austel to ensure `that carriers achieve the highest possible levels of accountability and responsiveness to customer and community needs'. It has as one of its objectives `to ensure the proper use of telecommunications networks in the supply of value added services'.

I do not know what Austel has been doing. From a reading of Janet Strickland's report, it appears that Austel has just washed its hands of its responsibilities in these particular areas. I would like a response from the Minister, or the Minister whom he represents, as to where Austel should fit into this not only in so far as Telecom is concerned but also with regard to other players in the game.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not disagree at all with Senator Harradine's interpretation of what Austel was set up to do. It would seem to me that this would certainly be an appropriate matter for it to consider. I have no information at the moment; frankly, I do not know. I will ask Mr Beazley what involvement Austel has had in 0055 services, if any, and provide that answer to the honourable senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I am the concluding speaker in this debate. It is quite clear to all of us that many questions remain unanswered, and the Minister has given an undertaken to get answers. He has also promised that he will have them chased up and answered properly.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night at 10.15, I asked the Minister three questions which were capable of being answered by the officers present, or those who should have been present-after all, Senator Harradine gave notice that he wanted to have the question of the 0055 numbers reserved to be debated in the Committee of the Whole. If those officers were not present, it should have been perfectly possible for the Minister, either at that time, or first thing this morning, to have made a telephone call and got the specific responses that were needed. At 10.15 this morning, that is, 12 hours after I originally asked those questions, the Minister was quite abusive and unhelpful-certainly at least unhelpful-in his response to me when I asked again for answers to those questions.

It is now over 13 hours since those questions were asked. They may seem to be trivial to the Minister, but they are important to us. Let me demonstrate why. The 0055 numbers are available to all Australians, including children. Telecom had with the service providers of the sex telephone calls contractual arrangements which entitled it to discontinue those services based on content or advertising. Despite complaints, Telecom chose not to exercise its contractual rights and instead did what Labor Party governments certainly do, but other governments have been known to do; that is, it set up a committee. The whole question was a bit hard, so Telecom set up a committee with Mrs Strickland, whose views were known to the Government-and I put it no higher than that.

Mrs Strickland came back with some very predictable recommendations which have now been sitting around for about six weeks. The Minister has told us that the recommendations will be implemented within about a month. One recommendation was to set up yet another committee comprising an independent chairman-any committee's outcome is likely to be determined very much by the care with which the choice of chairman is made; one arbitrator, who we believe to be Mrs Strickland, and we know what views she will hold; one representative of Telecom-in other words, the status quo; and two service providers whose vested interests are obviously to maintain the status quo. We then have a recommendation that there be two consultative groups taking part-a minority. We cannot be sure, but we believe that two out of seven members on this committee might be interested in the effects of this service on consumer groups and on society generally.

I asked the Minister a specific question as to which consumer groups had been consulted over the last six weeks or perhaps more, and that simple question has not been able to be answered in 13 hours. I also asked the Minister which consumer groups had been asked to put in nominations for possible appointment to this committee, which is important to our future. Whether it will be able to do anything worth while is another matter, but it has the potential to be extremely important. He was not able to answer that either.

The question of complaints has been very much an issue. I also drew attention to the difficulties that consumers have in lodging complaints with Telecom and asked for that to be investigated and for a response. I have not had a response as to whether the situation that my constituents in Tasmania are experiencing is typical of the situation around Australia.

I find 13 hours of non-response from the Government and from Telecom to be totally unacceptable. I therefore propose to give the Government one more chance. I intend now to give the Government the opportunity to get those answers for us while the Committee of the Whole is investigating the report on the Attorney-General's Department. I move:

That further consideration of the motion in respect of the Department of Transport and Communications be postponed till after consideration of the motion in respect of the Attorney-General's Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing this motion because, in terms of a time-wasting exercise-and I was hoping that this would not have to be said-this would have to be a monumental one and I hope the Committee will reject it. The unbelievably specious ground on which this motion has been moved-and I intend to give a very precise response to Senator Newman on this-is that the three questions that were asked in this debate late last night have not been answered this morning.
—Thirteen hours ago.

—Thirteen hours ago. Honourable senators will be voting on this motion and are entitled to know just how unreasonable, mischievous and silly this motion is. I gave an undertaking to the chamber last night that I would provide Senator Newman with answers to her questions by the end of business today, and I will ensure that that happens. I do not think I have missed a deadline in respect of questions yet. I thought that was a reasonable undertaking.

SPEECH.PARA: What I said more specifically was-and I do not think I could have been more frank or honest with the chamber-that I had no intention of dragging someone out of bed last night. Thousands of hours are spent by officers in serving Senate committees, and Senator Newman should know it. Thousands of hours are put in by public servants, as they have to do, rightly, to service these Senate committees. I certainly considered the questions important enough to get answers, but I did not think that tonight was an unreasonable time to provide them.

I will give Senator Newman an account of my movements in the last 13 hours to explain why I did not personally drag a Telecom officer out of bed late last night to provide her with these answers this morning. I worked in my office until one o'clock this morning. I left at the crack of dawn and went out to have a look at the new Siemens-Plessey radar system that is being offered for installation at Sydney airport. I got back here, having had what I thought was an extremely useful morning looking at this new radar flight system, at a quarter to 10.

I have asked my office, of course, in the meantime, as I always do, to pursue this matter with Telecom. It is doing so, and I will have an answer to all of Senator Newman's questions at the time I gave an undertaking last night to have it; that is, by the close of business today. I have always, and my record will show it, treated all questions asked in committee seriously and I have always personally pursued answers to them and made sure that they are provided the instant they are available.

Senator Newman makes this suggestion when officers are present, and there are more of them outside. It is not just a question of inconveniencing members of this chamber; it is a question of inconveniencing a large number of officers who have already spent a considerable amount of time-they are not Canberra-based officers-here in Canberra at the service of this Senate on something as specious as this. I say again to the Committee, with all reason, that I gave Senator Newman an undertaking last night that I will have answers to her three questions.

To get to the nub of this motion, I do not think that the fate of Tasmania is going to rest on getting an answer at this instant rather than later on today-and, hopefully, I will be able to provide this immediately after the lunch break-as to which people Telecom has consulted about 0055. Considering what I know of the efforts that these officers have put in-and I do know-to dig them out of bed at midnight to provide answers by this morning I think would have been unreasonable.

In respect of just how unreasonable it is, I just say-and I can assure Senator Harradine that I am not having a crack at him-that honourable senators are also entitled to know the background of the discussion on this issue before they vote on this motion. The appropriate place to discuss issues of this detail, without question-there is not a senator in here who would deny it, and in fact Senator Harradine confirmed it this morning-is in the committee process where, as Senator Harradine said, it is done across the table in a far less formal fashion.
