Of course, it is far more productive for that reason, with the officers participating to the same extent as the Minister in providing honourable senators with information, which is the point of the Estimates exercise.

The difficulty was that no-one indicated that 0055 officers were required at those Estimates Committee hearings until Senator Harradine-and fair enough- requested that they be present two hours prior to the Committee sitting. I can tell honourable senators that, despite that incredibly short notice and despite the fact that these officers are based in Sydney, not Canberra, efforts were made-as they always would be, I am sure-to get officers out of their offices, onto planes and to Canberra, despite the fact that this is an issue of such great moment that no-one in the Opposition requested that this information be provided at the appropriate place, which is the Estimates Committee itself. Neither Senator Newman nor any single member of the Opposition did that. The only person who did request these officers to be present was Senator Harradine.

This was all explained at the Committee. Efforts were made to comply and to get these officers on aircraft. It simply was not physically possible, with two hours notice that they were required, to get them there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why two hours notice?

—Why two hours? Because, as I say again, that is when Senator Harradine gave notice to the Secretary of the Committee that he would require officers from the 0055 service, which is a discrete section of Telecom, to be present. As I said before, no Opposition member even asked. As a result of that, the opportunity to have this matter debated in the proper place, to use this Senate chamber with some expedition and efficiency, was lost.

SPEECH.PARA: I can assure the Committee, before it votes on this motion, that that is the background to it. I did try to ensure that officers, despite only two hours notice, could be present. They physically were not able to be. Senator Harradine accepted that and took up the offer-and, as far as I know, he is the only one who did-to have, after the Senate Estimates Committee hearing, a full and detailed briefing from Telecom officers because of the lack of notice that was given to get them to the Senate Committee hearings, which is what should have happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have to give notice.

—I would like to respond to that interjection because it does Senator Reid no credit to make it, and I am sure she knows it. Senator Reid interjected, `You don't have to give notice for every officer that you want'. Of course not. There is no standing order that says one has to. But I thought what we were all trying to do in this Senate chamber was to make the Senate a more effective forum for serving the senators who serve in it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have never forgotten my first Senate Estimates experience. I can remember talking to Senator Parer about it, actually, in the corridor outside. I was appalled by that experience because the way in which it was run-and no-one in here would deny it-when we were in the old Parliament House, was scandalous. I will tell honourable senators what my first Estimates committee experience was: to come down to the old committee room in the old Parliament House to see a phalanx- and people know this is true. We have made considerable progress because of the courtesies and commonsense-in response to Senator Reid's interjection-of giving a little prior notice to ensure that people are not ripped out of their normal jobs for 18 or 20 hours for nothing. We have made considerable progress, as Senator Reid knows, in providing some sensible advice.

What Senator Reid is saying by her interjection is that we do not have to provide any management of the system at all; that senators have no obligation; that we are special, superbeings who can just expect people-highly paid public servants, all or any of them-who might conceivably be asked a question to turn up. Senator Reid knows that is not what we are striving to do in this chamber, but that is how we used to do it. It was a scandal and a disgrace.

I have never forgotten my first experience in Estimates. A group of four officers turned up at 2 o'clock in the afternoon for that Senate Estimates committee meeting. They waited in Parliament House the entire day for their little section to be dealt with. At 11 o'clock at night-and I was sitting next to Senator Parer when this happened-after waiting all that time, they presented themselves at the witness table and were not asked a solitary question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was running the Estimates then?

—Well, we all do, as the honourable senator well knows. It is not the Chairman who runs it, Senator. As Minister, I have taken the attitude-and the honourable senator knows it-that we are in the hands of the Committee even though we adopt an approach to make the process as useful as possible to all honourable senators. It is not a question of the Chairman running the Committee, and Senator Vanstone knows it. At the committees that I have attended, I have made every single officer available-including those from government business enterprises that are not strictly required to be there-when they have been asked for. That was done on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, this is an appalling proposal to waste further the time of the Committee and it should be resisted at all costs. Further, I again give the undertaking which I gave last night-I will provide the answers at the time I promised to give them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has heard about wasting time and we notice that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) has just run out of his allotted speaking time of 15 minutes. He has talked about the courtesies and commonsense that should be extended to officers. On a number of occasions yesterday and today I have noticed officers in the lounge area adjacent to the chamber who have been kept waiting because of the time that has been taken in this chamber by Senator Collins's long, tedious and boring answers. Many of his answers are based totally on anecdotal comments of his own personal views and do not reflect the policies of the Government or provide the information that is being sought by senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to support the motion of Senator Newman that the Committee needs to seek information before the Committee proceeds. Although I placed on notice before the Estimates Committee in the first week of September questions in the area of Minister Collins's responsibility, it took some six to seven weeks for all of them to be answered. At one stage, Senator Collins took umbrage when I suggested that perhaps some of that delay had been occasioned because a Northern Territory election was in progress and some of the answers that came back might have been embarrassing to the Federal Government. Senator Collins subsequently assured me in this chamber that, of course, none of them came back except on the days on which they reached his good office. I only hope that there was no blocking in the corridors in any way in getting that information returned.

I think it is important to note that Senator Newman is stressing the point that the Committee needs to be assured that we can have answers in the appropriate time. Certainly, from my experience, we have had to put up with delays in answers to formal questions on notice that could have been answered directly and immediately. There was no need for any of those answers to have been withheld. There was no need for any of them to have been held up or kept back. As Senator Newman has very rightly said, it is important that the answers to the questions very properly asked yesterday should have been provided to this chamber this morning. There is no way that the Committee can have confidence in what this Minister says. Instead of getting answers and information, all we get are anecdotes and excuses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to give a specific response to that piece of nonsense. I would indicate once again the amount of effort that has to be put in by highly paid public servants-I would have thought that that was a matter of some concern to the Estimates Committee-to provide what are often just absolute wide net and wide mesh fishing expeditions in respect of what are totally unwarranted complaints.
—You might not like accountability, but it is part of our democracy.
—Would the honourable senator mind not interjecting consistently, again. She did it all day yesterday; just give it a rest.
—Oh, dear!

—What we have just heard from Senator Knowles is the sort of attitude taken by honourable senators opposite-that the kind of effort that has to go into providing these questions is irrelevant. We could spend-and we have-hours and hours in a Senate committee asking questions--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would ask that Senator Collins be heard in silence.
—We could spend hours and hours asking questions about the expenditure of $1,000-I can certainly give specific evidence on this-that required the expenditure of about $50,000 to provide the answer.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of Senator Tambling's totally unwarranted criticism of the amount of time it has taken to answer questions, I will provide this little snippet of information: the Department of Transport and Communications received 428 questions on notice in respect of this Committee. Senator Short's questions alone required a total of 1,734 responses from 35 subprograms of the Department. This increased the number of actual questions asked to 2,111.

TALK.START.PARA: —Terrible.
—No-one is complaining about it, Senator; these are the facts.
—It sounds as if you are.

—I am not complaining about it but I just point out that I think it is a little bit unreasonable to be laying scorn and derision on the failure of a department to answer questions when this is the real story of why delays occur. Of the 2,111 questions asked, most of the answers to which I know will never see the light of day despite the extraordinary amount of money they cost to collect, only 12 questions-that is 0.5 per cent of the questions asked-remain outstanding at this time. Frankly, I think that is an outstanding response from the department.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine placed 40 questions on notice relating to the 0055 and Discovery services. Senator Harradine knows that those questions were not received by the Department until 8 October, that is, some 18 days after the Senate Estimates Committee meeting. In fact, Senator Harradine lodged them, I think, only 14 days after. That is a matter of no moment because he is not complaining.

In response to what Senator Tambling has said, I do not think the fact that only 12 questions out of 2,111 are still outstanding at this point in time would lead to too much criticism. This outrageous motion would further inconvenience officers who have been here for a significant amount of time to provide us with a service. There is an obligation to exercise some kind of management in this chamber. The attitude that is being adopted, to just lay back and let officers be at our beck and call, cannot be sustained.

There are three outstanding questions on which we are asked to divide in order to postpone this entire procedure. This would further back up the other officers waiting outside to be called. The three questions are: who was consulted by Telecom in regard to the 0055 service; what community groups were consulted; and did a constituent in Tasmania make a specific and detailed complaint to Senator Newman?

I have given an undertaking that those questions will be answered. I have to say, with respect, that I do not think any of them are very earth shattering. They will be answered by the end of today. This is not a sustainable reason, with respect, for this Committee to be further inconvenienced and, I might add, for a very large number of departmental officers also to be inconvenienced because of our mismanagement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins has indicated on a couple of occasions that these issues are specious ones. I do not know whether he is talking about the issue of the community's complaints about Discovery and 0055. If he is referring to that, they are certainly not specious or unimportant questions; they are very important questions.

SPEECH.PARA: In so far as Discovery is concerned, if the Discovery management is allowed to get away with what it is doing now, the precedent is being set for porn pay television. Let us not make any mistake about that at all; that is what the situation is. With Discovery, Telecom, without the approval of its board of management, has established the publishing model for the provision of computer porn into Australian homes via their computer network screens. What is the difference between that and television porn? That and the inherent nature of the Discovery service are the reasons that I have been raising these questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, on a point of order: that is not the question. The question currently before the Chair is whether the Committee's consideration of the Department of Transport and Communications should be postponed until these questions are answered. I wonder whether Senator Harradine could speak to the motion.
—On the point of order, Mr Chairman, I am speaking in response to what Senator Collins said. Senator Collins said that these issues are specious. I am trying to indicate to the chamber--

—Senator Harradine, you were speaking to the point of order at that stage. I remind you that the motion before the Chair is that further consideration of the Department of Transport and Communications be adjourned until after the consideration of the Attorney-General's Department. It would be helpful if you would put your comments in that context.

—I will do it briefly. They are important questions. I hope that Senator Collins waits to hear what I am going to say about the motion-shortly. As far as 0055 is concerned, here is a situation where Telecom is about to expand its sexploit business. How is it going to do that? It is going to do that by developing a system where there will be a particular code within 0055, and the material content of that service will be far more degrading to women than the material about which there are current complaints. I believe that the matters dealt with by way of questions that I have raised, that Senator Newman has raised, that Senator Walters has raised, and that Senator Knowles has raised-and other people as well-are very important issues indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins correctly indicated that the most appropriate place for these questions to have been dealt with would have been during the Estimates Committee hearings. He seems to indicate that somehow I was at fault for not giving sufficient notice to enable officers of Telecom to be there. Mr Fish, the Telecom officer who had written the letters to those people who were complaining, was in fact there and he was not prepared to answer the questions. He is the Manager, External Relations, Corporate Secretariat. He was there. He is the one that has been answering the questions asked by the public. Was I to expect that somebody else should be responsible for answering the questions? He is the one that has been answering the questions about Discovery service. He is the one that has been answering the public's questions about 0055. He was present on that occasion. Why was he not able to answer the questions? Since Senator Collins has raised it-I did not raise it; I was prepared to let it go- why was Mr Fish not able to answer our questions, since he has been the one that has been answering questions asked by the public by way of letter?

Telecom is the only public authority that I know of that has not, prior to Estimates, met with its officers and said, `What are the things that we are likely to be asked about?'. What were the things that they were likely to be asked about? There had been complaints about these services. Surely, Telecom should have been aware that questions would be asked. So I do not accept that. I was not going to raise it; Senator Collins raised it. I do not complain about the length of time that it has taken for answers to come from Telecom officials. I must say that Senator Collins, Telecom and the Department of Transport and Communications have been meticulous in the way that they have gone about dealing with questions to the Estimates committees. I also acknowledge the work that has been done by the Estimates committees to get those questions in-so far as they have been answered.

The reason for all of this debate in the Committee of the Whole is that the answers raised a series of other questions, which Senator Collins now has taken on notice. Senator Newman's questions are not the only ones that have been taken on notice. There are far more questions that have been taken on notice-from me, for one. I am prepared to accept Senator Collins's undertaking to provide answers in the time frame that he has mentioned; that is, by this afternoon. Would Senator Collins give an indication of the time frame that it might take for the answers to come back from the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) and from the Board of Telecom in respect of the questions that have been raised by me and some others in this debate?

As far as the individual questions are concerned, it is not for me to say whether I should support Senator Newman. Every honourable senator is entitled to make his or her request for responses. If Senator Collins has indicated that by this afternoon he will be providing the direct answers to those questions, maybe we should take that on faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —To give a precise response to Senator Harradine, I did acknowledge when I spoke, and I hope Senator Harradine heard me, that he has made no complaint about the diligence with which departmental officers have applied themselves to providing answers to honourable senators on this Committee. I notice that he is nodding assent to that and does appreciate it. I was responding directly to what I thought was a bit of off-the-top-of-the-head filibustering that Senator Tambling was probably asked to do when he criticised the length of time that had been taken to provide answers.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the answer I gave provided pretty significant ammunition against supporting this motion. Of the 2,100 questions asked on notice, only 12 have not yet been answered: that is 0.05 per cent of the questions. I think that is a pretty fair effort from the Department. I gave an undertaking to Senator Newman last night. The questions are not exactly earth- shaking. I did not at any stage suggest who I treated them trivially. I have never treated questions put to the Committee trivially. As I said before, there are plenty of honourable senators in this chamber who can attest to the diligence that I apply in getting answers to questions that are asked. I have always provided them.

I did have another obligation this morning, in company with Senator Kernot-who I was very pleased came in her capacity as the Australian Democrats spokesperson on aviation-to look at some rather important equipment to do with air management at Sydney Airport. I ensured that the questions were noted. I gave an undertaking to the Committee last night, and these questions again relate to the people and the organisations that Telecom consulted about 0055 and a particular matter raised by a constituent in Tasmania. I repeat that I have given an undertaking to provide the Committee with those answers before the end of today. I will discharge that obligation. That is no reason to keep the Committee waiting--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are.
—In response to Senator Newman's motion, with respect.
—I took five minutes. You have taken nearly half an hour.
—Senator Newman, I have warned you several times this morning. I now warn you this afternoon.

—I would like one senator to deny this: we are all collectively responsible for how we manage the Estimates committee process. There is some obligation jointly on us all to avoid the scandals of the past, and they were scandalous. I have to give credit and say that I think the Senate has made considerable progress, since we have moved to the new Parliament House, by a bit of tighter management and a bit of courtesy being extended by those on both sides, with people letting other people know what they want to know about, in avoiding rafts of public servants having to waste their precious time-which we pay for-and ours on this exercise. We are all collectively responsible for that. I will discharge the undertaking I gave to Senator Newman this afternoon. I think that is no reason to delay this process any further.

—I regret to have to intervene. I was going to intervene earlier when Senator Collins was extremely rude about the role of the Opposition in Estimates. Our role is to examine what goes on, to question the Estimates, and that is what has occurred. The Minister's behaviour during this debate and, in particular, in the last three-quarters of an hour, is symptomatic of the time-wasting that has gone on. But what has caused me to rise now is that in his last speech the Minister accused the Opposition of filibustering. This has not occurred. The Minister used that word, and he knows that he did.
—Senator Tambling, I said.

—That is not the case. Senator Tambling raised a legitimate point, as have other honourable senators. The Minister is the one who speaks for nearly 15 minutes every time. He is the one who has not been answering questions in the way in which they ought to have been answered in this debate. The Minister is responsible for the time that has been taken on this particular section of Estimates Committee E. The sensible thing for the Minister to have done-knowing that he can get answers in a short time, as he has assured us-would have been to have adjourned the matter three-quarters of an hour ago so that the chamber could get on with its business; it could finish this matter later. I cannot understand why it is that the Minister feels it needs to be dealt with in this fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time is nearly 12.10 p.m. The Minister promised that he would get the information this afternoon. As Senator Newman said, it required nothing more than a telephone call. The Minister talked about getting officers out of bed last night; there was no need for officers to be got out of bed last night. If his Department or his office had rung through for the information at nine o'clock this morning, I believe it would be nothing but gross incompetence if it could not have been made available within at least two hours. However, it is now three hours since the working time commenced for the Department. If the Minister had really tried-I am sick to death of hearing him say how good he is-I believe the officers could have responded in the period. It is now after midday, and if the Minister had any intention of keeping his promise then we would have the information.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister is ignoring the fact that if the answers to Senator Newman's questions are given after this section of the Appropriation Bill has been finalised, Senator Newman will not have the ability to ask any additional questions on the answers given. As the Minister knows, this is the only time honourable senators have to ask a series of questions on answers given. The Minister understands that. I guess that is the reason why he will not give us the answers during this consideration of the appropriations.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of those other questions that remain unanswered, can the Minister indicate whether they will go to the responsible Minister and to the board of directors for response?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I will give that undertaking. I assure Senator Harradine that I will personally ensure that those questions are answered expeditiously.
—Senator Newman has moved that further consideration of the Department of Transport and Communications be adjourned until after consideration of the Attorney-General's Department.

—Are there any further matters in the Department of Transport and Communications for further examination? If not, the Committee will proceed to consideration of matters for examination under the Attorney-General's Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise briefly a matter I raised at the Estimates Committee and it is referred to in the report under subprogram 1.2, the Solicitor-General. I raised it on 13 September at the Estimates Committee hearing. I raised it again in the Senate when I spoke on the Appropriation Bills. The substance of the matter is the fact that the Attorney-General's Department or the Solicitor-General does not charge departments of state for legal work that is done for them. From one point of view we might say that it is money merely changing hands. What disturbs me is that there seems to be no accurate record of the taxpayers' money which is spent in the Government pursuing legal action of any kind. It puts any other person at an enormous disadvantage when the Commonwealth has unlimited resources to pursue legal action.

SPEECH.PARA: What I was speaking about in particular was the question of Mr Hans Milton's action in the Small Claims Court in Canberra, which he won with a judgment of $929.49, and which the Department of Finance or the Commissioner for Superannuation wished to appeal. Any other citizen in this country would have thought pretty deeply about whether or not to spend the legal costs to pursue the action further. But, with no responsibility required whatever for somebody pursuing such an action, the Department proceeded to instruct the Solicitor-General to lodge an appeal.

During the same period, the Department of Finance issued a press release, reported in the Canberra Times, indicating that in future this would not be the case. But as far as I know to this moment, notwithstanding that decision, the claim against Mr Milton is still being appealed, despite the enormous costs to the taxpayers. I received some answers as a result of the questions I raised at the Estimates Committee. They indicated that, yes, Mr Milton did institute proceedings and, yes, he obtained a judgment in the Small Claims Court; that no costs are awarded in the small claims court apart from disbursements, and indicated the total number of disbursements. The interesting piece of information was that the work done by the Commonwealth in this small matter was by a principal legal officer, amounting to some 40 hours, and by a senior legal officer, amounting to some eight hours. The costs thus incurred amounted to about $1,480.

Quite frankly, I challenge that figure. There is not a legal firm in the country that would be charging out at that rate if it is paying solicitors the amount of money that one pays principal legal officers and senior legal officers for their work. A principal legal officer is in the salary range of just over $50,000 to $53,000. A senior legal officer is in the range of over $42,000 to $45,000. If one takes the 40 hours on a 38-hour-week basis, it is absurd to try to tell the chamber that the legal costs that the Commonwealth has incurred pursuing this are as little as $1,480. We all know that is nonsense because it does not, in addition to the salary, take into account all the other costs that a legal firm has to bear in order to operate and to function as the solicitor for a department of state in this matter. What I would like to know from the Minister is whether it is a fact that the Commonwealth is still, with scant regard for the taxpayers of this country, pursuing this matter on appeal, or has the appeal been withdrawn?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to find out from the officers whether the appeal is being furthered. I will try to find that answer as soon as I can. In relation to the real point that I think Senator Reid is making-and she makes the point by illustration using this case-I believe that there will be a submission going to the Government shortly in relation to user pays principles applying between the Australian Government Solicitor and departments of the Commonwealth. I believe that this will put a very real constraint on departments so that they have to consider very carefully whether in fact they should pursue a particular matter through the various stages, such as has occurred in the case of Mr Hans Milton. It will also require the Australian Government Solicitor to note more carefully the time spent, and therefore the cost involved, in providing a particular legal service to the client department or Commonwealth agency.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Reid's point is well made in general. As to her specific question, I will get that information as soon as I can. I believe that if the question of cost recovery and user pays is adopted, as is envisaged by the Australian Government Solicitor, then many of the concerns that Senator Reid expressed will be dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of Estimates Committee E specifically recommends that further matters in relation to the administration of the Family Court be discussed. There are a few matters that I know Senator Tate is aware of that I want to raise with him very briefly. I can do it in one speech, or not much more than that.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Tate is no doubt aware, Family Court jurisdiction is a very emotive and sensitive jurisdiction for the litigants involved. Everything the Commonwealth can do to facilitate the proper administration of those family law courts I assume it would want to do. I know the situation is, as in all matters, that there can only be one winner and the loser is often dissatisfied. We all know that the unsuccessful litigant in a family matter appears to be frequently more dissatisfied than unsuccessful litigants in other areas. That is because of the sensitivity and the emotional nature of this jurisdiction.

Generally, one is not arguing about some small claim or a piece of tin that is fashioned into a car that has been smashed up; one is arguing about the dissolution of one's family, the custody of children, dissolution of property and the ending of what presumably was at one stage a successful marriage.

The situation is, as far as I am informed, that in South Australia the administration of the court is being hampered by its inadequate housing. I want to put to Senator Tate a number of matters that have been put to me and ask him to respond on behalf of the Government as to why it is that the Family Court in South Australia has to stay in its currently inadequate housing. As I understand it, there have been numerous incidents over the life of the court and this would not be, I am sure, particular to South Australia.

Recently, there have been a number of incidents. As I understand it, late last year Justice McGovern was proceeding towards a stairwell and was chased by a man with a bag of syringes. As I further understand it, the man previously identified himself as being a diabetic. That is why he had the syringes; let me say that from the very beginning. I do not want to create the impression that some more hazardous position eventuated than otherwise was the case. Nonetheless, it does highlight what could happen.

As I understand it, Justice McGovern made it to the stairwell quite safely in the company of an officer who was accompanying him back to his chambers; so everybody can breathe a sigh of relief and say that nothing happened. But, of course, there is possibly a disaster waiting to happen and there is a situation in which members of the judiciary, the staff who are meant to look after them and, for that matter, the litigants and the members of the legal profession advising the litigants do not feel safe.

I have tried to commence by highlighting that I understand that this jurisdiction by its very nature is a very sensitive and emotional one. But that is the very reason that it has to be adequately housed. It could have been someone with a syringe tainted with acquired immune deficiency syndrome contaminated blood who was chasing Justice McGovern. As I say, it was not, but it highlights the situation where it could be the case.

There was another incident where a man entered from the back of one of the courts in Adelaide. His demeanour was such that the presiding judge had to adjourn the hearing and disappear into the anteroom. Of course, what the judge discovered when he or she got there was that there was nowhere to go. Had the man who had entered the courtroom yelling and screaming wanted to do more damage than he did, he could have. Had the man had a gun he could have done even more damage. In fact, I am informed that the person, on leaving the courtroom, muttered to somebody that he could have shot the judge if he wanted to.

One is left wondering how the judge must have felt when, having adjourned proceedings and moved off into an anteroom at the side of the court, he discovered the anteroom had no exit. So a judge could be in a position where a lunatic came into a court-not necessarily an unsuccessful litigant, but just a lunatic-armed in some way and the judge had nowhere to go.

As I understand it, in South Australia the members of the judiciary have to use a public stairwell off which public toilets run. This is not to say that the judiciary is composed of a level of people who need not mix with the public, but we are aware of the security that should be afforded to judges in this jurisdiction because of its sensitive and emotional character. It appears that that kind of security is not being offered to them in Adelaide.

In particular, I understand that the profession is very concerned about the inadequacy of the waiting areas on level six. There are two courtrooms on that floor. The three waiting areas are not properly closed off; they are semi-open waiting areas. Litigants need to hang around here and discuss their matters, with the opposing parties not necessarily out of earshot. It is in this area that counsel need to take advice and there is only one small counsel room where they can go to prepare draft orders and matters of that sort. So frequently that sort of work is going on in this public area as well. It is through this public area that the people presiding in those two courts have to proceed to get back to their chambers and/or offices. As I understand it, it is in this area in July that one litigant chose to stab his wife not long after the judge had left that area. We all know what stabbing means. It means taking a sharp instrument and thrusting it into someone else's body.

We can say we are thankful that the judge had left the area, but we should not be any less displeased that the litigant managed to stab his wife. When members of the judiciary, or perhaps members of the legal profession, have nowhere to go in this melting pot of a jurisdiction and are all put together on the sixth floor, we have to expect trouble. It is a disaster waiting to happen. The litigant could have come out and stabbed the judge.

We have a very worrying situation in Adelaide. I am informed that the staff of the Family Court in Adelaide is operating under considerable stress. People do not like to work unless there are glass shields between them and members of the public. It is sad that we have come to this, but if people are working in the administration of the Family Court and someone takes a swipe at them over the counter, as happened recently in Adelaide, then we can understand people saying that they do not want to work there unless there is some protection.

This is a very serious matter. It is not just a question of protecting the judiciary. It is not just a question of providing a suitable forum for litigants in this jurisdiction to have their matters heard. There are costs for the Commonwealth. Heaven knows what the costs for Comcare would be of stress related claims in this area or what the costs for the Commonwealth would be were someone-an unsuccessful litigant or a lunatic-to stab successfully a member of staff of the Commonwealth Public Service.

If these sorts of things happened in a Supreme Court there would be an uproar, with headlines in the Australian: `Man stabbed in Supreme Court'. But because it is the Family Court-dare I suggest partly because it is the Family Court in Adelaide and therefore not so politically important as Family courts in the eastern States, where there are more seats to be won-nothing is done. If it happened in the Supreme Court the headlines would read, `Judge chased by man with bag of syringes in hand' and `Person stabbed in Supreme Court just after a judge has passed through the area'. It would be regarded as totally unacceptable.

I put to the Minister that this is totally unacceptable for the Family Court. It is just as unacceptable, if not more so, as it would be if it happened in another court. The profession in South Australia has been led to believe for some time that this matter would be attended to, that the Family Court would be rehoused in more suitable buildings where members of the profession could feel safe, where members of the Public Service could feel safe, where the judiciary could feel safe and where litigants could feel safe.

In conclusion, I put to the Minister that we have a situation in Adelaide where the Family Court is clearly inadequately housed. We have a situation where judges can be chased up stairwells by men with bags of syringes. We have a situation where judges and the profession and the litigants have to mix together in a melting pot of an area where not so recently a litigant stabbed his wife. We have had people taking swipes at counter staff. It is a disaster waiting to happen. I would like to know what the Commonwealth is going to do about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone has raised some points about the physical security of those who are on the bench performing their functions as officers of the court in various guises and those who seek the assistance of the court. All those people deserve the greatest possible personal security in an environment which, as she quite rightly said, is charged with emotion. We know this only too well from the tragic and very unAustralian series of bombings of registries in New South Wales Family Court buildings and attacks on judges, leading to the fatal bombing of Mr Justice Watson's home in Sydney which tragically killed his wife.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that people can become violent and, having harboured their grievance, break out in a form which takes as a focus for that violence an officer of the court or perhaps the judge who was concerned in their particular case. For that reason, the Australian Federal Police, and in a narrower role the Australian Protective Service, have a particular function in relation to the security of Family Courts. I will certainly undertake to check with the Australian Federal Police on the incidents which have given rise to Senator Vanstone's concern to try to ensure that, even within the current environment, steps are taken to provide the necessary personal security which she quite rightly says must be a feature of any court, not only in consideration of the personal safety of those involved but also if the system of justice and people's access and confidence to it is to remain as it ought to be.

Senator Vanstone uses those incidents as part of an argument to try to get the housing of the Family Court in Adelaide somewhat higher up the list than it is now in regard to other Family Court projects around Australia. By the way, these projects are normally part of a larger Federal Court complex project, so there are other courts involved. Their requirements also have to be taken into account in the planning and priority of the provision of court buildings for judges exercising Federal jurisdiction of various kinds, the Family Court being only one.

Senator Vanstone has brought to the attention of the Senate particular characteristics of the building which in my estimation, just listening to her, would need immediate modification anyway in order to secure the safety of exit of the judge in the particular instance she outlined. I think that ought to be looked at quite apart from the question of the impact of her description of the situation on the ranking of the Adelaide Federal Court project alongside other projects around Australia. We will look at the immediate situation and take it into account in any reassessment of the ranking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs for the manner in which he has responded. I used examples-they are just a few from the last 18 months-of what I think are very serious risks undertaken, as the Minister rightly pointed out, by all the people participating in this jurisdiction, not just the judiciary but the legal profession, the litigants and the staff of the courts as well. Their safety is important.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate what the Minister said about the Family Court being a part of the larger Federal system and therefore in terms of rehousing is considered along with other courts. But it is not like other courts in the sense of its sensitive and emotional nature and needs to be given some higher priority because of that. Since the Minister has undertaken to look at the existing housing in respect of the exit of judges particularly, is that an undertaking to look at the existing housing in terms of the safety of everybody involved? For example, as he probably well knows, the Family Court is currently housed in a public building. It is not separately partitioned off so it is probably difficult to maintain decent security over who comes in and out and whether they bring weapons with them or whatever. The safety of counter staff is important and, for that matter, the safety of the legal profession and the litigants. Is the adequacy of the waiting rooms off the counselling area and off level 6 something the Minister is prepared to look at as well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that of course I am concerned with more than the physical safety of the judges. In so far as there are other persons using the court premises for their various purposes and/or employment then their safety and security also ought to be taken into account, and that will be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reid asked a question concerning the Hans Milton case. I have had a reply from the litigation division that the case is still under appeal. There is no change in that situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister able to tell us why that is so in view of the fact that the Department of Finance has changed its policy on this matter and agreed that it should pay interest? I would say that the Minister's solicitors should ask for instructions as to why the appeal should proceed and perhaps give advice to the fact that it should not. The Department was ordered to pay interest to Mr Milton on his superannuation because it was late-I think by 13 days-in paying him his money. As I said before, I have no doubt that, if any private company did that and did not pay the penalty, all of us would feel it was a grave error of judgment not to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department has now determined that in future, where it is late and it is its own fault, it will pay interest. Why is it now pursuing this matter? The cost is not to anyone other than the taxpayers of Australia, who are already sorely pressed to keep up with their own finances. I would like the Minister to ask his solicitors to seek further instructions from the Department as to why it wishes to proceed with the matter in the circumstances.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give an undertaking on behalf of the client, which is the Department of Finance, but I will certainly bring your remarks in the Hansard to the attention of the Department with a view to its deciding on an appropriate course of action. I think the matters Senator Reid has raised are matters that the Department ought to take into account and give relevant weight to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of Estimates Committee E says at point 9:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee considered that a Parliamentary Committee should be able to obtain an opinion from the Attorney or his Department on a confidential basis.
It then goes on to say:
However, the Committee recommends that this matter should be further examined by the Senate in the light of the answer on it provided by the Attorney-General's Department . . .

I would like briefly to ask the Minister a question in relation to that answer. As I understand it, the answer says that if, for example, a parliamentary committee asks the Attorney-General a question that relates to an area or an Act administered by the Attorney-General's Department then the Attorney would feel free to distribute that opinion as he saw fit within the Attorney-General's Department. Perhaps the Minister can clarify first whether I have understood what has been said in that respect. I think it is the last part of the answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could have this checked with the officers but, as I understand it, what is being said is that where the Act is administered by the Attorney-General's Department copies are provided to other departments, statutory authorities and other persons if the Attorney-General's Department considers it necessary or appropriate that they should receive copies of the advice. That appears to be a correct reading.

—Do I understand then that the Attorney-General is saying to a parliamentary committee that, if people want advice on a confidential basis and they happen to be in the position of wanting advice that might relate to a matter being administered by the Attorney-General's Department, then they cannot have confidential advice? I can foresee a number of situations-the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority would be one but there would be plenty of others-where one might want advice on a confidential basis and where the proceedings of that committee may be prejudiced if the advice sought was bandied around. Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General saying that in those situations parliamentary committees have to seek outside advice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that in part 3 of the answer already provided to Senate Estimates Committee E it is made clear what the future practice of the Attorney-General will be. I think it has come about as a result of the sorts of matters which Senator Vanstone raised at the Estimates Committee hearing. The report makes the position clear when it says:

SPEECH.PARA: In all future cases where the Attorney-General . . . is asked to advise a parliamentary committee on the interpretation of an Act-
including, I take it, Acts administered by the Attorney-General's Department-
- copies of the advice will be made available in accordance with the practices stated above-
which I have just outlined-
unless the committee or the committee's secretary has informed the Attorney-General's Department that the committee objects; and

- if there is any such objection, the Attorney-General will consider whether, having regard to potential conflicts of interest and other matters, the advice should nevertheless be given to the committee.

In other words, if the committee seeks to receive advice which is absolutely secure, confidential and exclusive to it, and it makes that clear to the Attorney when it seeks some assistance in a matter of statutory interpretation or legal advice, then the Attorney will take that into account because of all those sorts of factors as to the proper administration of his Department and its agencies and the statutes under which they conduct their business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. I appreciate the Attorney-General's outline of the future practice in that respect but, as I see it, that puts the parliamentary committee in the position that it has to disclose its hand to the Minister first off. The Attorney has to consider what advice the committee wants and weigh that up against the potential conflicts of interest and other matters. The Attorney cannot do that unless the committee discloses its hand and says what advice it wants. Irrespective of whether the committee then proceeds to get advice from the Attorney or goes to some private counsel, having disclosed its hand to the Attorney, it may well have disclosed its hand to all and sundry in the Attorney-General's Department. Is the request to be kept confidential? Could the committee know that at least?

SPEECH.PARA: Just suppose the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority wanted some confidential advice on the conduct of a member of the Authority or a member of the staff of the Authority. The committee certainly would not distrust the advice that it would get from the Attorney but it may not want to disclose to the Authority, any member of the Authority, or to a staff member of the Authority that it was seeking such advice. According to this outline, the Committee obviously has to tell the Attorney what it wants advice on so that he can weigh up these matters. What if he weighs it up so that the balance is not in favour of giving the Committee advice? Does the Attorney then feel free to go back and relate the seeking of advice and the nature of the advice sought to the other parties involved because of his responsibility to them? I do not mean he would do that to try to dip the Committee into it but because of the responsibility he holds.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is, I suppose, a little difficult to forecast every situation, but in the situation put by Senator Vanstone-the example she gave of seeking advice about the proper interpretation of the National Crime Authority Act, for example-then quite clearly the Attorney-General would need to seek some advice from his own Department as to the possible conflicts of interest and difficulties if he did not make that advice more generally available to affected agencies. He would take departmental advice. I am sure it would be at the very highest level and would not involve, for example, in that case, the National Crime Authority. It would be the Attorney-General taking the advice of his most senior departmental officers, no doubt in conjunction with his own political judgment. They would be the sorts of matters he would take into account. I cannot say that he would deal with it personally without taking some advice from his senior departmental officers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m. I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: — My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister seen reports that the President of the Janata Dal, Mr Bommai, has claimed that Pakistan now has nine nuclear bombs? Has not the Indian Government maintained throughout that the Mirage aircraft sold by Australia to Pakistan represent a significant addition to the military capability of that country and are, therefore, a destabilising element in the region? Does not the unexpected haste with which the Pakistan Government has effected delivery suggest that the value of the aircraft, in terms of military capability, is much greater than the Government has been prepared to admit and is therefore a legitimate cause of concern to the Indian Government? Bearing in mind the recent suspension of United States arms sales to Pakistan because of concerns about its nuclear capacity, does the Minister continue to maintain that India's concerns about regional stability are unfounded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the particular statement from the Janata Dal representative to which Senator Durack has referred.
—It was on the news reports this morning.

—That may be so, but I did not hear it. But that does not alter in any way the assessment that the Government continues to make that such anxiety as India has expressed about the Mirage aircraft sale is not linked in any specific way to concern about the impact of the Mirages on the military balance of power on the subcontinent. It has simply not ever been put in those terms in any of the innumerable representations that have been made to me.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been acknowledged throughout that what this is all about is essentially a psychological matter-just the inappropriateness, it was argued, of being seen to be acting in any way to support Pakistan at a time of potential conflict between the two countries. Really, there is not much more I can say on that subject.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MIDDLE EAST: USE OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. With regard to the Middle East, I ask the Minister: does the Government support the use of nuclear weapons in any context whatsoever?
—I am a little surprised by the question because I had thought that I had made the Government's position on this perfectly clear yesterday. In case I did not, the short answer is no.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I particularly refer to two recent reports of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) national secretariat announcing the donation of $5,000 and the intention to donate a further $10,000 to the Opposition Fiji Labor Party-National Federation Party coalition to help establish a new opposition coalition office. Was the Minister consulted before the decision was made, does the Minister support this decision and how does the Minister assess the donations will affect Australia's already strained relationship with Fiji?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a member of that secretariat, and I was present when that decision was made. I supported the decision. To support a particular party organisation in any country is, of course, not the decision that the Government itself would make, but it is a perfectly appropriate, familiar, usual and indeed almost routine kind of decision for the ALP to make, and this case was no exception in that respect.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not imagine that decision will be greeted with ecstasy within Fiji, but equally I would expect a clear distinction to be made between party-to-party contacts of that kind, support of that kind and government support of a financial kind for an internal party which, in this particular context, would not be appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. Has the Minister been informed about confusion amongst patients who are attending State hospitals and receiving pharmaceuticals? If so, does this confusion centre on whether pharmaceuticals they receive at the hospital count towards the safety net in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS)? Is the Commonwealth Government making any efforts to encourage State governments to recognise the PBS safety net for the hospital patient prescriptions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pharmaceutical benefits scheme is funded by the Federal Government and is not in any way related to outpatient pharmacy services operated by State governments through public hospitals. The Federal Government has fully compensated pensioners for the new PBS charge by providing a pension increase equal in value to the amount pensioners need to pay to reach the safety net. State and Territory governments have not provided any compensation to pensioners for the cost of drugs needed to reach the safety net set for public hospital outpatients.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation is not new. The Commonwealth's PBS safety net arrangements have existed since November 1986 and hospital prescription supplies have never counted towards the 25 prescription safety net threshold. This Government does, however, recognise that people have been confused by the different schemes, particularly in Queensland where such charges were recently introduced for the first time. It would be preferable for there to be an arrangement of some sort between the two levels of government on this issue, as with other broader issues which we are all aware have been agreed as worthy of further exploration of future Special Premiers Conferences.

A working party reporting to the Australian Health Minister's Advisory Council is currently looking at a range of Commonwealth-State issues and the provision and funding of pharmaceutical services. The Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Brian Howe, has directed the working party to consider this issue of the respective State public hospital and Commonwealth PBS safety nets as a matter of priority.

Mr Staples tells me that he has been advised that the Victorian Government has decided to recognise the Commonwealth safety net card in Victoria's public hospital pharmacies. If people produce a safety net card which shows they have already spent $130 on PBS items in Victorian community pharmacies, they will be entitled to receive drugs free of charge from Victorian public hospitals for the rest of that year. I hope the other States follow Victoria's commendable example so that people are not disadvantaged by differing safety net arrangements.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REGIONAL PASSENGER RAIL SERVICES: SOUTH AUSTRALIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. I draw the Minister's attention to an answer that he gave in the Senate to a question I asked on 14 May 1990 regarding the closure of regional passenger rail services in South Australia. He said at that time:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government will not make a decision in respect of those regional services until it has fully consulted with the South Australian Government.

I am not sure if the Minister is aware, but on Thursday, 15 November 1990, on Tony McCarthy's program on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio, Frank Blevins, a South Australian Minister, assured listeners that there was no consultation, but that he had simply been notified at 1 p.m. on that day of the closures. Were there full consultations; secondly, when and where did these full consultations with the South Australian Government take place; thirdly, what issues were on the agenda; and, fourthly, who was present?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the statements that were made by the Hon. Frank Blevins, the South Australian Minister for Transport, in respect of this matter and have pursued this with the Minister's office. The Minister for Land Transport has advised me, in response to the honourable senator's question, that the Minister has in fact raised this matter with Mr Blevins on at least two occasions; that the discussions were informal; that there was in fact no fixed agenda for the meeting; that a range of other transport issues were discussed as well; and that no record was kept of those present.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. It concerns the wage-tax trade-off agreed last week by the Government with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Is it a fact that the trade-off will bring about a welcome increase in take home pay for Australian workers? Can the Minister advise the Senate about the impact of the proposed tax cut, in particular on the wages of ordinary workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, I said in answer to a question in the Senate that effectively the wage-tax trade-off amounted to a 12 months wage pause in Australia; that the inflation rate target set out in the Budget of 6 per cent will be achieved, if not in fact undershot; that Australia's inflation rate is going down while that of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development is trending upwards; that our aggregate wage outcome for the year set at 7 per cent in the Budget is now targeted for 6.25 per cent; that the trade-off proves the flexibility of the accord and its value; and that the measure has been universally acclaimed.

ANSWER.PARA: What Senator Schacht has done is focus on yet another feature of the wage-tax trade-off. That feature is that low and middle income earners, by virtue of the mathematical calculation of the tax scales, will be better off under the trade-off than they would have been had they taken the increase as a wage increase and not as a tax reduction. The Government welcomes that more equitable dimension in the trade-off terms.

Let me give to the Senate three very quick examples of what I mean. Taking wages at the levels of $21,000, $25,000 and $30,000 a year, I can demonstrate why middle and low income earners are better off under the trade-off by using wage equivalent terms. At $21,000 a year, the wage value of the 0.7 per cent September quarter increase would be $2.80. Under the trade-off the wage equivalent would be $4.85; that is, $2 a week more. Then adding the wage equivalent of the tax cuts already foreshadowed in the Budget, plus these new tax cuts, the wage equivalent for that level of income would be $15.20 a week.

At the $25,000 mark, the wage increase would be worth $3.40 under the 0.7 per cent adjustment. Under the tax cut it is worth $4.85, an extra $1.45 per week. The total wage value of both tax cuts is $16.45 at that wage level. Under the $30,000 mark, the wage increase at the 0.7 per cent indexation rate would be $4.20. The wage equivalent under the tax cut is $4.85; that is, an extra 65c a week. The joint tax cuts are worth $18.05 in equivalent wage terms at that level.

What has to be said about this is that no employer under this trade-off will be paying the equivalent wage level. All employers under this trade-off will save those costs to their business and thus have effectively a wage holiday for 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to a number of questions raised in the last week of sittings regarding redundancy payments to Comcar drivers. I ask the Minister: what are the redundancy payments offered? Must the offer of redundancy be made to all Comcar drivers? Is there a minimum payment irrespective of years of service? If so, what is that figure? Why are redundancy payments being offered in areas where clearly there is no redundancy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer asked five specific questions about which I will get full and comprehensive details for him. I should ask the Senate to note that the number of drivers who are expected to leave by Christmas is 150.
—I didn't ask that.

—Senator Parer did not ask it, but in his last question he asked about areas where drivers are taking redundancy payments and where there is no need for redundancy. The overall figure of drivers expected to leave by Christmas is 150, and the new ones to come in by then will be 43.

ANSWER.PARA: In answering the question in a general sense at this stage, I ask the Senate to note that what is going on in Comcar is a major review of the organisation, its functions and its direction. The redundancy packages that have been organised in respect of Comcar are very much part of that fundamental change of direction of the organisation. Having said that, I reiterate that I will provide full answers to the four specific questions that Senator Parer has asked, possibly by the end of Question Time but certainly later this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training been drawn to reports that the Western Australian Government has made available a grant of 150 hectares of crown land at a market value of $7m to the proposed Notre Dame University and that the university will be free to sell the endowed land or develop it for any income purposes it desires within general planning guidelines? Does the Federal Government have a view on the exclusive provision of such grants of land to a private, sectarian university? Does the grant of land set a precedent in the provision of government support for a private tertiary institution? What Federal Government assistance will be provided for Notre Dame? How does this compare with the Government's attitude to other private institutions such as the Bond University?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indeed seen reports indicating that the Western Australian Government will grant 150 hectares of crown land to the University of Notre Dame Australia. The first point I make is that we should appreciate that decisions about the establishment of private institutions are very much matters for State government. The Commonwealth does not have legislative power in this area. Nevertheless, we have been asked for an expression of attitude and the Federal Government is surprised at this extraordinarily generous public subvention to a private institution.

ANSWER.PARA: Our position, in line with Australian Labor Party policy, is that private institutions would not be granted direct or indirect financial assistance for development purposes. Any decision such as the one that Senator Beahan asked about by the Western Australian Government to support the University of Notre Dame Australia would no doubt reflect the priorities of that Government and the benefits that it perceives as flowing to Western Australia from the proposed development. However, the move is somewhat curious considering the often called for need by public institutions in Western Australia-such as the University of Western Australia , the Murdoch University, the Curtin University of Technology and the Western Australian College of Advanced Education-for more resources. Indeed, the decision to grant land to a private institution such as Notre Dame is even more odd when the public institutions in Western Australia are not granted the same privilege.

Our main concern in this field is for public institutions and for the public system of higher education. If the Western Australian Government held similar concern for the public system it would have considered a more even-handed approach to this matter or, indeed, it would revisit this decision altogether.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services and follows a general question from Senator Parer. I note the Minister's answer that organisational changes in Comcar are a reason for redundancy payments, but I will ask a more simple question. The Minister will be aware that there are 12 Comcar drivers in Tasmania, all of whom were offered redundancy payments. I ask the Minister: is it a fact that one driver accepted the redundancy and that that driver is to be replaced? If that is the case, why were the Tasmanian Comcar drivers offered redundancy? What was the reasoning behind this blatant waste of taxpayers' money?

—I am not aware of the specific circumstance. What I have said before about this issue, which obviously needs to be repeated, is that what is happening in the reorganisation, the restructuring and the reorientation of Comcar is nothing different from what has happened and what is happening to large public and private operations in the same field. I have probably said enough about this question, and that concludes my answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of the concerns that have been expressed by Amnesty International regarding the conduct of some elements of the Papua New Guinea (PNG) defence forces? Has the Minister been made aware of possible abuses of human rights that have occurred on Bougainville as a result of operations of the PNG defence forces? What is the Government's response to suggestions of this kind?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the latest Amnesty report and I share the concern of the Papua New Guinea Government about the contents of it. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and I have raised the issue with the PNG Government on a number of occasions and at the highest levels, emphasising the need for investigations and appropriate disciplinary action to be taken against those responsible. In September, for example, the Prime Minister during his visit discussed our concerns with Prime Minister Namaliu and senior Ministers.

ANSWER.PARA: The PNG Government has acknow- ledged that abuses have occurred on Bougainville, committed by both the Bougainville Revolutionary Army (BRA) and some members of the security forces. The PNG Parliament, through the Berghuser Committee, also investigated allegations of human rights abuses on Bougainville. The PNG Government has itself undertaken a number of investigations but there are difficulties in pursuing a number of those allegations because of the continuation of the situation on Bougainville.

Nevertheless, 67 cases have been listed before the National Court in Rabaul and are being handled by the Public Solicitor's Office. The preliminary hearing in this respect was held on 12 October. The PNG Defence Force (PNGDF) at that hearing gave an undertaking that relevant documents would be released. A new date for hearing has been left open for the Public Prosecutor's Office to bring on cases as and when the various complainants come forward.

It is also the case that during the Endeavour talks, the PNG Government proposed the involvement of an International Committee of Jurists group to assist investigations into human rights abuses by both sides but the BRA did not agree to that. I understand that there were some reports this morning that a similar offer was repeated by the PNG Government yesterday.

In cooperation with PNG's own efforts and in response to PNG's request for assistance, Australia has initiated a program to improve the effectiveness of Papua New Guinea's security forces. A $19m advisory and training assistance program to the PNG Police Force has already been in operation since 1988. As one of its objectives, Australian advisers are assisting PNG trainers with courses which include lectures on the role of police within the Constitution; the rights of citizens; and the use of minimum force to achieve objectives.

An important element in the training program carried out by the Australian defence forces for new recruits to the Papua New Guinea defence forces is to improve discipline and leadership and to create an environment in which respect for human rights is upheld. It is also the case that, in response to the PNG Government's concerns, the International Committee of the Red Cross recently conducted training or awareness courses on international human rights conventions for the PNGDF.

As the Amnesty report acknowledges, the PNG Constitution does contain strong guarantees for the protection and promotion of human rights. I think, Mr President, summing all that up, the best guarantee we do have is the commitment, which undoubtedly still exists so far as the Prime Minister and senior Ministers are concerned, to respond in an appropriate way to these problems of human rights abuse whenever and wherever they do occur.

There are obviously going to be difficulties in tracking down and dealing with all of them, particularly in the circumstances that continue to exist on Bougainville. But we in the Australian Government believe the commitment is there and in a number of ways that I have already indicated we are doing our best to help the Papua New Guinea Government respond to the situation that has been spelt out.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Further to a question I asked Senator Cook regarding the current meat industry dispute in Queensland and Victoria, I ask whether the Minister is aware that the President of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, Mr Justice Maddern, in establishing the meat industry inquiry, said on 23 March, 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: In Victoria during the inquiry there should be no bans or limitations on work and we would recommend the status quo as at 1 January remain in relation to wages and conditions of employment.
Mr Rothman, representing the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, replied:
The union has, and continues to recommend to its members, to abide by the recommendations of the orders of the commission, and that includes the recommendations just made by the bench.

I ask: is the Minister also aware that, despite these assurances by Mr Rothman, the AMIEU currently has claims before export works in Victoria that into 1991 will cost not less than $140 per week per employee? I would also again ask the Minister: in view of these additional facts, is the Government prepared to intervene in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission hearing tomorrow on this matter in an endeavour to bring some sanity to our export meat industry and restore international confidence in our reputation as a reliable supplier?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It irks me tremendously that we should hear from the Opposition this allegation, which damages Australia's export standing in the world, that we are not a reliable supplier. One of the realities of our term of government is that industrial disputes in this country are down by 62 per cent from the level that applied during the Fraser years, and that in key export industries-notably in the iron ore industry and a number of agricultural export industries-Australia has a reputation as a reliable supplier. Let me give honourable senators one key example of a very sensitive industry which has a premium reputation, regarded at the highest level. Out of the North West Shelf project Australia supplies liquefied natural gas (LNG) to Japan.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. This is an interesting debate, but it has nothing to do with the meat industry, which is the subject of the question. I ask that you bring the Minister back to the subject.
—Senator Cook was asked a question about industrial disputes. He is dealing with the subject generally, but I ask him to answer the question asked by Senator Crane.

—Thank you, Mr President. I was dealing with the allegation contained in the question that Australia is not a reliable supplier. Every Australian should defend our trading reputation overseas, and those who seek to damage it are conducting an unpatriotic act.

ANSWER.PARA: My point is that out of the North West Shelf Australia supplies LNG to the Japanese market, and we do so because in Japanese eyes Australia is a reliable supplier.

Let me now turn to the meat industry. As I said to Senator Crane yesterday, the difference between our period of government and the period of government over which his Party presided in Australia some eight years ago is that there is generally a much lower level of industrial disputation, and we are able to isolate sectors of industry--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—That is absolutely true. If the honourable senator does not believe statistics--

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—We are able to isolate particular sectors that are dispute prone. Unfortunately, the meat industry is one of those sectors. As a consequence, an inquiry is being conducted into the industry by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Nothing in the preface to Senator Crane's question is at all surprising. Why he then equates the fact that a claim should be made with promoting industrial disputation is quite surprising because claims are made every day of the week. The purpose of making claims is to create a dispute at law so the matter can be dealt with by the arbitration Commission. If the Commission chooses, in whatever circumstances, to deal with it, that is the right of the Commission. Unlike Senator Crane's Party when it was in government, this Government will not stand over and interfere with the Commission, nor will we dictate to the Commission as to its rights. This Government believes the Commission is properly placed to make a judgment on each case that comes before it based on the merits of the case and the substantial arguments of the parties. Therefore, without trying to indicate to the Commission, I think it is appropriate that the Commission should deal with it. As I said yesterday, if there is a public interest dimension in this case, we will make an appearance and present the public interest in that case when it occurs.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Melbourne conference on housing and the church held on 9 November, and generally commend the Government on its national housing strategy. However, I regret that the Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Howe, failed to provide a rationale for continuing the negative gearing concessions for housing investors. Is the Minister aware of the statistics available from the Victorian Ministry of Housing and Construction which indicate that, in the two years since negative gearing was reintroduced, property investment has been concentrated in the wealthier suburbs while rent for a two-bedroom flat has increased by 30 per cent? Does the Minister agree that negative gearing was intended to stimulate low cost rental housing, that this objective has not been achieved and that negative gearing provisions should be abolished?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think housing investment in Melbourne, which is a city I can speak about with some greater knowledge, has probably been biased towards the upper end of the market because of the absence of capital gains tax on the domestic home. Certainly, there has been a lot of construction activity in Melbourne-and I suspect other cities-because of that fact in the housing market.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me come to the point of the question. I am not aware of what Mr Howe said at the conference to which the honourable senator referred, but it is not my recollection that the introduction of negative gearing was designed to deal with the problems of low cost housing.
