I thought that was essentially the function of public housing policy, and that the introduction of negative gearing was certainly because, as it has been put by the Treasurer since, as a matter of principle interest deductions should be permitted against income from any source as it is in the primary industry sector and in other sectors of the economy. Whether anything was said about the benefits which would flow to low cost rental accommodation from the introduction of negative gearing at the time, I do not recall. I will certainly try to obtain a more detailed answer from the Treasurer and provide it to the honourable senator as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer, it is fairly clear that he is not really aware that the cost of these particular concessions has been estimated at between $1 billion and $3 billion. Even if we take the lower figure, the expenditure on public housing could be doubled in any one year if these concessions were removed. It seems to me that by retaining these particular poorly targeted concessions, the Government is in fact contradicting its own national housing strategy. Would the Minister comment on that fact?
—Order! Senator Spindler, that was not really a question; it was a speech.

—I was not aware of all those matters and that is because I can read the honourable senator's lips but not his mind. He did not refer to any of those matters in his earlier question. In so far as I have undertaken to get a more detailed answer from the Treasurer, I will forward to the Treasurer's office queries about those alleged factual matters which the honourable senator put in his so-called supplementary question.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware that the minutes of the meeting of the Western Australian State Government Insurance Corporation Board of Commissioners dated 19 November 1987 show that a letter dated 16 November from the Premier and Treasurer of Western Australia at that time, Brian Burke, approved borrowings of $300m to purchase Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd shares from Bell Resources Ltd and that subsequently in the Legislative Assembly of Western Australia, on 18 November 1987, Premier Brian Burke denied that he had approved the borrowings and therefore grossly misled the Parliament and the people of Western Australia? Furthermore, is the Minister aware of conflicting evidence provided to the McCusker inquiry into Rothwells Ltd by the Ambassador to Ireland, Brian Burke, and former Rothwells director, John Hilton, about whether a meeting between Laurie Connell, Hilton and Burke to discuss the Rothwells rescue took place in May 1988, some six months after the announcement of Mr Burke's ambassadorial posting? Has the Minister investigated the propriety of the Ambassador in these matters; if not, will he? Finally, is it appropriate that Mr Burke remain in an ambassadorial position whilst these disturbing issues remain unresolved?

—I am not aware of any of the matters to which Senator Campbell refers. I do not propose to initiate any exercise of the kind that he invites me to. My answer in relation to this matter is the same as it has always been: if and when some evidence emerges through the courts or elsewhere of something which would make it inappropriate for the ambassadorial position to be maintained then I will act, but not sooner.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I referred the Minister in my question to two matters of fact, both of which are on the public record-one in the Hansard of the Western Australian Legislative Assembly, which says that the then Premier denied he knew of the borrowings, and the other in the minutes of the meeting of the State Government Insurance Corporation. So they are matters of fact. I will table these documents. I ask the Minister: will he investigate these matters of fact? They are not allegations.
—I have nothing to add to my previous answer.
—I seek leave to table the documents.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask whether the Minister is aware of the criticisms during recent days directed at the union movement in Victoria and the action proposed against it by the Opposition in that State. Does the Federal Government intend to adopt the program towards the union movement in Victoria proposed by the Opposition there? Can the Minister place Victoria's recent industrial history in a national context and, if so, will he do so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the first three questions, yes, yes and no. To the last question--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There were four questions. Just hang on; he is entitled to an answer. In answer to the last question, it is a sad fact that conservative political leaders in this country seem to think that they gain political points by attacking trade unions or by intervening in industrial relations in a disruptive way. The history of the Bjelke-Petersen, Ahern and Cooper governments is one recent example; in New South Wales the Greiner Government is embarking on that course; and it would seem that Mr Alan Brown in Victoria has chosen that course as well. They certainly ignore history. We were elected in 1983 on bringing Australia together and not setting Australians against Australians. We have brought Australia together significantly in terms of industrial relations.

ANSWER.PARA: Using the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) industrial disputes series, catalogue No. 6321.0, I have compiled a table of industrial disputation in the States of Australia, which makes interesting reading. During the Fraser Government years, from 1976 to 1982, Victoria had the highest rate of industrial disputation of any Australian State-an annual average of 689 days lost per 1,000 employees. The Australian average annual rate was 589 per 1,000 during the Fraser years.

During the Hawke Labor Government years, from 1983 to July 1990, the overall annual average rate of industrial disputation in Australia has dropped by 62 per cent to 224 working days lost per 1,000 employees. Industrial disputation in Victoria has fallen by the highest amount of any Australian State: it has dropped by 72 per cent to 193 working days lost per 1,000 employees, and is now below the Australian average. I point out for interest's sake that New South Wales has fallen by 55.4 per cent which is, in fact, a reduction that is trailing the field and is above the average annual reduction achieved throughout Australia.

For the record of the Parliament, I table the ABS series and the computations made to arrive at the figures that I have, Quite clearly, this demonstrates what all Australians, as respondents to surveys of opinion, know and say: that Labor governments handle industrial relations better; that Labor governments have a more realistic understanding of how to bring harmony to the working place and how industrial relations work; and that by not embarking on confrontationist, interventionist-type proposals of the sort that the Opposition Leader in Victoria is proposing, Labor governments are able to succeed at reducing the level of industrial disputes to the benefit of the productivity per person employed in this country and to the benefit of a reduction in real unit labour costs-a reduction achieved during the period of this Government but not during the period of the former Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of a document prepared for the receivers from the accounts of the Ravenshoe sawmill which shows that over $7.8m, including $7.6m of Commonwealth money, was retained by the company's Sydney office for use other than on the retooling of the Ravenshoe sawmill? Is it true that almost $200,000 of this was accounted for by a shortfall in fund transfers between Ravenshoe and Sydney? Is it not the case that $1.15m worth of veneer timber was sent to Sydney and not paid for in what is essentially a case of good, old-fashioned asset stripping? At this point I seek leave to table the document.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee was kind enough to show me the document at the beginning of Question Time. Certainly, it would appear from what he has provided me that the statement he makes is true. I am not sure of the status of these documents, nor am I sure of who prepared them and for what reason. Obviously, I will have to go and check on their veracity. But certainly it would appear from the documents that rotary veneers produced at Ravenshoe were shipped to Sydney and no payments were received. The total amount of--
—Whose house is being renovated?
—Don't worry.

—I won't. She is not worth worrying about. The total amount of Commonwealth money involved in assisting the Ravenshoe mill was $7.68m. If this document were true, then nothing at all was spent on retooling. Yet there is no question that some retooling did occur. I therefore cannot explain the discrepancy between the fact that retooling occurred and this document claiming that no money at all was spent on it. As Senator O'Chee would recall, the agreement with the mill at Ravenshoe provided for it to do more than just retool. It provided for it to be able to make up operating losses and to maintain employment at a particular number. So it was never suggested that every penny would be spent on retooling.

ANSWER.PARA: Our monitoring and meetings suggested that retooling had occurred. I do not understand, therefore, how it can be suggested in a document that more money than was paid by the Commonwealth could have been retained. That just does not make much sense. I will have to try to get an explanation for it and hopefully provide it to the honourable senator tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. Is the Minister aware that it is reported that a Hong Kong based company planning to build a $200m aircraft maintenance facility in Townsville has become impatient with alleged bureaucratic inertia and will now transfer this enterprise to Mexico? Can the Minister advise whether this report is accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to say that no, it is not accurate. I think, from memory, the matter was raised in the Senate by Senator Macdonald yesterday, and I read the Townsville Bulletin story and asked my office to speak to the people concerned who directly act in Australia for this company, Denbridge Ltd. My office has in fact spoken to the principal of the company.
—It is a dorothy dixer from Senator Reynolds.
—I do not consider it to be a laughing matter, actually, Senator Hill.
—I am just laughing about the way you gave a dorothy dixer to Senator Reynolds.

—I would have thought it of some interest to Senator Macdonald as well. Is that the case? He raised it and I am happy to provide him with the information. I must say, for the benefit of the residents of Queensland, if not for Senator Hill, that the facts are that the chief agent for this company in Australia has categorically denied this story. Mr Dunning, in fact, has been spoken to at some length by people in my office. They have advised that the company has in fact not washed its hands of the project for Townsville. They are still keen to go ahead with the aircraft maintenance facility in the city.

ANSWER.PARA: The original story did give the reader the clear impression that Denbridge had chosen, that is, had made a decision, to site the facility in Mexico instead of Townsville. This is not and, according to Mr Dunning, has never been the case. In those terms, the story is totally inaccurate. Townsville is in fact one of four sites where aircraft maintenance facilities are being considered by this company. The other sites are Mexico, Dubai-which is looking rather doubtful at the moment-and Hungary. Townsville is still being considered as the Asian base for maintenance for this company.

Mr Dunning has told my office that he is keen to get the project moving. He is planning to come to Australia shortly, and I will be meeting with him myself to discuss where the project can go from here. He has also advised my office that he is keen to talk to the Queensland Premier, Wayne Goss, and to other relevant Ministers in the Queensland Government.

There is still a great deal of work to be done to prove up the economic viability of this project, but I commend the efforts of the private consortium headed by the President of the Townsville and Thuringowa Development Board, Mr John McIntyre, in its bid to attract such important investment to the city of Townsville. I was heartened to see, in today's edition of the Townsville Bulletin, a statement by Mr McIntyre setting the record straight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade explain why a joint party delegation presently overseas on a fact finding trip originally planned to visit Pakistan and Greece was ordered at the last minute not to proceed to Pakistan but to substitute Romania instead? Can the Minister also explain why the political situation in Pakistan remains secure enough at this point for the sale of Mirage jets to that country, yet is clearly not considered by the Government and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to be secure enough or legitimate enough to enable a group of Australian politicians to visit?

— To my knowledge that question is based on a completely false premise. The parliamentary delegation was not ordered not to go anywhere. The members of the delegation chose themselves at the last minute not to go to Pakistan but to go to Romania instead, and there was no question of any intervention on my or the Government's part.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to statements made recently by a leading Canadian environmental consultant, Mr Jim MacNeil, who claimed that the proposed multifunction polis (MFP) in Adelaide's north-western suburbs had the potential to influence environmental management on a world scale. Is Mr MacNeil's assessment credible? If so, can the Minister give more information about the MFP's environmental benefits which may help to alleviate environmentalists' concerns regarding the proposed site for the venture?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Maguire, as a senator from South Australia, has taken a very keen interest in these matters--
—And he is to be commended.

— I thank Senator Crichton-Browne. Listening all these years, he will gradually learn. The fact of the matter is that MFP Adelaide could well enhance efforts to create a world leading management industry. Environmental management is one of the five key industries upon which the proposal is based. With environmental issues becoming of increasing concern both in Australia and globally, this area will be important to the MFP in terms of the opportunities offered by the Gillman site to research, develop, teach and demonstrate the skills and techniques of environmental renewal and responsible management. I make the point that these things have been done with sites like this in other countries and the technology is available.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, it involves the possibility of capturing the opportunities offered by the large and growing world market for environmental management services, tech- nology and education. The MFP could indeed have the potential to influence environmental management on a world scale, and a world environmental management centre is envisaged as one of the key proposals for the MFP. Initiatives are already progressing in South Australia in environmental research and teaching activities, including the proposal by the Flinders University to establish a new centre for sustainable development.

These and other proposals are being further investigated by one of the working parties set up by the MFP Adelaide management board, which is coordinating the next phase of the project and is due to report early next year. The report will include a detailed environmental assessment and the investigation of commercial feasibility. I again make the point that the Commonwealth and South Australian governments have said that there will be no final decision on the MFP unless it can be clearly shown that it is in Australia's best economic interests and is environmentally sustainable.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN COUNCIL OF TRADE UNIONS: GRANTS FOR FOREIGN AID

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Minister will be aware that the Hawke Government, during its term of office, has granted nearly $9m to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to administer for foreign aid purposes. Does the ACTU receive a management fee, contribution towards staff costs, or other form of compensation to administer these grants? What method of assessment does the Minister's Department employ to monitor and assess the effectiveness of these grants and to ensure that they achieve their stated goals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The grants in question are not to the ACTU as such but to an organisation which, in effect, is the overseas aid agency of the ACTU called the Australian People for Health, Education and Development Abroad (APHEDA), which operates for all practical purposes as an aid non-government organisation in exactly the same way as other aid NGOs operate and is subject to the same guidelines and the same principles in terms of the management, organisation, administration and accountability of the grants which are made to it.

ANSWER.PARA: APHEDA has a reputation of being one of Australia's most effective and efficient non-government aid organisations. That is really all I need to say. I will see whether there is any more information that I can dig up about the specific consultancy fees and so on which the honourable senator mentioned. But the short answer is that they are entirely consistent with the normal principles that apply to NGOs of that kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. In view of the comment that the Minister has made about the effectiveness of grants made by APHEDA, can he tell us how effective is the grant of $121,000 made to the African National Congress (ANC) for its planning meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to, Mr President. So far as that particular grant is concerned, the circumstances are as follows: the ANC is active in areas across the full range of development activity, including providing health and education services, both in and outside South Africa. A number of international aid donors look to the ANC to in fact plan and coordinate their activities.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a donor coordination meeting being organised by the ANC for early 1990-91. The ANC organised a preliminary planning meeting, together with the Mass Democratic Movement and trade union representatives from within South Africa, to set priorities and to develop proposals for presentation at that donor coordination meeting. It sought APHEDA funding for the planning meeting and, in turn, APHEDA approached the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau. The Government was pleased to meet the APHEDA request, given the important role of these bodies in bringing about change and in establishing and setting new development priorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Are the account verification provisions of the Cash Transaction Reports Act of 1988 another example of invasion of privacy perpetrated by this legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to inform Senator Sherry that there is no undue invasion of privacy occasioned by this particular Act and its implementation from time to time. Indeed, the Attorney-General announced yesterday that the provisions of the Act requiring cash dealers to verify the identity of new signatories to accounts will come into force on 1 February 1991. This will apply to banks and other financial institutions such as building societies, credit unions, TABs and casinos.

ANSWER.PARA: Parliament has already decided, in formulating the Act itself, on the balance to be struck between the legitimate privacy interests of individuals and the other legitimate interests of society, and particularly following the money trail, in order to secure the apprehension and conviction of those involved in organised crime, but particularly drug trafficking. That balance is a very delicate one but I believe it has been struck well in the legislation and in the various regulations now being put in place to implement it fully.

I well remember that when Mr Frank Costigan QC made his great report on the painters and dockers he pointed to many instances where suburban bank managers were virtually acting as accomplices and collaborators with organised crime groups in that they were not checking on obviously fictitious names used for the opening of accounts.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was eight years ago. You have done nothing since.

—Senator Alston says that we have done nothing in relation to that, which is completely and utterly ridiculous because the Cash Transaction Reports Act was passed-Senator Alston may have been asleep-and came into effect on 1 July 1988. To operate an account in a false name has been, as I say, an offence for some 2 1/2 years. But, no doubt, he would not have quite grasped that. These measures were a very important response by the Parliament to the Costigan report in relation to the opening of accounts in false names. I believe that, if we are to combat money laundering through financial institutions, this par- ticular Act and its implementation will become increasingly important.

ANSWER.PARA: As I say, the Act is being implemented in a piecemeal fashion. We have now reached the stage whereby on 1 February 1991 these various financial institutions will be required to verify the identity of those who open accounts with them or who are signatories to business transactions with them. There will be several methods of carrying out that verification of identity.

It is important to note that the records of that verification process will be held by the bank, credit union, the TAB agency or the building society and will not be made available to law enforcement agencies as a matter of course. They will be available only under the normal methods of search warrants and so on. That is to be distinguished from the usual pattern of activity by the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, whereby suspect transactions, those involving cash dealings of $10,000 or more, are automatically reported to the Agency and, of course, form the basis for some very effective investigative work by law enforcement agencies around Australia.

I believe that Mr Costigan's hopes in this regard have been fulfilled in a way which provides a proper recognition of the privacy concerns of individuals who open accounts or do business with these financial institutions. I believe that it goes a very long way towards helping Australia combat organised crime.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it the practice of Telecom Australia to intercept or monitor telephone calls between its employees and its employers, save for Telecom telephonists? Has Telecom knowledge of such a practice taking place in Western Australia? Under what authority does such conduct take place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne gave me prior notice of this question. I have asked Telecom for a response. It has provided me with the following information which, in fact, arrived just this morning. The answer to the first part of Senator Crichton-Browne's question is no. The interception of telephone calls is regulated in Australia by the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. The Act makes it unlawful for any person to intercept telephone calls without the knowledge of the person making the communication, except where it is done by an officer of Telecom in the execution of his or her duties in certain specific circumstances or under a warrant issued under the Act.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the second part of the question, in early 1989 Telecom investigatory staff in Western Australia incorrectly arranged for call charge analysis equipment-that is, CCAS equipment-to be placed on the services of some employees whose compensation cases were under review. CCAS equipment does not record details of conversations, but records the number dialled, the date and the duration of the calls. The error was detected and the matter was referred to the Australian Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions for consideration.

In relation to that last piece of advice, and perhaps to avoid the necessity for Senator Crichton-Browne to ask a supplementary question, I have asked Telecom to provide me with further advice as to what the results of that referral to the Australian Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions were.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As I understood the Minister, he was referring to compensation cases. Can I ask the Minister whether Telecom management in Perth is aware of other cases-and I refer to cases occurring between technical staff and clients-not related to the incident to which he has referred?

—The direct question that I put to Telecom was in fact that question. Senator Crichton-Browne's question was quite specific as to whether any interception equipment had been used in the manner that he has just described. That was precisely the question which I put to Telecom, and this is the advice that Telecom has provided me with in direct response to that question. So I would have to assume that the answer to that question is no, but I certainly will be happy to reconfirm that with Telecom and provide the Senate with further information because, as I say, I am following up the last part of this question in any case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

—Yesterday Senator Watson asked a question of Senator Gareth Evans in my absence about Senator McMullan's comments relating to the National Taxation Liaison Group. I am able to provide a further answer, there being several parts to Senator Watson's question as I understand it. In response to the first and second parts of the question, Senator McMullan was in his comments conveying the advice of the Commissioner of Taxation as to the discussions at the Taxation Liaison Group meeting. Confirmation of that advice is available, and I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the written confirmatory advice from the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN TAXATION OFFICE
MINUTE PAPER
Senator Bob McMullan
Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600

I understand that some doubt has arisen concerning my earlier oral advice to you that there was broad consensus at the Taxation Liaison Group meeting on 4 April 1990 that it was inappropriate to amend the law dealing with substantiation requirements.

2. This matter was raised by practitioners at that TLG meeting. It was raised in the context of a decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (commonly referred to as the ``evangelist case''), which decision confirmed the strict requirements of the substantiation provisions.
3. Practitioners, in the light of that decision, sought my views on how the provisions would be handled in the future.

4. I noted that the substantiation provisions had been introduced to deal with abuse of deductions for work and related expenses. I indicated that there was an ongoing need for a provision of this general kind.

5. There was reference made to the difficulties of finding a solution which was administratively practicable, having regard to the variety of situations that can arise and to broad administrative processes.

6. At the same meeting, there was discussion of progress in the moves to full self-assessment. There were practitioner comments, made in that context, that the discretions available to and exercisable by the Commissioner ought to be limited.
7. It seemed that a solution to the substantiation matter could only, in practice, be found in the giving of some sort of additional discretionary power to the Commissioner.
8. There was broad consensus at the meeting that it was not appropriate to change the law, and that the matter could be dealt with by the application of administrative commonsense.
9. It was also agreed that because of the nature of the issue, the outcome should be conveyed internally to taxation officers by me, and internally to practitioners by their representatives.

10. Given the nature of the issue, it was agreed that it would be counter-productive for there to be a perception amongst the general taxpaying public that the provisions were other than very strict, which they are.
T.P. Boucher
COMMISSIONER OF TAXATION
27 November 1990

TALK.START.PARA: —Could we have a copy?

—Of course the honourable senator may have a copy; he will just have to be mildly patient. On the third question, Senator McMullan was conveying the results of discussions between the practitioner representatives and the Commissioner of Taxation whose administration is the Parliamentary Secretary's responsibility. As to the fourth question, sound administration obviously requires the application of commonsense. Unyielding inflexibility regardless of the circumstances of the case would be totally unacceptable to the Australian public, and would bring the wheels of government to a grinding halt. That is not to say that the Government is ignoring the debate over the proper balance of the substantiation provisions. Senator McMullan said during the debate in the Senate on the subject of this question and answer:

ANSWER.PARA: There are other possibilities under consideration. The current view of the Government-and I think it is the absolutely correct one, on the balance of evidence-is that the Opposition's discretion measure is not the appropriate answer, certainly not as a one-off exercise like this . . . it does not go to all the questions that may arise as to the appropriate role of substantiation in the overall scheme of the legislation, the broader issues relating to substantiation rules, and it may be that when we look at those this discretion is entirely inappropriate.
On the fifth question, the answer is clearly no.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Coulter directed a question in my absence to Senator Cook. The question related to the use of photovoltaic cells in motor vehicles. I have an answer to Senator Coulter's question which is somewhat long and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
QUESTIONS RAISED BY SENATOR COULTER ON SOLAR CELL TECHNOLOGY
BACKGROUND
The photovoltaic (solar) cells used by the winning entry (Spirit of Biel) in the 1990 World Solar Challenge are not yet in commercial production anywhere in the world
- the cells on the car were produced by the German photovoltaic manufacturer AEG Telefunken to a design devised by Professor Martin Green at the University of New South Wales
- these laser grooved solar cells exhibit the highest energy conversion efficiency (19%) yet achieved using commercial grade silicon material.
Since 1978 Professor Green has received grants totalling in excess of $2m from the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration program to develop high efficiency solar cells
- much of the pioneering work undertaken by this research group on the laser grooved cells has been undertaken with Program support
- Professor Green's work is receiving continuing support from the recently established Energy Research and Development Corporation

- the research group has also been the recipient of substantial funding from the Government initially as part of a Centre of Excellence (Joint Microelectronics Research Centre) and more recently as a Special Research Centre (Photovoltaic Devices and Systems) in its own right
. . annual funding for the Centre is $850,000
The laser grooved solar cell technology has been licensed to three companies, including the Australian manufacturer BP Solar
- the company is shortly to commence small scale production of these cells in Spain
. . should the results of this trial be successful, BP has indicated that it is likely that it will employ the technology in its Sydney manufacturing plant

BP Solar has indicated that the reason initial production of laser grooved cells did not commence in Australia was that the company did not have the necessary infrastructure to initiate manufacture in Australia

- the production techniques are analogous to those employed by the computer industry and the company argues that, to develop a commercially viable product, it was necessary to undertake on-going development of the technology in a region of the world with ready access to this infrastructure
I think we would all very much hope to see these solar cells eventually manufactured and marketed in Australia.

We also consider that the greater commercial freedom available to the Energy Research and Development Corporation, which the Government has established to carry forward the work of the NERD& Program, will provide greater opportunity to exploit the commercial opportu- nities arising out of our local research and development efforts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 November 1990, Senator Coulter asked me a question regarding the Queensland Electricity Commission, which is not, of course, within the direct province of any Minister in this Government, but I undertook to obtain an answer for him if I could. I now have an answer to Senator Coulter's question, and as it is somewhat long I again seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The electrical power industry is principally the responsibility of the States and the questions asked concerning the Queensland electricity industry would therefore be more appropriately addressed to the Queensland Government. I can offer the following points, however, in response to the questions:

In its 1990 annual report the Electricity Supply Association of Australia indicates capital liabilities were $25 billion at the end June 1989; this includes domestic borrowings as well as foreign debt.
Given the importance of the electrical power industry the Commonwealth Government wishes to see continued improvement in the industry's efficiency. Recent Commonwealth initiatives include:

The Industry Commission (IC) inquiry into Energy Generation and distribution was announced in May 1990. Its Terms of Reference, which were developed in consultation with the States, are broadly to examine the scope for improving the efficiency of the electricity and gas industries and the means by which these improvements can be achieved. The electricity industry has made submissions and is closely involved in the inquiry. The draft IC report is scheduled for release in December 1990, followed by public hearings and a final report in May 1991.

The Special Premiers' Conference (SPC) of 30-31 October agreed that there may be additional benefits from extension and/or organisational changes to the interstate electricity network which now covers NSW, Victoria, South Australia and the ACT, with the possibility of Tasmania and Queensland being added. The SPC further agreed to the establishment of a working group to assess whether extensions are economically justified and if so also assess the organisational options to achieve this, including a jointly owned transmission system and other ways to improve current interstate management arrangements. The working group will report to the next Premiers' Conference and will include representation from relevant electricity authorities.

Working Groups on energy production and energy end-use established as part of the Government's sustainable development initiatives will draw on input from the electricity industry. The energy production Working Group will cover issues aimed at improving efficiency including the improved usage of plant and the impact of different generation techniques and sources. The energy end-use Working Group will assess the scope for demand reduction via tariff variation, demand management and improved equipment efficiency etc. The deadline for the Working Groups to report is October 1991.
On the Tully-Millstream power station proposal, the Queensland Government set up a task force in May 1990 to review the need for the Scheme. The task force is due to report its findings in May 1991.

New electricity generation developments are usually undertaken at high capital cost and generally involve installation of overseas equipment not available domestically. Assessment of capital loan requirements are made within the annual global Loans Council context where they relate to State Authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer for Senator Calvert to a question which he asked yesterday of me as the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I have provided a copy of the answer to Senator Calvert, and I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

There has been a clear misinterpretation of the message I delivered to the ACROD Convention in Sydney last week. There are no cuts proposed to the funding of sheltered workshops and there is no intention on the Government's part to arbitrarily close any service that is needed by people with disabilities.

As I indicated at the ACROD Convention the Government is committed to getting a better deal for people with disabilities, ensuring they have the same rights and opportunities as any other Australian-which is totally consistent with this Government's social justice strategy.

The Government is seeking co-operative and evolutionary change within sheltered workshops. This change is wanted by people with disabilities and their families because of the significant positive outcomes such change can provide. In fact, a key element of the Disability Services Act is the provision of necessary ongoing support to provide people with more severe levels of disability with the opportunity to participate in real work for real pay and also to make a meaningful contribution to society.

However, I did acknowledge that there are concerns about making change, particularly in the transition of sheltered workshops to employment approaches which are eligible under the Disability Services Act.
My approach to assisting sheltered workshops overcome these concerns includes:
- the Government's commitment of unprecedented funding levels to enable new options and better opportunities to be provided;
- pointing to examples of change which could be applied, where there is a will to do so;
- agreeing to streamline the process of reviewing sheltered workshops; and
- announcing the establishment of an independent, expert National Transition Technical Assistance Unit to assist sheltered workshops in the change process.
I announced this assistance at the ACROD Convention on 22 November 1990, and invite Honourable Senators to read my speech on that occasion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time Senator Olsen asked me a question about the parliamentary delegation to Pakistan. I have subsequently checked the terms of my correspondence with the Presiding Officers on this matter and they confirm the accuracy of my answer. Originally there was a letter of 5 October from Dr Blewett, as Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, informing the Presiding Officers that at that stage the Australian Government had no objections to planning for the parliamentary delegation's visit to Pakistan proceeding. But the point was made that in the light of uncertainty about the election and the electoral process that advice may need to be revised.

ANSWER.PARA: I wrote again on or about 1 November to the Presiding Officers saying that, on the basis of information available to us at that stage, I did not have any objections to the visiting proceeding as planned. So any changes that were made to the visit arrangements would have been as a result of further consideration by the Presiding Officers based on budgetary and other relevant considerations. They had nothing to do with any policy prescription being stated by the Government. So all those breathless oohs and aahs that accompanied my answer previously were entirely misplaced.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could just add to that answer given by Senator Evans-because it was a decision taken by the Presiding Officers, not by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade-he is correct in saying that early in August concerns were expressed about the possibility of a delegation going to Pakistan, given that the elections were going to take place. Given that uncertainty, it was imperative that planning be undertaken for the parliamentary delegation to visit another country in case the visit to Pakistan did not eventuate.

INTERJECT.PARA: In the event the Romanian Parliament, which we were due to visit next year, agreed to host a visit while at the same time the Pakistani authorities indicated a difficulty in meeting our proposed timetable for the visit to Pakistan. TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 November Senator Watson asked me a question about the increase in the cost of sending Christmas cards overseas by airmail, and particularly the differential between the cost of seamail and airmail.

ANSWER.PARA: I have received the following advice for Senator Watson: honourable senators will be aware that under the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 Australia Post has an obligation to act commercially. It must raise sufficient revenue to cover its operating costs and produce a profit sufficient to achieve a satisfactory rate of return on assets paid as a dividend to the Government and finance its ongoing capital investment program. Australia Post is also subject to all of the Commonwealth, State and local government taxes and charges that apply to business generally. Australia Post has advised that international postal charges are set according to the costs incurred in providing the service and are based on the weight--

TALK.START.PARA: —The sea costs are dearer.

—This is a good news story; not a bad news story. The international postal charges are based on the weight and bulk of the article to be posted, not the intrinsic value. The seamail Christmas card concession rate, which applied previously, was withdrawn because of significant losses incurred in the service. In addition, it is much more difficult to manage sea carriage to meet specific delivery standards. To offset the abolition of this concession, Australia Post has introduced an economy air concession which, for cards weighing up to 20 grams, will enable Australia Post customers to send their greeting cards by air at a cheaper rate than by seamail. In addition, sending their cards by economy air will enable a more reliable standard of service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator O'Chee this day, relating to the Ravenshoe sawmill.

I thank the Minister for Social Security most sincerely. I have moved this motion because information has come to hand which confirms my earlier fears that there has been a substantial misappropriation at the Ravenshoe sawmill in north Queensland. In October I tabled financial statements relating to Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd and other associated companies which suggested that in excess of $5m may have been misappropriated from the sawmill in Ravenshoe. I was concerned about the possible misappropriation because it appeared, and now transpires, that it occurred under the Government's very nose. In response to my original allegations Senator Richardson stated:

. . . up until the time the Company went into receivership it had met the conditions placed upon it by the Commonwealth. I am advised that there was, therefore, no need to take any action until then and no reason for us to do so.

I subsequently tabled in the Senate evidence to show that between $5.3m and $5.7m had been syphoned out of Ravenshoe, apparently for the purpose of building a sawmill in Kyogle. The money of course should have stayed in Ravenshoe. That was the intention and that was why the money was made available by the Commonwealth.

I have now tabled documents which, I understand, were prepared from accounts of the Ravenshoe mill and which confirm my earlier suspicions and in fact go much further. Almost $7.6m of Commonwealth funds was made available to the mill. At most, only $3.8m, as identified in the tabled documents, was spent either directly or indirectly on the retooling of the mill. A sum of $1.2m of this came out of the company's own working capital. This means that only $2.6m of the $7.6m made available by the Commonwealth was used in the retooling of the mill.

The documents in my possession also indicate that there was a substantial discrepancy in the funds transferred between the National Australia Bank Ltd in Ravenshoe and Westpac Banking Corporation in Sydney. The effect of this was that some $200,000 appears to have been syphoned out of the company's accounts in Ravenshoe.

Also of concern to me is the transfer of $1.15m of veneer timber from Ravenshoe to associated companies which was never paid for. These transfers occurred mainly between October 1988 and August 1989. The failure of the Ravenshoe mill to receive payment for this timber was not a clerical oversight as it occurred over a protracted period. The accounts were unpaid for up to 18 months before the group went into receivership. As far as I can see, this is a case of asset stripping, pure and simple.
According to the statement tabled by Senator Richardson on 16 October:

Like any good business manager the Commonwealth did not let its loan go unwatched. Officers of the Department regularly telephoned the manager of the mill to seek information on progress with the retooling. The mill was visited by representatives on several occasions. The Department's financial advisers on this issue, Price Waterhouse, also monitored the operations of the mill.

I cannot understand how $1.15m worth of timber could disappear from the mill and not be noticed. That it could occur is not surprising, however, given that the veneer mill was sold and that was not noted by the departmental officers. I am now able to show that the money for this veneer mill was received on 14 November 1989, a full five months before the company went into receivership. I can only assume that the machinery was sold about this time as the moneys were received but never noted by the departmental officers. As I said in October, this is clearly in breach of clause 2, subclause 1, paragraph 1 of the assistance agreement.

All this shows very clearly that the Ravenshoe sawmill was and remains a viable financial proposition. Its failure can be attributed to two things: the apparent rorts by the previous management and the Government's financial negligence. This also proves beyond doubt that the Government should and must do everything in its power to keep the mill going. On behalf of the people of Ravenshoe, I must say that I also believe that there is very good evidence that fraud may have occurred and that the Commonwealth's consultants, Price Waterhouse, may have been negligent in monitoring the operations of the mill.

I am continuing my investigations and look forward to frank and open cooperation by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, to right the wrongs that have occurred.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I wish to congratulate the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority on the presentation of another report and the expiration of another very fine year. It is very important to note a comment in the report in order to understand the significance of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park-that is, that the Barrier Reef is a natural resource, the economic value of which is estimated to be $1,000m per annum and the ecological value of which is quite incalculable. It is a massive resource. It is one of the eight wonders of the world. It is something which attracts tourists to north Queensland from all over the world and it is something which, in general, north Queenslanders and Australians guard very jealously. It is a marvellous asset to this country and something of which we, as Australians, should be very proud.

The Authority which manages the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park is held in particularly high regard throughout the world. Its members are known for their competence, their expertise and their even-handedness in all their dealings. Among the projects the Authority looked at during the year in question was a matter which is very important to the Great Barrier Reef and to conservation and ecology generally-that is, the effect on the Great Barrier Reef of the run-off of nutrients from the land into the sea.

The Authority notes with some satisfaction that a lot of work is being done, a lot of guidance is being given and advice is being sought through the Great Barrier Reef Marine Council. It also notes that the farming community of north Queensland is aware of the problem of nutrient run-off into the sea around the reef and is adding its weight to try to overcome it. The farming community is joining in projects and investigations to stop that soil erosion. It is doing so for two reasons: firstly, to save the Great Barrier Reef and, secondly, to lessen the rate of soil erosion and land degradation which occurs in some of the fragile lands of north Queensland.

It is also interesting to note from the report that over the past year the Authority has been charging for its investigations into development matters. I am particularly pleased to note that the Authority is undertaking a program to examine continually its procedures in order to maximise efficiency and to avoid unnecessary bureaucracy. This is indeed a worthwhile aim for a government agency. It is one which does not surprise me, because I know of the high standing in which the Authority is held. It is worth noting, and making an example of, the efforts to which the Authority has gone to make sure its methods are carried out in the most efficient way to reduce costs for the customers it serves.

I also want to mention briefly the enormous amount of work that the Authority does in trying to minimise the risk from oil spills on the reef and to minimise the dangers such a spill, should it ever tragically occur, would create. Hopefully, with all the work being put in by the Authority, such a thing will never happen. But if it does, the Authority is as well prepared as anyone ever could be to try to save the reef.

I draw the Senate's attention to an appeal made by the Chairman of the Authority in his report regarding appeal procedures that the Authority is involved in. I ask the Government to look very seriously at that matter. A development was constructed at Magnetic Quay--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike Senator Macdonald, I find that this is a cosy document in that problems are noted but not really addressed. For example, page 2 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence continues to accumulate that the levels of nitrogen and phosphorous in the waters of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park are causing damage to some coral communities . . .

The farming community itself is aware of the problem and changes are occurring already in farming practices which will have the effect of reducing the run-off of nutrients, as well as reducing the rate of soil erosion and land degradation.

It is the view of the Australian Democrats that pollution from agricultural, industrial, mining and sewage effluents is being pumped into the reef system from many rivers and island resorts at dangerous levels. While I welcome the comments of the Queensland cane growers in particular, I think that there is a much more urgent need to modify land use practices now. We need to address the matter of the excessive use of fertilisers, soil erosion and run-off from the infamous Daintree road.

Several times over the last few years the Democrats have attempted to introduce amendments to legislation in this place to protect the reef from mining. We have also attempted to introduce amendments to strengthen conservation procedures regarding the reef. The threats to the reef now really include intense pressure from commercial interests, such as tourism and fishing, which are not adequately screened off from the reef.

There is presently an unsustainable level of fishing, both commercial and recreational. As there has been an upsurge in tourist numbers-an annual increase of 30 per cent, with about 1.5 million visitors in 1989-this means that such pressures will become greater. Therefore, we believe that zoning needs to be strengthened and tourist proposals need to be more carefully monitored.
Page 15 of the report deals with zoning as perceived by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. It states:
Whenever a zoning plan is about to be prepared, Reef users are invited to give their opinions on how zoning should be undertaken as well as providing information about their use of the Reef.

That is the problem as we see it: all of the emphasis is on the use of the reef. There seems to be little recognition of the fact that the reef, like our forests and our mountains, belongs to all Australians, not just the users and the exploiters. We should recognise the fact that the reef has a right simply to exist in its own right-it is an ecosystem which we have no right to destroy or degrade.

The major threat to the reef comes from outside-from the Government's strategy of offshore oil exploration which would see drilling adjacent to the reef in the Townsville trough and the Maryborough basin, the Queensland trough and the Capricorn basin, where wind and currents would disastrously carry oil spill on to the reef, causing major ecological disaster.

On the credit side is this week's announcement that the international maritime authorities have agreed to declare the reef a compulsory pilotage area. This was decided, obviously, after the printing of this document. However, I welcome this announcement, which will mean greater safety from oil spillage from marine accidents. I also note with pleasure the happy ending to the floating hotel saga whereby the monster has been removed without leaving any trace.

In conclusion, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is doing a good job, probably the best it can under the circumstances, but I believe that policy needs to be hardened. We need to stop attempting to compromise with tourist and commercial pressures and, indeed, see the role of the Authority as custodian of this unique part of the world.
However, it is unrealistic to ask any department to function to its optimum with inadequate funds. A constant refrain of this report can be found on page 23, where it is stated:
The year was characterised by pressure to deal with a heavy workload without sufficient resources.
We should give the Authority the necessary resources to preserve the incalculable ecological value, which Senator Macdonald spoke of, that the Great Barrier Reef has for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to mention a few matters that have emerged out of this debate on the annual report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. I join with previous speakers in commending the Authority on not only the work it is doing but also the manner in which it is doing it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that the Australian Democrats have made the comment that there is a deficiency in the report in the sense that problems were noted but not really addressed. But I think one of the significant things about this report is that it is addressing the problems. On the question of nutrients, for example, I thought it would have been nice if the last speaker had acknowledged the fact that the Authority is now in a much better position to deal with this because, as the report says:

Coordination of action in relation to nutrients, most of which are likely to originate from run-off from farm land on the mainland, will be made much easier through the new membership of the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council. Members now include the Ministers for the Environment and the Ministers responsible for Primary Industries in both the Queensland and Commonwealth Governments. It is these ministries which have the primary responsibilities relevant to research and management of land use on the mainland.
I thought it would have been nice if the previous speaker had rounded off her quote and said that the report says:
Such programs and changes will benefit not only the mainland, but the Great Barrier Reef as well.

It seems to me that questions are being addressed. On the question of oil spills, for example, there is no doubt there is a significant addressing of that problem. While it is true that the Authority says that the various measures it is taking, and has taken, can reduce the risks of an oil spill and, in most circumstances, reduce the adverse environmental effects of a spill, it cannot eliminate them. That is quite true, but it is churlish not to acknowledge that the Authority is not only noting but is also addressing these problems. The report states:
A significant amount of oil is transported by ship in the shipping channels within the Great Barrier Reef.
However, it goes on:

. . . the Authority is developing a computer program which incorporates maps showing the location of environmentally sensitive areas and which predicts the movement of an oil spill relative to wind and tide conditions. This simple program, which runs on the popular Apple McIntosh microcomputer, has proven more effective than far more elaborate programs developed by other agencies around the world because its use requires almost no special training.
It goes on to state:
The Authority has worked with a number of Commonwealth Government Departments towards the introduction of compulsory pilotage for all vessels . . .

I am glad to see it was acknowledged that, although the report says that about 90 per cent of the relevant vessels now using the Great Barrier Reef employ pilots on a voluntary basis, we are moving to 100 per cent despite the constraints under international law.

The point that Senator Macdonald was unable to complete about appeals procedures when developers wish to proceed with a development in the area is that the appeals system has been, I will not say abused, but has caused a great many problems in the past. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority strongly believes that the delays that are set up by people using the mechanisms almost ad absurdum are:

. . . unfair to the public, unfair to developers and to opponents of proposals and projects within the Great Barrier Marine Park. The matter has been taken up with the Commonwealth Government with the hope of achieving changes in the procedures relating to such appeals.

I believe that this indicates that this body, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, is acting in a sensible and coherent way to address the problems-and they are very real indeed-of threat to the reef from nutrients, oil spills or excessive development. I believe that this is one of those bodies that should be commended for its active and effective handling of the problems, and also its determination to do so in a sympathetic and sensitive way.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Australian film industry is facing a great deal of difficulty, not only because of repeated changes in government policy and international problems, but also because of the collapse of all of the major Australian television networks. I do not think that the Chairman of the Australian Film Commission necessarily does himself or his status much good by giving gratuitous insults to the people who en- gineered the collapse of the Australian commercial television industry. I think we can do without Mr Phillip Adams giving us the benefit of his advice, and I quote:
. . . the once flourishing commercial networks which have fallen victim to corporate greed and stupidity.

He says that the broadcasters have had to pay for the follies of new owners. The net result has been chaos, insolvency and an inability to play their traditional part as instigators of, or investors in, a proper level of local drama and documentary.

There is no doubt that the collapse of those entrepreneurs in the television industry has caused serious problems. I think it can be commented on without going over the top in the way Mr Phillip Adams, as Chairman of the Australian Film Commission, does in its annual report. Nonetheless, it is a serious problem, and it is particularly worrying when one recognises that there are some important Australian content targets that have been agreed to and that will in fact involve the Australian television industry in high levels of expenditure. Looking at the television industry at the moment, it is a matter of some concern where the money is going to come from. It is vital that there is sufficient funding for Australian productions. This industry was prospering at the time of the Fraser Government under the very enlightened ministry of Mr Bob Ellicott, but it is now facing a whole series of problems.

It is unfortunate that Australians do not seem to be terribly keen to see Australian films. I notice that in the annual report it says that Australian features only had a 5 per cent share of capital city cinemas in Australia last year. It is also interesting to see that the number of Australian drama programs on Australian prime time television totalled 26 features last year, compared to 30 Australian drama programs on North American pay television last year. Apparently, American pay television channels are more interested in Australian features than Australian prime time television producers are.

I believe the Australian Film Commission is doing a worthwhile job, although it is going through major changes in its activities and direction. It is now basically aimed less at involving itself in big Australian productions-which are now financed through the Australian Film Finance Corporation Pty Ltd-and more at providing opportunities for younger, less experienced people in the industry to get a performance opportunity. In this area the Australian Film Commission has apparently been having a reasonable level of success. I think that the challenges that the film industry face in the coming years will be facilitated if the Australian Film Commission can continue to provide the basic support that is required in this developing area of young Australian film-makers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I have glanced quickly through the Law Reform Commission report. As I did, it occurred to me that there are a lot of good people in the community who do a lot of good things. If one reads through report No. 54 of the Law Reform Commission, it becomes apparent what I mean. There is the Commission itself and there are the people on whom the Commission has been able to call over the years to help it do its work; and it is work which is vital.

Doctors look after our life and health and are therefore to be given much kudos, but the people who make the law and see that it is enforced, and properly interpreted, also serve a noble purpose. They guard our rights; they look to see that our reputation is preserved as it should be; they facilitate the machinery of the law, which looks after those great aspirations of the human spirit-such as aspirations to liberty, to tolerance, to kindness, and to generosity-that we like to think are the marks of what is best in humankind. In doing those things, people connected with the law perform a very high duty in society.

The law, like society itself, is an institution which is forever in flux. Society is forever changing and the law, which reflects that society, must change with it. In effect, that means that there will always be need for law reform. The way that reform is carried out is crucial to the sort of community we live in and to the sort of life we are able to pursue. In that context, the Law Reform Commission, to which governments of both colours have looked since it was set up in 1973, is a vital instrument through which good can be done to this society.

It is always invidious, as has often been said, to mention names, but I do think it proper to mention the President of the Law Reform Commission, Justice Elizabeth Evatt, who has led a mighty team-mighty in the way it has suggested reform to the law; mighty in the way it has carried out its task; and mighty in the way it has expressed the things it has done with such clarity. She has been a great source of information to the Committee which I chair, that is, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and she has been an inspiration to that Committee. She is greatly assisted by the Secretary and Director of Research of the Commission, that is, Mr Stephen Mason. The Deputy President, Mr Greenwell, also deserves mention, as do the many people whose names appear in this report. If time were available I would certainly mention many of them, because they all deserve mention. As ever, time is on the wing and I am unable to do so. I simply sum up by saying that this is a great report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The examination of laws against the background and framework of values that are held and necessary for a cohesive, happy society are very necessary within this country or any other country. The work of the Law Reform Commission over a number of years has been the subject of discussion in this chamber and elsewhere. Not infrequently, the discussion has focused on particular reports of the Law Reform Commission. This report, however, is the annual report of the Law Reform Commission and, as has been indicated, quite a range of people, not only on the Commission but also outside of it, have made contributions to the work of the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I do, however, have one caveat-given the statements made by the previous speaker-in respect of Justice Elizabeth Evatt. It is important when Justice Elizabeth Evatt goes to particular locations and addresses organisations that the speeches she makes be made available to members of parliament and to any individual in the community who requests them. On 17 November, Justice Elizabeth Evatt, the President of the Law Reform Commission, addressed the conference dinner at the Abortion Providers Federation of Australia. A request has been made for a copy of her address, but that has not been forthcoming.

It is very important that we know what is being said by people who are looking at law reform in Australia. The area of abortion is a matter of great tragedy in Australia. It is a matter of great human cost, and indeed financial cost, in Australia. It would be illuminating for members of parliament and members of the public to know what is being said by Justice Elizabeth Evatt, and particularly to know, from a perusal of that address, why she chose to accept an invitation from an organisation which has a vested interest in the abortion industry in Australia.

With that caveat, I should like to concur with what has been said about the work that is being done by a large number of people to run the rule over the laws of this country and to respond to some of the difficult references that are frequently being made by governments of all colours.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 September 1984 and 11 October 1984, the Senate and the House of Representatives respectively agreed to resolutions which in part relate to the release of in camera evidence and records of joint committees of the Parliament which have been in the custody of the Parliament for at least 30 years.

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to those resolutions, I report that, in conjunction with the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the President has authorised the release of transcripts of in camera evidence and other related material of the Joint Committee on Rural Industries (1940-1943) and the Joint Committee on Social Security (1940-1946) to Dr Noel Whiteside, a British academic currently seconded to work at the Centre for International Research on Communications and Technologies in Melbourne.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table additional information received by Estimates Committee A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I say from the outset, so that it is clearly understood, that, of course-and it need not be said-the coalition fully supports the endeavours and the efforts of the National Crime Authority and naturally, as has been said before, the appointment of Mr Justice Phillips as the Chairman of the National Crime Authority. It fully embraces and endorses the new direction which was unveiled last weekend to the intergovernmental committee in Alice Springs.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) to some comments he made in the Senate some days ago about turning over the cinders of the past. Am I right in assuming that that does not imply in any way that the Government does not support the present reference that the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority Committee has of inquiring into the effectiveness of the National Crime Authority?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crichton-Browne for his indication that the Opposition parties-and from what has been said in informal conversations with Senator Spindler, I have no doubt the Australian Democrats also-support very strongly the appointment of Mr Justice Phillips as Chairman of the National Crime Authority and the new direction in which he is taking the investigative work of that Authority, which, of course, is charged with assembling admissible evidence, using extraordinary powers, over a whole range of serious organised criminal activity in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Justice Phillips has indicated that there will be a shift in emphasis from drug trafficking questions-though not, of course, abandoning inquiries where appropriate-to the investigation of white collar crime as an important facet of its work. Of course, money laundering is the bridge between the two. We know that great volumes of money are generated from drug trafficking and find their way into apparently legitimate businesses. In that way, there is an attempt to shield from investigative agencies the true origin in criminal activity of substantial amounts of money which are to be found in our commercial and trading enterprises and life. I am very pleased to have received that assurance from Senator CrichtonBrowne, on behalf of the Opposition. I am sure that it will be of great comfort to Justice Phillips as he undertakes his task.

In that context, it is not so much that the Government has a view as to the appropriateness of the parliamentary Joint Committee undertaking earlier than it originally envisaged its review of the overall operation of the National Crime Authority. As I understand it, the parliamentary Joint Committee is entitled to undertake such a review, given its statutory terms of reference.

The intergovernmental committee is composed not simply of the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth of Australia but of Attorneys-General and Ministers for police from all jurisdictions. It receives very strong support from Mr Ted Pickering, representing the Government of New South Wales, Mr Marshall Perron, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and Mr Bernard Collaery, who was invited to attend as an observer at the recent meeting in Alice Springs. The committee is made up of people from all jurisdictions. I merely mention those people to show that it is a bipartisan matter. They have indicated that they believe it would be better and more conducive if this new direction envisaged and captained by Mr Justice Phillips be allowed to develop without the distraction of raking over dying embers of past difficulties which did exist and for which a remedy was needed.

In so far as many of those difficulties had to do, for example, with the question of some jealousy, the protection of turf and a perceived lack of cooperation and collaboration with other law enforcement agencies, they have been addressed head on by Mr Justice Phillips. He has indicated a new collaborative and cooperative approach which has the support of all Ministers from all jurisdictions together with their commissioners of police and, I am sure, other Federal Government agencies, such as the Cash Transaction Reports Agency.

As far as matters of morale within the organisation are concerned, I believe very strongly that those working within the organisation, under the leadership of Mr Justice Phillips, ably aided by Mr Julian Leckie and Mr Greg Cusack, QC, and knowing that all governments are fully supportive of the new directions and of the new leadership, will have had a tremendous boost to their morale and will be anxious to get on with the job, newly defined as it is.

It was in that context that the inter-governmental committee made a suggestion to the parliamentary Committee that it might hold its review at the original time that was intended rather than having it brought forward, as is apparently the case at the moment. So it is not so much a government directive, if one likes, as a matter for the Commonwealth Attorney-General, as chairman of the intergovernmental committee and on behalf of the Committee, writing to the parliamentary Joint Committee in those terms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking only for myself, I should say that I was concerned to understand that a number of States had, in fact, prepared submissions for us and, as a result of a reconsideration, I assume, by the intergovernmental committee those submissions are not to proceed to us and we are not to receive the benefit of them. I understand that we will be receiving collectively one submission. I think that is the position.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise that only because if we are to get a proper understanding of the functioning of the Authority, it is better that we receive the submission from each of the law enforcement agencies and each of the authorities that are working with the National Crime Authority, which are involved in this area and make up the inter-governmental committee.

Much of what the honourable senator says, of course, is indisputable. But, as has been observed by others greater than I, if we do not learn from the mistakes of the past, we can be certain about repeating those errors in the future. Of course, there would be nothing more debilitating than simply having an exercise which allowed old battles to be refought and to be relived. But, to the extent that that was demonstrated in the minority report to which I attested my signature, the problems in the Authority thus far have not been restricted to the areas to which the honourable senator referred; rather, they have extended to very real difficulties amongst present and past members of the Authority. There is clearly a morale problem, at least as perceived by some employees of the Authority. I would have thought that there was some virtue in ensuring that those matters are more properly behind us.

I have no doubt that, with the approach that has been taken by Mr Justice Phillips, we will see a new attitude within the Authority and I think a new understanding amongst all the members of the Authority. I think its attitude, for instance, towards our Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority is quite different from that which I have perceived in the past during the short time I have been a member of that Committee.

I refer honourable senators to one of the inevitable problems that the Committee now has, and that is the clash between the secrecy provisions which I think are found in section 51 of the National Crime Authority Act and subsections (1) and (2) of the Parliamentary Privileges Act, which is causing some difficulty to the extent that, when we have sought what I would have thought was fairly elementary information, such as whether an inquiry was undertaken into the circumstances of the past Chairman's resignation-with very legitimate reasons for requesting that information-the Authority has been un- able to provide us even with that. It suggested that to tell us that was to leave us with the revelation as to whether or not it was an operational matter. That is, to say the least, absurd. The Authority has properly said that it has to concern itself with the secrecy provisions and that, if it could receive certainty beyond that which is presently available to it that it would not be in breach of section 51, it would be happy to disclose further information.

The Clerk of the Senate has proffered a view which is shared by a number of senators that it would not be in breach of that section because of section 49 of the Constitution and because of the Parliamentary Privileges Act. It seems to me, if we are to embrace the view given to us by the Solicitor-General, that that opens up a whole new vista in respect of many Acts. I think that about 300 Acts contain secrecy provisions. I refer honourable senators to, for instance-without debating a Bill which I do not think has actually been introduced yet-to a Bill which will be dealt with by Senator Michael Baume relating to the Australian Sports Drug Agency. If one refers to clause 67 of that Bill, one will see secrecy provisions which, in my view, at a very cursory glance, seem to be not terribly different from those contained in the National Crime Authority Act.
