I assume, if one were to pursue the proposition being put forward by Dr Griffith, that it would be an offence with a penalty of two years gaol, for instance, for the Chairman of the Australian Sports Drug Agency to come before the Committee, having been perhaps subpoenaed-the Committee using its coercive powers-and then being required to disclose the names of the athletes who have tested positive in recent testing. I would have thought that that is an intolerable proposition to be putting to us. Frankly, it would make impossible the functioning of committees in terms of executing their responsibilities. I would be grateful if the Minister could indicate to me whether I have got it right or whether I am on the wrong tram.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the particular difficulty facing the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority, I have already indicated, in answer to a question in the Senate-I think it was last week or earlier this week-to Senator Spindler that I believe that getting the balance right between the proper supervisory role of the Parliamentary Joint Committee and the need for the National Crime Authority to operate in a secret fashion, without disclosure of the sorts of investigations which it is undertaking, is a very difficult one indeed. I do not believe that the balance is at the right point at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that, whilst it was quite proper for the Solicitor-General's opinion to be relied upon in relation to a particular dispute which arose, it may be that neither I nor Senator Crichton-Browne would have written the opinion in exactly the same way. But there it is and, as I say, I believe that it was quite proper for the National Crime Authority and others to have regard to that opinion as definitive. I do not think that one can seek a higher opinion from within the government system than that of the Solicitor-General, who is a most esteemed and eminent Queen's Counsel.

I do believe that the whole question of the relationship between a parliamentary committee and its scope of inquiry when confronted by a secrecy provision shielding an organisation into which it is making an inquiry or over which it has a supervisory role, is one which can depend less on a supposed clash between the privileges of the Parliament and the secrecy provisions than on a simple inquiry into the proper scope of an inquiry which can be undertaken by the Committee.

Whereas normally, standing committees and select committees are bound only by terms of reference given to them by the chamber or chambers, in the case of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority, of course, there is a set of statutory parameters as to the sorts of inquiries it may properly undertake. As I understand it, the Solicitor-General's opinion really depended on saying that the question of a clash between privileges and secrecy provisions did not get off the ground because the parliamentary committee was not proposing to investigate a matter within its terms of reference. In other words, it was acting ultra vires. So I do not think the matter has exactly been resolved even by the Solicitor-General's opinion, and that gives scope for an investigation of the balance--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; I missed that.

—I do not believe that the matter of the balance that I have been referring to is actually resolved by the Solicitor-General's opinion because, as I understand it, he really went on the ground that the Parliamentary Joint Committee was proposing to act in a way which was ultra vires its statutory terms of reference. I think that is a correct way in which to express it. What I am saying is that, not only in relation to this particular provision but in relation to all the secrecy provisions as they might clash with the asserted privilege of the Parliament to inquire without fear and to allow parliamentarians to be absolutely fully informed of a matter under their supervision or investigation, those matters can still be looked at. In fact, I said in an answer to Senator Spindler, which I referred to earlier, that the Government would look to his particular contribution as a constructive one as part of that process, and I believe that is still the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is why I am confused, but I am easily confused so forgive me. There is a distinction between sections 51 and 55: 51 is the secrecy provisions, and 55 is the powers of the Authority. Clearly, if the Committee exceeds its powers-and I assume this is justici- able-an injunction or some such process could be sought which could be determined in the appropriate court. That is one matter. For instance, that might arise where a question is asked of a member of the Authority which might be, in his view, impinging upon the secrecy provisions, but is in his judgment outside section 55 because the terms of reference-the statutory powers and particularly the responsibilities-have been exceeded. Presumably he can seek relief from being required to answer that question on the grounds that the matters being inquired into are beyond the authority of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: That is quite different to, for instance, a reference that without question is inside section 55. But that question might be one which the Authority member judges to breach section 51 and not in any way bring into question section 55, and that was one of the matters which was raised. As I understand it, one of the questions asked was whether the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 provides immunity for any member or member of the staff of the Authority who provides information to the Committee notwithstanding the secrecy provisions of section 51 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984. That is the threshold question that we are seeking determination on, irrespective of whether any particular questions that impinged upon secrecy were, for instance, operational matters or anything else outside the scope of the authority of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that it is very conducive to investigating the legal niceties to have a continual exchange of opinions across the floor of the chamber in the Estimates Committee of the Whole. I have tried to indicate that the Government is aware of the difficulty of ensuring that an authority such as the National Crime Authority-vested as it is with powers which certainly at the time of its creation were not vested in any other law enforcement agency in Australia-ought to be subject nevertheless to some sort of democratic supervision to ensure that it does not act in a way which undermines the very democratic fabric of the society we are purporting to defend against organised crime.

SPEECH.PARA: In so far as the privileges of Parliament are an important part of the armoury of the elected representatives of the people to ensure that information is properly made available to those parliamentarians so that they can discharge their duties, those privileges have to be taken very seriously into account and perhaps need to have a decisive democratic weighting. But, I do not believe that the issue was resolved absolutely fairly and squarely in the opinion to which I have referred. The matter of that balance is still open to discussion and I am sure in the ensuing months that discussion will continue and we will also have the benefit of being able to review not only the Hansard of this debate so far, but also other contributions that no doubt will be forwarded by the Parliamentary Joint Committee itself as a collective expression of its view as to the proper balance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Tate's opening comments. I did not want this to be an exchange of views, and in fact I do not have a view. I was just putting a position which I understood to be one that was tolerably acceptable. I continue to raise it because, as I understand it, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has made it clear that the Solicitor-General's opinion has been embraced and that is the official position. If that is the case, how does that impinge or impact upon other legislation such as the proposed Australian Sports Drug Agency Bill?

SPEECH.PARA: Although perhaps this is not the appropriate time to raise this matter now, to save me hopping up again I will do so: the Minister may be unaware of it but I have introduced a Bill to amend the Act; a declaratory amendment which provides beyond doubt that the Parliamentary Privileges Act will prevail in respect of section 51 of the National Crime Authority Act. That gives the Committee no greater powers or authority, because nothing in section 55 changes. It simply clears up that question. If the Committee trespasses outside its powers, that can be dealt with in a quite separate way.

I raise those two points: the fact that what I have suggested I would have hoped might be an acceptable position to the Government; and also I ask what implications there are for other legislation as a result of the opinion that the Solicitor-General has given. As the Minister says, he is not God. Perhaps I should precisely reflect what he said- `others may have written the opinion differently'-which implies that there might be two points of view. But on the basis that it has been adopted by the Government, what implications does it have for other legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have tried to indicate, I believe that the Solicitor-General was dealing with what turned out to be a much more narrow area of legal advice than was perhaps envisaged by Senator Crichton-Browne. Therefore, I believe that his opinion will have some impact on the question of the proper interpretation of other secrecy provisions, scattered as they are amongst hundreds of provisions to be found in many statutes of the Commonwealth. I believe that that general inquiry being undertaken by the Attorney-General's Department into the secrecy provisions right throughout the whole statute book will be assisted by the opinion of the Solicitor-General.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it will be only rarely definitive, I would think, because the fact is that there are not many instances where one has a parliamentary committee vested with statutory terms of authority and with a whole structure of secrecy and offence provisions set out in the statute itself in relation to the work of the parliamentary committee. I believe that the opinion will be useful, but it may not have a wide ranging impact on the way in which the Government reviews the operation of all the privacy provisions which have been undertaken.

TALK.START.PARA: —What brought on the review of the secrecy provisions?

—This has been a longstanding, much put off for questions of priority, project of the Attorney-General's Department simply because it is thought very important, as Senator Crichton-Browne would acknowledge in our sort of well functioning democracy, that a review be undertaken of those sorts of provisions to see that they are operating well to protect vital interests. This chamber is more conscious than almost any other chamber in the Western world, I would think, of the need to ensure that there is proper secrecy of matters held by government agencies in relation to citizens, residents and even transient visitors to Australia. There are many concerns which have to be addressed, and these have been approached in somewhat of a piecemeal fashion. The Government thought it was appropriate that a more comprehensive look at the way in which the secrecy provisions had grown up would be useful, and that is being undertaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mention is made at the end of the report of Estimates Committee E that the Committee thinks it appropriate that certain matters be at least open to further examination if people want to take this up. I have dealt with one this morning, which was the administration of the Family Court in Adelaide. The second was the funding and work of the National Crime Authority, due to public concerns about it. I think that the Committee did the right thing in making that recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) is no doubt aware, the operation of the National Crime Authority has been a matter of considerable public debate not only in the last couple of months but for a long time, particularly in my State of South Australia. It is appropriate for Parliament to provide opportunities to honourable senators who might be concerned about that to raise those concerns. If they choose not to do so, that is their business. As a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority, in the interests of speeding through the appropriations, I might have passed by the opportunity that recommendation 14 provides.

However, the Minister made some comments yesterday in Question Time that I want to link to that. I think this can be cleared up reasonably quickly. When responding to a question from Senator Faulkner about the National Crime Authority's published change in direction, the Minister said:

I think it would be useful if the Parliamentary Joint Committee considered, not so much raking over dying embers of past disputes, which I agree were matters of concern, but looking to the matters which will be canvassed by the National Crime Authority and investigated by it as it assembles admissible evidence in relation to major criminal activity in the future.

Two parts of the Minister's remarks concern me but I will deal with only one part today. The two parts I have identified are, first, the suggestion that any `dying embers', as the Minister put it, should be left and, secondly, his very positive view that the Committee will be able to work with the Authority as it assembles admissible evidence in relation to future matters. I am not sure just how much information the Minister thinks the Authority has ever given or will give to the Committee. I hope we can look to positive changes in that respect.

It is the first part of the Minister's remarks that cause me some concern, namely, the words `not so much raking over past embers of past disputes'. This Committee, as the Minister will be well aware, has tabled one report since I have been on it-that was in May-relating to the state of the Committee's knowledge of Operation Ark. As the Minister is probably no doubt aware, there was a bit of fuss over not so much that report but the dissenting report attached to it. That is the only matter of which I am aware that the Committee has had the opportunity-to paraphrase the Minister-to `rake over'. I could make a very good case that the Committee was not given adequate opportunity to rake that over. The full story on that is still not known. Can the Minister cast some light on what other past disputes exist that ought to be left alone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no intention of providing a check list of past activities of the National Crime Authority that could be investigated by the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority. I am sure that Senator Vanstone has many on her own little list somewhere that she is ticking off quietly. I was referring more generally to matters which had arisen, in particular, from relations with other law enforcement agencies and even within the National Crime Authority such as, for example, the way in which either lawyers or police officers were given greater prominence in particular investigative teams and were put in charge of particular inquiries.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that those sorts of matters of concern which, it was alleged, led to a lowering of morale and to territorial disputes and jealousies with other law enforcement agencies were very well dealt with by Mr Justice Phillips in his statement, endorsed by the intergovernmental committee of Ministers in Alice Springs last Friday, when he made it clear that every effort was to be made to secure a more collaborative, cooperative approach with other law enforcement agencies. This would extend to the lawful sharing of intelligence. It would also mean that, internally, there would be proper regard and respect for the various skills offered by police officers together with lawyers and those skills would be acknowledged. In those ways, I believe that remedies were foreshadowed, many of which will be put into operation by Mr Justice Phillips, for many of the matters which led to those sorts of concerns. No doubt Senator Vanstone has heard about those-I have read about them only in the press-in the public hearings of the Joint Committee in its general review.

I should have said in answer to Senator Crichton-Browne that it is the intention of the intergovernmental committee to put in a submission to the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. We hope that that will be a useful contribution to the Committee's deliberations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) for that answer. I share his view that the reputation of Justice Phillips precedes him. I have nothing but a positive approach to what will happen with the National Crime Authority in the future. My concern has been very much allayed by the Minister indicating that what he referred to was not what I thought it was and that in fact he was referring to the administrative problems that do not now need to be raked over if we can see a solution.

SPEECH.PARA: I make it clear that my view, as a consequence of the new Chairman's appointment, is nothing but positive. But I add that that does not encourage me to do two things. First, it does not encourage me to shut my eyes and think, `Now that we have got Justice Phillips we do not have to worry; we do not even need a joint parliamentary committee to oversee them'. I have no doubt that Justice Phillips is a good bloke, but there is a possibility of his being deified to such an extent that nobody bothers to cast a critical eye in the future at the National Crime Authority. That is not a mistake I intend to make if I can avoid it.

Secondly, the parliamentary Committee is charged with the task of overseeing the Authority. It does not do that on a day by day, month by month basis. It has to review the past. Can the Minister state that he and the Government is not in any way seeking to block the Committee from making an evaluation of the efficiency and effectiveness of the National Crime Authority, for example, up until the appointment of Justice Phillips? Otherwise, the Committee has nothing to do for six or twelve months. It is blocked by the Act from inquiring into current operational matters by the whole definition of its task to review-that is, look back-at what the National Crime Authority has done. That is one limitation.

The other limitation is the need to look at only past operational matters. I am very concerned that the Government is trying to block off an evaluation of the past efficiency and effectiveness of the National Crime Authority; that is, prior to the appointment of Justice Phillips. That would be a very bad thing. An enormous amount of taxpayers' money has been spent on this. If it has been wasted, the taxpayers are entitled to know. That is no reflection on what will happen in the future. If it has been wasted but the remedies have been found and we have a better chairman-or a man for the times, if one does not want to put it in terms of better or worse-and things look good for the future, well and good. But we do not say to the Department of Social Security, `Oh well, you have a new Minister, so we do not really care how you spent the money last year'. Parliament does not say that in a general sense to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Department of Defence or to any of those bodies, notwithstanding that a Committee is charged with the task of looking at what has happened.

The only blimp, if you like, that Parliament has heard from this Committee thus far is in relation to Operation Ark. There has been a lot more going on and a lot more money being spent, and what I am seeking to satisfy myself about so that I can allay concerns in the community as best as I am able is that the Government is not going to use every trick it can to block off looking at the past in this sense-and I quite like the Minister's wording-of `raking over dying embers of past disputes'. Albeit the Minister has clarified that he was not referring to what I am now referring to, I am still seeking an undertaking that the Government is not going to try to do that.

Committee members were very surprised to receive a letter which is now public knowledge. I cannot quite remember which newspaper I read it in; it was either the Australian or the Sydney Morning Herald-I do not think it was the Age. In any event, I read in a national daily that the Attorney-General had written to the Committee and suggested that it might not be a proper time to have an evaluation because we have a new chairman.

If one speaks to any person involved in the history of statutory authorities, that is what they all say- `Look, we have made a bit of a mess of this but we are cleaning it up now. We have a new chairman. We have a new board of directors, a new this, a new that, and a new name'. So why does the Minister not look at what has happened in the past? It is an appalling thing when so much of taxpayers' money has been spent. The past simply has to be looked at.

That letter suggested that it might not be an appropriate time to have an inquiry as to the past, and I cannot think when would be more appropriate. Why it would be more appropriate to inquire into the early years of the NCA 10 years from now, I am at a loss to imagine. Surely now is the time to look back to find out what problems there have been and to make an assessment of what changes need to be made. To the extent that Mr Justice Phillips has made them, well and good; and to the extent that he has not, perhaps such an evaluation will acquaint him with further opportunities for improving the situation of the National Crime Authority.

Let us not imagine for one minute that one announcement on 23 November is the panacea for all that might be wrong. I doubt that even Mr Justice Phillips would suggest that no more improvements could be made. I put it to the Minister that an evaluation of what has happened in the past may reveal other problems of an administrative nature, and that changes could be made within the NCA to make sure such problems did not arise again.

It is very embarrassing for a parliamentary committee to be told by the relevant State bodies that they are preparing a submission-even to be told, as I understand it, by some that the submission is ready-and then to receive a letter advising of an intergovernmental committee (IGC) decision that it is not really appropriate to have an inquiry now, that any of the bodies under the jurisdiction of this happy little band of men will not now be putting in a submission, but that the IGC will. So much for scrutiny by Parliament.

What we have been told effectively by the IGC, through the Attorney-General, is, `Look, Parliament, you can go and do something else with yourself other than the task you are charged with because we have sat together and we have decided it would be much better if it was done this other way'. That is most inappropriate, and I would be very pleased to hear from the Minister some explanation, such as there may be-I am at a loss to imagine what it will be-as to why, as I call them, a happy little bunch of men can get together and say to Parliament, `Go and do something else other than that with which you are charged'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can see that it is because the intergovernmental committee is composed of men that it has particularly roused the wrath of Senator Vanstone! Putting that sexist comment to one side, it is important to recall that this intergovernmental committee is not a committee of officials; it is a committee of Ministers, elected representatives of the people in their various jurisdictions, answerable to their parliaments, responsible to their parliaments, and with a very real political sense therefore of the necessity for the National Crime Authority to conduct itself in a way which is able to gather public confidence. As Mr Justice Phillips himself acknowledged recently, it is in the context of public confidence that it can best operate and we, as a committee of Ministers, intend to ensure that that democratic base for the operations of the National Crime Authority is maintained. Therefore, we are as interested as the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority in ensuring the efficient and honourable discharge by the National Crime Authority of its functions.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to make the point that we are both different groups of elected representatives of the Australian people with different duties conferred on us by the various sections of the National Crime Authority Act. But I am sure that the Federal Attorney-General, in writing to the Committee as chairman of the intergovernmental committee, was not trying to say to the Committee that it should not undertake a particular review. He was simply questioning the timeliness of the review. Indeed, since that time, as I mentioned to the honourable senator, there will be prepared by the intergovernmental committee-which means by the Ministers responsible to their parliaments-a submission that will be forwarded to the Joint Parliamentary Committee for its consideration and, I hope, its edification.

It is also important to point out that the Government recognises the role of the Joint Parliamentary Committee and its review function. I believe it is important that it be able to monitor and review the performance by the Authority of its functions and report to the Parliament in accordance with that monitoring and review function. I recall very well in the prelude to the 1987 election, I think it was, when I was Special Minister of State, that Senator Brian Archer, on behalf of the Opposition, kept on calling for the repeal of the sunset clause and I kept on saying no, it was not appropriate until the Joint Parliamentary Committee, for example, had conducted a review. In fact, the Joint Parliamentary Committee did so and concluded that the National Crime Authority had performed not merely adequately but in a way which allowed the Parliament to confidently repeal that particular sunset clause. That is an important point to note in the whole unfolding history of this parliamentary supervision of the National Crime Authority. It has already been undertaken in relation to the question of the sunset clauses being lifted.

The function of the Committee, or the duty of the Committee, to put it even higher perhaps and in accordance with the actual statutory provision in section 55, envisages not only this monitoring and review function but also, linked inextricably to it, reporting to the Parliament. The point I was making there was that that is in order to secure remedial action if it is required. What I was trying to say to Senator Crichton-Browne was that I believe in many ways a new directions paper endorsed by the intergovernmental committee in Alice Springs last Friday does not pre-empt the Joint Parliamentary Committee but indicates that many of the remedies which it would probably have suggested are already being put in place-and to that extent the type of review it might wish to undertake is probably not quite as necessary as if governments and the National Crime Authority itself had shown an unwillingness to remedy deficiencies as they were apparent to the Authority or to governments, quite apart from reports by the Joint Parliamentary Committee. So I think that section 55 is still an important section obviously in the National Crime Authority Act and the Government has no intention of trying to minimise the importance of that particular provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of remarks the Minister made occasion some concern. I appreciate what the Minister says about the intergovernmental committee (IGC) and its function, but nonetheless the course outlined is effectively to say to the parliamentary Committee, `Look, you could speak to a whole raft of people here, but we will act as a filter between you and them, and we will tell you what we have distilled as to what they would say'. To an extent, each State is entitled to do that with the bodies under its control, but I think it is regrettable.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not see why the IGC could not undertake its task and leave the Committee to undertake its task and speak to the people to whom it chooses to speak. I remind the Minister who primarily pays for the operation of the National Crime Authority (NCA). It is not the State Attorneys-General; I know it is in part, but not primarily. It is all very well for the State Attorneys-General to get together to have a bit of a chat about what ought happen in terms of a review, but they are not answerable to the taxpayers who are funding it. However, we in this place are, and it involves millions of dollars of taxpayers' money. I do not think it is appropriate for the State Attorneys-General to give hints to the Federal Parliament about whether it ought to bother inquiring into what has happened to money collected by the Commonwealth Government and primarily spent by it. In my view everything seems to be turned up the wrong way.

The second remark made by the Minister that caused me some concern is that the Committee has a reporting function that can alert Parliament to things of a remedial nature. By that I hope the Minister did not mean that that is the only occasion on which the Committee should report.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—I think I heard the Minister mutter, `No, I did not mean that', and that is a good thing. I will be very happy if that is the case. I will move on if I am mistaken in that respect.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be interested to hear the Minister's assessment of the performance indicators the public should use-and I assume the Committee can use the same ones-for the National Crime Authority. How should we judge whether it is doing a good job? I do not think we can judge that by whether the NCA has good or bad press. We all know what the media are like. The media are interested always in a bad story because it makes things more colourful. They do not necessarily want to write up the achievements. I understand that not all the achievements of the Authority can readily be made public at the time they are made because that might in some way prejudice following further criminal rabbits down holes, if one wants to use that analogy. What performance indicators does the Minister use to assess whether the Authority is achieving its set task?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a difficult problem which has exercised the minds of members of the Joint Committee. I recall that it was the subject of a report to Parliament by the Committee, perhaps at the time of the review of the sunset clause. The Committee in its report said-and I agree with it-that it would be simplistic simply to look at a scoreboard approach, at the number of arrests, charges, successful prosecutions, lengths of sentences and so on, because that cannot necessarily tell us the quality of the work being undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not mention names, but if a major figure, named and featured in various royal commission reports as a leader of organised criminal activity in Australia, who, through corruption of police commissioners and lesser officers, particularly in a certain jurisdiction, had evaded prosecution not just over decades but virtually over generations, were to be eventually successfully prosecuted by the National Crime Authority-even if not on a direct serious criminal charge but, for example, on a tax charge, which was the way in which the Federal Bureau of Investigation eventually dealt with Al Capone-that would be a significant victory. It would be a signal that major crime figures in Australia could be targeted successfully by the Authority and that their position was not beyond reach of law enforcement. That is, they would be prosecuted and sentenced and would serve out a gaol sentence in accordance with the term set by a judge.

In other words, it would point to a qualitative difference in the relationship between the community, as represented by its parliaments passing certain laws to create certain criminal offences and asking law enforcement agencies to enforce those laws on the one hand, and those engaged in organised criminal activity on the other. A very important signal was sent out by the National Crime Authority in relation to that by its successful prosecution of a particular crime figure. I know that Senator Vanstone knows to whom I am referring.

I am saying that a simple scoreboard approach will not suffice. On the other hand, the relationship with the various directors of public prosecutions is also very important and is a proper criterion to use. It is one thing for the National Crime Authority to say its task is simply to assemble admissible evidence and hand that over to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP), but it is quite clear that a close relationship needs to exist between the two, particularly in the final stages of the preparation of that admissible evidence. It is essential that cases do not fall for lack of credible evidence being brought before the magistrate at a committal proceeding or before a jury in a trial situation.

I believe that it is when magistrates or juries in particular throw out a charge brought on the basis of evidence assembled by the National Crime Authority that its reputation in the community suffers terribly. For example, the use of accomplices in particular criminal activity as witnesses needs to be dealt with extremely carefully by both the Authority and by the DPPs concerned.

I believe that a mature and sensible approach to that relationship with the DPPs will be extremely important, not only to the successful operation of the National Crime Authority in securing convictions, but also thereby in the standing that it has in the community. There is nothing more damaging than remarks made by magistrates which are aimed, quite properly in some instances, at the deficiencies in the relationship between the DPPs and the National Crime Authority in that regard. It is even worse when a major trial has been conducted for weeks or even months and the jury finds that a particular witness is so lacking in credibility that it does not convict the accused.

Those are some of the criteria which might be used, but it is not an easy matter. I am sure that the Joint Committee in its current review will pay great attention to the proper criteria and how they are met, or not met, by the Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer. I have one final question. What can the Government say to the South Australian public in particular about this?
—Keep voting for the Bannon Government.

— Apart from the Minister's suggestion that they should vote for the Bannon Government, what can the Government say to them in relation to the operation of the National Crime Authority (NCA) in that State? I realise the contribution made by the State Government in the running of the NCA in South Australia; nonetheless it is a Federal body. I am sure that the Minister is aware of the situation in South Australia where there is almost despair in the community in terms of what the Authority is doing in Adelaide. I was amazed to find in some reports recently that the Authority had been leasing offices in the same street as my office and had been watching for months someone in the office opposite the one it had leased. I have been trying to work out for weeks which office the NCA was watching. But that was all called off. I have not yet had the opportunity to make inquiries about that matter, but it is just another example of the sorts of reports we see in the Adelaide newspapers all the time-National Crime Authority bungle here, bungle there and bungle almost everywhere. Frankly, there is nothing to show for it in South Australia. Heaven knows what the NCA has been doing for the past 12 months. What does the Commonwealth Government have to say to the people of South Australia about the effectiveness of the Authority as it operates in that State?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My interjection was not entirely flippant because, as Senator Vanstone would know, the operations of the National Crime Authority to this point have been funded entirely by the South Australian Government. I believe that it is more properly the responsibility of that Government to answer to the South Australian public in relation to its operations within that jurisdiction. However, the Federal Government has indicated its intention that when the current inquiry so funded by the South Australian Government is concluded, it would want an office to be maintained by the National Crime Authority in Adelaide and a transition arrangement will need to be put in place to ensure that that is achieved successfully.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that Mr Greg Cusack, QC, one of the three members of the National Crime Authority, has taken as a top priority the task of concluding the South Australian investigation. He is a most experienced Queen's Counsel from Sydney, as Senator Vanstone will know. It is hoped that he will be able to achieve that by the end of this calendar year-I am not exactly sure, but I understand that that is the target date-and then the South Australian people will be able to make their judgment.

As to the operation, as reported in the press, where the National Crime Authority was apparently carrying out a surveillance in Senator Vanstone's street, I have to tell her that it was not keeping the premises opposite under surveillance-it was really looking at her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had wondered, because one reason given in the Adelaide Advertiser for part of this being a mess-up was that the office the Authority was looking at had stained coloured dark windows, which my office has. I am quite sure it was not looking at me.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister indicates, rightly, that the Bannon Government is paying for this, and perhaps questions should go to the State Government in that respect. If the Commonwealth Government is unwilling to comment on the up-to-now view of the effectiveness of the Authority in South Australia on the basis that it is not paying for it, so it should not worry, let me put the question to the Minister another way. The Minister has indicated that when the Adelaide office closes under Labor Government funding, his Government would like to see a National Crime Authority (NCA) office in Adelaide. On the basis of what the Government now knows about the conduct of that office in Adelaide, would it be happy to take over that office? In other words, has the Government made an assessment that the running of the NCA in South Australia is such that the Commonwealth would be happy to just shift in and take over?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The operation of the office in Adelaide will be structured, I imagine, quite differently from that which pertains at the moment. At present it is undertaking particular references given to it by the South Australian Government. Once those are concluded, the structure of the organisation will be required to carry out a more general role in accordance with such references that might be given either exclusively by the Commonwealth Government but touching on South Australia, by the South Australian Government exclusively, by both governments, or by a series of South Australian and other State or Territory governments. All that combination of possible references and activities will determine the way in which the South Australian permanent office-Federal office; national office, if you like; branch office of the National Crime Authority- will be set up. I have no doubt that Mr Justice Phillips has plans afoot as to the way in which that might be organised. But I am not privy to them and I am unable to elucidate further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Committee to the questions that I posed to Estimates Committee E on 13 September 1990 concerning the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. They are to be found at pages E15 to E18 of the Hansard. I also refer the Minister to answers to certain questions that were then taken on notice. Those questions refer to the possible use, ironically, of the Convention on the Rights of the Child by an international committee established to monitor how countries are observing the convention and the possibility of a provision in the convention for the purposes of promoting abortion in various countries.

SPEECH.PARA: At the Estimates Committee I referred to a provision in the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women-the CEDAW convention. Article 10, paragraph (h) in the Convention on the Rights of the Child relates to family planning services. That provision is quite similar to a provision in the CEDAW convention. Article 10, paragraph (h), states:

State Parties shall take all appropriate measures to eliminate discrimination against women in order to ensure to them equal rights with men in the field of education and in particular to ensure, on a basis of equality of men and women:
Access to specific educational information to help to ensure the health and well-being of families, including information and advice on family planning.
Article 12(1) refers to access to health care services, including those related to family planning. Article 16, paragraph (e), refers to the same rights as men, presumably, and states:
The same rights to decide freely and responsibly on the number and spacing of their children and to have access to the information, education and means to enable them to exercise these rights.
That is the CEDAW convention. Article 24, paragraph (1) in the Convention on the Rights of the Child, states:

State Parties recognise the right of the child to the enjoyment of the highest attainable standard of health and to facilities for the treatment of illness and rehabilitation of health. State Parties shall strive to ensure that no child is deprived of his or her right of access to such health care services.
It goes on:
State Parties shall pursue full implementation of this right and, in particular, shall take appropriate measures . . .
Article 24.2(f) states:
to develop preventive health care, guidance for parents and family planning education and services.

Here is a relatively similar provision to that contained in CEDAW. As I mentioned at the Estimates Committee hearing, the provision relating to the CEDAW Convention is being used by the monitoring committee to question countries about the provision of abortion services-and I quote its words; they are not mine. The Chair of the international monitoring committee for CEDAW is none other than Justice Elizabeth Evatt. I gave evidence to Estimates Committee E that the CEDAW committee is being used in such a way as to promote abortion on the basis of a similar provision as is contained now in the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

At Estimates Committee B I asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to explain why the United Nations (UN) committee established by the CEDAW Convention criticised countries with anti-abortion laws for their failure to comply with the articles of that Convention. I indicated then that no mention had been made of abortion in the CEDAW Convention, nor was any mention made of abortion in the travaux preparatoires relating to the articles in the CEDAW Convention, yet the evidence was that the committee is, in fact, questioning countries about their provision of abortion services.

Here is a danger that a similar committee, which is to be established under the Rights of the Child Convention, could use a similar provision in the Rights of the Child Convention to promote abortion. Is that not ironic? I asked the Minister about this and his response came back later. In Senate Estimates Committee E I raised this with Senator Tate and with a representative of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I asked whether the UN committee to monitor the Convention on the Rights of the Child would question countries on their provision of abortion facilities. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has responded by saying that the committee had not yet been established and its membership was not known. In his written reply he said:

The Convention provides for the establishment of a Committee on the Rights of the Child, to consist of experts in the field covered by the Convention to be elected by secret ballot of State Parties to the Convention. These experts will sit on the Committee in their personal capacities, not as representatives of the States of which they are nationals. They will have the task of developing an approach to monitoring the implementation of the Convention and their work will contribute to the development of international jurisprudence in this area. The first Committee has not been elected as yet; elections will be held by March 1991. All of these factors make it inappropriate to attempt to forecast or pre-empt the work of the Committee.

I want a guarantee from the Federal Attorney-General that there will be no way that a monitoring committee to be established under this Convention-that is, the Convention on the Rights of the Child-can promote abortions and thus destroy the lives of children in participating countries. I think it is fair for me to ask that because, again, I say that a similar provision in the CEDAW Convention is being used for that very purpose. Indeed, I referred the Estimates Committee to a statement made by Justice Elizabeth Evatt as reported by Associated Press in the international news database on 24 January 1990 as follows:
One of the most important issues that the committee takes up with states is their provision of family planning and abortion services for women, Evatt said.

I asked the Minister what Justice Elizabeth Evatt was on about. The response that has been received from the Attorney-General is that Justice Elizabeth Evatt denies having made that statement. I cannot find the response that was given but, in effect, from memory, that is what was indicated. I have here the computer print-out of the report from the international news database. Either the reporters are wrong or Justice Elizabeth Evatt is not telling us what she said.

One has to accept-having been given the response by the Attorney-General-the word of the Attorney-General and Justice Elizabeth Evatt, but that begs a question. Whether or not she actually said to the reporter what is contained in this document that is in my hand is really irrelevant. The question is: are Justice Elizabeth Evatt-as Chair of the inter- national monitoring committee for CEDAW-and the committee questioning countries about the provision of what they called abortion services in those particular countries? That is what I want to know. What, in fact, is she doing? What, in fact, is the committee doing? I refer the chamber to the information which I detailed to Estimates Committee E which showed that there is a record of this sort of inquisition about the abortion facilities of these countries taking place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —So many matters have been raised by Senator Harradine that it is difficult to know precisely what requires to be answered, except to say that, as far as the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) is concerned, it should be emphasised that the committee of which Justice Evatt is a member has no power whatsoever to give authoritative interpretations of the Convention. I believe that if it attempted to do so in the area which Senator Harradine has mentioned it would be going beyond its proper role.

SPEECH.PARA: In saying that, of course, I am not admitting that, indeed, that particular line of inquiry was undertaken in the way that has been attributed to Justice Evatt. I am unable to resolve the particular discrepancy between the apparent publication of her views and the clear answer which she has given to be conveyed to the Committee, except to say that I believe that she would be a truthful and honest person, given her high status, in denying that she made the remarks that have been attributed to her.

The fact is that article 24 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child makes it abundantly clear that article 24 (2) (f) is part of the implementation of the right mentioned in article 24 (1). That is, of course, concerned with recognising the right of the child to the enjoyment of the highest attainable standard of health, et cetera. It is within that context that article 24 would fall to be interpreted, if it ever required interpretation, by the states party to the Convention. The proper interpretation of that matter would therefore fall to Australia as a state party. I believe that there is no indication whatsoever in the travaux preparatoires, which have been examined by the Attorney-General's Department or the Foreign Affairs and Trade Department-in those basic documents which lead up to and form the foundation for this particular article-that they were in any way designed to allow the promotion of abortion under the guise of providing guidance for parents in relation to family planning education.

I simply believe that the role of the committee in relation to the CEDAW Convention has been overstated. I might say that in relation to article 10 of the CEDAW Convention, Senator Harradine already received the answer that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has been unable to find any interpretation suggested by the Committee or relevant aspects of article 10 in the material referred to by Senator Harradine or generally. The fact that members of the committee asked questions relating to abortion does not imply that any particular view has been adopted by the committee. In particular, the questions asked of the representative of Ecuador, to which Senator Harradine referred, do not presuppose any view of the circumstances in which abortion should be permissible. To our knowledge, the committee has not published any general comments or suggestions on this question.

I think that the role of the committee in relation to CEDAW has perhaps been overstated and perhaps misstated, if what Justice Evatt has indicated is the case in relation to the publication of her supposed views is in fact the case. In relation to article 24, I have here a note which might be of interest. As far as the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is concerned or is aware, there has been no suggestion in the travaux preparatoires for the Convention of the Rights of the Child of an interpretation of article 24, such as Senator Harradine has suggested. I think that is the important point. It is commented that the relevant portion of that article was proposed by the representative of Venezuela, a country with relatively restrictive abortion laws, and it is most unlikely that such an interpretation could have been envisaged. There is a reference to the United Nations documents which are relevant. I think that answer has been provided.

I think all that can be said is that as far as one can judge in the putting together of article 24 (2) (f), there appears to have been no intention on the part of the states parties to indicate that abortion services ought to be promoted as part of the fulfilment of the implementation of the right mentioned in article 24 (1). Indeed, it would seem on the surface to be incompatible. I believe that the matter is left to the understanding of the states parties such as Australia, and we have already made very clear our understanding of the Convention in so far as it relates to the question of abortion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate has given information which I already know about and which I have already stated. I object to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission regurgitating what I have already told it. The answer that Senator Tate gave me states blandly that the Commission has been unable to find any interpretation suggested by the committee of relevant aspects of article 10 in the material referred to by Senator Harradine or generally. I told him that, of course. There was no mention in the travaux preparatoires, in the CEDAW Convention as it relates to the three articles that I mentioned previously; no mention at all. Yet those articles are being relied upon by the monitoring committee to promote questions amongst states parties to the Convention as to the provision of abortion facilities in those States. That is the very point. They have been used by the CEDAW monitoring committee. What guarantee is there that a similar article in the Convention of the Rights of the Child will not be used in the same way? I agree with the Minister that these are separate but of course related questions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister mentioned the preamble to article 24 in the Convention of the Rights of the Child. If one has a look at the preamble to similar provisions in the CEDAW Convention, one would wonder how the CEDAW monitoring committee could possibly ask countries about the provision of abortion facilities in those countries. After all, the CEDAW Convention is all about the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women. Discrimination on what grounds? It is really about equality of rights of men and women. How could it possibly be interpreted so as to enable a monitoring committee to press countries to provide information about abortion services in those countries?

I ask the Minister: will he provide the committee with the minutes of discussions that have taken place by the CEDAW monitoring committee over the last 10 years so that we can test this matter and get it perfectly clear? Will he ask Justice Elizabeth Evatt whether she considers that one of the most important issues that the CEDAW monitoring committee takes up with states is their provision of abortion services? Will he ask whether she consider that it is appropriate for the monitoring committee to ask countries about the provision of abortion services for women? I would like to have that response so that we can get perfectly clear where we are at in respect of that committee and the provisions of the CEDAW Convention where they are similar to the provisions of the Rights of the Child Convention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has more accurately stated-if in fact it proves to be the case that any of these questions relating to abortion facilities were raised in the way that it has been put-that the committee was promoting questions concerning abortion facilities. That is quite different from my understanding of the earlier thrust of his assertions: that the committee relating to the CEDAW Convention was promoting the provision of abortion facilities. If it was asking or promoting questions about abortion facilities, it may still be that they are beyond the scope of the committee on a proper interpretation of article 10 of the Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: It has to be recognised that the committee asks questions in relation to reports submitted by states parties. I am unable to say at the moment whether the question of abortion facilities was mentioned in any of those reports, and that might give ground for the sorts of questions that have been put rather than the promotion of the provision of abortion facilities being the purport of any questioning undertaken by members of the committee. On that matter I think I might take a punt and say that the charter for the committee to be established in relation to the Convention on the Rights of the Child is in article 43.2, which says:
The Committee shall consist of ten experts of high moral standing and recognized competence in the field covered by this Convention.

I believe that the field covered by the Convention is, in a sense, of an important limiting character. As abortion was a matter not dealt with precisely by the states parties in drawing up the Convention, if I was appearing before the committee and asked a question about the provision of abortion facilities, I would say that it is not the field covered by this Convention. I would deal with the matter in that way.

In regard to Senator Harradine's particular questions as to providing the minutes of the CEDAW Committee going back some 10 years, I will ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) whether in fact he has a means by which the minutes can be made available to Senator Harradine. I think it would be his responsibility. I do not imagine that it would be impossible to provide.

Regarding Senator Harradine's second question asking me to relay certain questions to Justice Evatt, of course I can relay them, but I should say that, in her capacity, status or function as a member of the committee of the CEDAW Convention relating to the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women, she is there in a personal capacity and not as a member of any agency of the Federal Government. In that respect, I take it that her appointment to that committee comes from the United Nations and that the secretariat of that committee would fund her participation in that committee's work. As I say, she is a member of the committee in a personal capacity and, therefore, it may well be that she declines to give an answer. Of course, she would not be responsible to any Australian Minister for the way in which she conducts herself on that particular Committee, but I will forward the questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —During her absence on committee work, is she paid by the Australian Law Reform Commission?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to give an answer to that. I will try to see whether there is a provision which states that she is on recreation leave, on leave without pay or whether she has some other status while she is undertaking this particular committee work. I will endeavour to find an answer for Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to a question put by me on 7 November, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) said:

SPEECH.PARA: I anticipate that when the Australian Government ratifies the convention, should it do so, one would find that those same understandings as to the pre-eminent role of the family would be acknowledged. It would be surprising were that not the case, given the fact that Australia inserted article 5, meaning that for the first time in the international community a document was open to ratification which recognised that pre-eminent role of the family, parents or legal guardians in giving guidance and direction to children in accordance with their evolving capacities.

That was an answer to a question that I raised with the Minister. I referred to a previous question by Senator Childs. The answer Senator Tate gave to that question was that the Holy See and a number of others had backed the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. I asked whether it was really fair for the Government to continue saying that the Holy See had actually backed the Convention when the Holy See, in acceding to the Convention, made several reservations.

One reservation was in respect of the interpretation of the issue of the rights of the child before as well as after birth and the rights of the child to protection before as well as after birth. Another reservation related to the rights of the primary and unalienable rights of parents, in particular in so far as these rights concern education, religion, association with others and privacy. It was to the latter-that is, to the rights of the parents-that the Minister was referring when he indicated that he anticipated that, when the Australian Government ratifies the Convention, one would find that those same understandings as to the pre-eminent role of the family would be acknowledged. Is this currently the case?

Secondly, the Minister mentions that Australia inserted article 5. I must have a different copy of the travaux preparatoires to the Minister, but I have had a look at the part of the travaux which is the report of the working group on the draft Convention on the Rights of the Child, and I would be grateful if he could indicate whether there is some other document which establishes that Australia in fact inserted article 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to article 5, my clear understanding is that it was indeed the Australian delegation which kept pressing for some such recognition as finds its expression in article 5, and was indeed the leading catalyst in the various discussions and deliberations which took place as the Convention reached its concluding stages. I do not know what is exactly in the travaux preparatoires in relation to article 5, but I am advised very firmly that Australia played an instigating role in the insertion of that particular article. It is because it is such an important and innovative article that Australia takes such pride in it.

SPEECH.PARA: As to whether it ought to form the text of an accompanying declaration upon the ratification of the Convention, the Government, on reflection, having considered that possibility, is now of the view that that might detract from the single, clear statement of article 5 in that, not by way of reservation but by way of declaration, one would merely be trying to repeat, perhaps in some sort of paraphrase, the effect of article 5. It is thought that it would be better to leave article 5 unadorned, but highlighted in any accompanying statement made by the Government on the ratification. But as to a formal declaration of article 5, it would be purely affirming language. In so far as it was even modestly or minutely different from the actual wording of article 5, it might be taken in some way to query whether article 5 was as strong as we certainly affirm that it is. It is important to perhaps read article 5 in full:
States Parties-
that is, international governments-

shall respect the responsibilities, rights and duties of parents or, where applicable, the members of the extended family or community as provided for by local custom, legal guardians or other persons legally responsible for the child, to provide, in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child, appropriate direction and guidance in the exercise by the child of the rights recognized in the present Convention.

That is an extremely important recognition- I believe the first in an international convention-of the way in which parents have a role, rights and duties recognised and respected by state parties to these international conventions. That will certainly be highlighted in any statement from the Australian Government which accompanies its ratification of this particular Convention but which will not form an accompanying declaration in the very formal sense of the law of treaties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I know that you would not permit a debate on the Convention, but I would like to debate the latter statement of Senator Tate by giving him reference to certain other articles which do appear, by their constant repetition, to diminish those rights in certain ways. One wonders why the Holy See decided that there should be reservations. Presumably it considered it important to have an international focus to overcome the very disconcerting treatment that is meted out to children in a number of countries. I have said on a number of occasions as well that an international convention is an important area. It ought to be on the record that the Convention on the Rights of the Child was born out of the desire to eradicate the exploitation of children in those countries where children are treated as chattels. There does need to be an international focus for these efforts and the Convention may well provide this.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of my reservations, however, I indicated that there is a danger that articles of the Convention could be misinterpreted by some social engineers, both at home and abroad, and particularly in the United Nations Monitoring Committee, unless the Federal Government does take appropriate action and makes reservations on the articles of the Convention about which valid concerns have been raised. I was interested to note that Senator Tate, in answer to the question, indicated that `one would find that those same understandings as to the pre-eminent role of the family would be acknowledged'-and that at the time of ratification. Now it appears that the Attorney-General does not believe that and Senator Tate has indicated that he feels it might be a watering down.

I believe it is a strengthening of the situation and we need to have some clear indication by the Government as to the protection of parental rights and the need for protection of the unborn child as well. Mr Temporary Chairman, I am sorry: I am probably debating the issue now, and I will not do that. But in respect of parental rights and article 5, the parts of the traveaux preparatoires which I have in my hand do not indicate that it was Australia that initiated article 5. I do not discount what the Minister is saying. For the completeness of my file on this subject, which goes back to 1980, I would like to have there an indication that Australia did take the leading role in this area. It is important for the completeness of my file and for the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew that you were leading inexorably to a question. That is why I allowed you to debate the issue.
—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will undertake to provide such evidence of the claim as can be provided for Senator Harradine's file and for the edification of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one other question I want to ask within the Attorney-General's portfolio. I raise this matter because it is important to get on the record some of the comments that have been made in responses to questions that I asked at the Estimates Committee. I refer to questions that I asked of the Institute of Criminology. It will be recalled that in the Estimates Committee hearing on 13 September I raised a number of questions with the Institute of Criminology officials. I referred to the report of the Committee on Violence. Without going over it-and I know I would not be permitted to go over the questions I asked in Estimates Committee E-I do want to refer now to a response that was given to one of those questions.

SPEECH.PARA: My questions were related to the report of the National Committee on Violence Violence: Directions for Australia. I had raised quite a series of questions as to what time was used by the Committee on Violence to discuss the question of the likely effect that hard-core pornography would have on its viewers and on the development of callous or violent attitudes amongst its viewers.

The responses that I was given indicated that the Committee spent very little time indeed-in fact, hardly any time-on this issue. I asked how long the National Committee on Violence had spent examining the harmful effects of videos in reinforcing or framing various attitudes. That is a precis of a question that I asked. The answer that has now been given to me on notice is as follows:
Although it is not possible to respond to this question in terms of hours spent on the topic, it can be said that the issue was raised at several of the Committee's seven meetings.
The issue was raised at several of the Committee's seven meetings! It continued:
However, it was the view of all but one Committee member that because of the breadth of the Terms of Reference, this was not an issue which the Committee was able to debate at length.

Yet I point out to the Committee that the vote at the House of Assembly in the Australian Capital Territory to ban this type of video material-that is, hard-core porn-was lost by one vote. That was the vote of Mr Collaery, the Attorney-General. Mr Collaery placed a great deal of emphasis on the report of the National Committee on Violence. He quoted the National Committee on Violence in support of his vote.

Here we have an admission by the National Committee on Violence and by the Australian Institute of Criminology, which provided the secretarial backup for that National Committee, that it was the view of all but one member of the Committee that, because of the breadth of terms of reference, this was not an issue which the Committee was able to debate at length. Anybody who knows the situation knows that there was a very brief time devoted to this matter-an extraordinarily brief time. The response went on:
The one member not of that opinion-
that is to say, the member who believed that proper consideration should be given to the possible development of a violent mentality as a result of the viewing of this material-
Mr Peter Quinn, resolved his position by submitting a minority report on the subject, which is found at pages 252 to 259 of the Committee's Report.

I also raise the question as to why the Committee said in its report that I had referred to research which purported to demonstrate the adverse effects of non-violent erotica. I did not use that term at all. The Committee on Violence is supposed to have its facts correct. I did not use the term `non-violent erotica `.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never.

—No, because it is a term that cannot be used for the material which is officially described in the explanatory memorandum to the previous ordinance, which is now the legislation, as hard-core pornography. The Institute of Criminology, which was giving the backup to the Committee on Violence, chose to put words in my mouth which I did not use. When I asked why it did that, the answer was this:

SPEECH.PARA: The term was used in reference to research discussed in the Report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. It was used to distinguish between violent and non-violent sexual material in the context of their differential effect on the viewer's response in terms of violent behaviour.

I think that is a disgrace. I think it shows a lack of awareness of the issues that are involved. It also shows a degree of ignorance about the work of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. The fact is that we were discussing material which is described officially, as I indicated, in the Federal Government's explanatory memorandum as hard-core pornography, not non-violent erotica.

In the words of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, it treats women `as sexual commodities to arouse the sexual desires of its target audience and reduces persons to objects or occasions of sexual pleasure'. This material is exploitative and degrading. Although physically non-violent, it cannot be labelled or described in the manner that the Institute of Criminology and, through it, the Committee on Violence have done without violating the true meaning of the words that they used.

Evidence cited by the Joint Select Committee majority shows that such material engenders a sexually calloused and manipulative orientation towards women. It was interesting to note that at least four of the behavioural scientists whose research was submitted to the Committee saw this non-violent hard-core pornography as being more harmful in this regard than even the violent, explicit pornography which is already banned.

I invite honourable senators to look at what is contained in the transcript of the meeting of Estimates Committee E on 13 September and the admissions that are recorded there, and then to judge whether one can take any notice at all of the statement or the assertions made in the report of the Committee on Violence.

I would not have taken the time of the Committee, except that that report was used quite innocently by the AttorneyGeneral in the Australian Capital Territory. He thought the report was well researched-in this instance it was not and has proven not to be-and it was referred to by him in support of his decision to oppose the banning of this material.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I refer to a reservation that I made to the report of Estimates Committee E. That reservation relates to aspects of investigations and prosecutions under the War Crimes Act. No-one in our society can do anything but recoil in horror at the thought of the genocide that occurred during the Second World War. The horror of what we have been told about human beings engaging in the mass slaughter of other human beings just seems to be too much for us to accept and comprehend in this day and age. It is fortunately an era which was before my generation but it is one which, particularly in recent years, has more and more come to light. We should never forget the horror and the bestiality of mankind during those times.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose the Second World War has had its counterparts during my generation but these conflicts have not been on quite the same scale. In more recent times we have heard of genocide in Ethiopia and on the Horn of Africa. In South Africa at the moment there are allegations of one black tribe slaughtering another black tribe. We have heard stories of mass killings in Iran and Iraq for no reason apart from ethnic origin and background. A lot of these things are as horrific, I suppose, but they are not on the same scale as what took place in World War II. So nothing should ever be done which in any way lessens the horror with which we treat war crimes which were committed during the Second World War.

I simply want to raise again whether this nation should be spending the sort of money it is using to pursue alleged war criminals so long after the event. My understanding from the figures given to Estimates Committee is that something like $16m has been spent to date on war crimes proceedings, references and investigations under the War Crimes Act. That seems to me to be an extraordinary amount of money in view of the results that have been achieved from those investigations.

We are in a time of economic crisis. The world and this nation currently face an enormous number of problems. Many people in this country are currently living in desperate poverty and absolute distress and yet we have spent what seems to me to be an inordinate amount of money in pursuing war crimes prosecutions with no real result.

As I understand it-and maybe the Minister will be able to elaborate if things have progressed since the Estimates Committee hearings-one person has been charged and there is a possibility of two or three others being charged. That seems to be the end of it. I repeat that if there are guilty people in Australia now, we should spend the money to prosecute them. But it has always seemed to me that the investigation of war crimes, under the Act, was doomed to failure from the start. The problems of prosecuting an offence so long after it was committed are horrendous and should have been seen as such. It does seem to me that the money has not been wisely spent in the programs under this War Crimes Act.

I wonder whether the Minister might indicate just how much longer action is going to be taken under the War Crimes Act; how much longer the special investigations unit is likely to continue; what the costs are likely to be in the future; and what possibility there is of any convictions or further charges being laid as a result of the expenditure of this enormous amount of money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, it will be apparent to the Committee that the question of the war crimes prosecutions very much depends on a decision to be taken by the High Court of Australia. The High Court has reserved its decision and the whole question of the constitutional validity of that legislation is now being determined by the justices. I guess that will be quite a long deliberative process by them, and I would not imagine that we would get an answer before the end of this calendar year. So I would say that we are some way away from knowing whether in fact there is a firm constitutional basis for this whole edifice constructed on the basis of legislation passed through this Parliament to deal with war crimes of the horrific nature which Senator Macdonald has acknowledged.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the actual expenditure, I believe the honourable senator said something about $16m having been spent. I have figures before me which indicate-and these are only brief notes from the officers available to me-that the total expenditure on the special investigations unit (SIU) has been $3,798,539 as at the end of August; on legal aid, some $332,722; and on the Department of Public Prosecutions, some $404,938. So, to that extent, it falls somewhat short of the $16m that the honourable senator mentioned-in fact, about $12m short. As to the question of the length of time that the SIU might take to complete its investigations, I am advised that that might be towards the end of the next financial year- 1991-92.

Finally, the honourable senator asked what were the prospects of success for the prosecutions. That cannot be answered, except to say this: this Parliament and this Senate in particular were very adamant that the same rules which apply to the trial of any accused person in the Australian criminal justice system be applied in this particular instance.
