In particular, that casts an obligation not only on the court process but I believe on the Director of Public Prosecutions to apply stringently the published rules relating to his prosecution policy-I believe in this instance with a particular stringency because, naturally, one would not wish to subject a person to the situation of being an accused and, therefore, being submitted to a committal proceeding and/or trial without having a strong case.

So I believe that the honourable senator can rest assured that the usual rules relating to prosecution policies will be stringently applied and that there will be the fairness and impartiality of our courts, supervised by the judges to ensure that there is no abuse of process-of course, this clause was written into the Bill and modified at various times as it progressed through the Senate.

Ultimately, the foundation of our criminal justice system, namely, the capacity of a jury to make decisions as to questions of fact involved in the alleged criminal offence, will be the safeguards which will ensure that such prosecutions as are undertaken will be successful only if 12 members of the Australian public selected in the normal way are convinced that the crime alleged actually did occur. I believe that is the fundamental safeguard in ensuring that these prosecutions, if they succeed, will succeed because they deserve to succeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not suppose it achieves much by being pedantic on the figures, but in the Estimates Committee hearings I did add them up and come to a total figure on all costs associated with these things, including legal aid and the Special Investigations Unit, of $16m. I suggest to the Minister that that was acknowledged by Mr Greenwood when I put to him that it cost $16m to get one person to court. He said, `No; to get this one person to court plus four others'. Whilst he objected to my counting of the numbers that might get to court he seemed to accept that, all in, something like $16m had been spent. If the Minister would like to look at page E76 of the Estimates Committee transcript, he will see the figures $9.5m plus $4.4m plus $3.9m, and in round figures that is $16m. I wonder whether the Minister might elaborate for me, some two months later, whether there has been any progress in getting the other four to court. I accept that there are sensitivities, that he cannot identify them or cannot be specific, but I would like to know how we are going in getting those four others to court and whether there is now any likelihood of anyone else being charged. Are those four cases the end of the matter? Will the whole process wind up after that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a quick look at page E76 of the transcript. All I can say is that I think there may be slight confusion as to the money appropriated as opposed to the money spent. I think it was even explained during the Estimates Committee hearing that the appropriation was in anticipation of certain trials getting under way, and legal aid of a very large amount being required in relation to those trials. Of course, the prosecutions of four or five cases have not been undertaken and cannot conceivably be undertaken in this financial year. I think that is the difference: I was talking about money spent; Senator Macdonald was really speaking about money appropriated.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the question of the other three or four cases and how they are progressing, I have no further information that I can usefully convey to the Committee. Quite clearly, there is something of a hiatus in the consideration of whether these matters can be brought forward, as we await the High Court's reserved decision. Nevertheless, I have no doubt that Mr Greenwood and Mr Weinberg are carrying on conversations about the readiness of particular matters to be handed to Mr Weinberg, but I have no further information for the Committee on the actual state of those three or four other cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister indicate how many people on the Commonwealth Government payroll are involved in these war crimes prosecutions and investigation?

—That is an ideal question for the Estimates Committee when it is meeting as an Estimates committee. I will have to take that on notice and provide Senator Macdonald with an answer. Clearly, it would cover personnel in the Special Investigations Unit and the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions. It would not cover legal aid; that would be only incidental. We will try to put some figures together.
—What is going to happen to those people who are specifically on that project once the project winds down?

—We do not know whether that will be early next year or four or five years hence. It is very difficult to say, except that quite clearly the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) personnel will be available to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions for other duties. As far as the Special Investigations Unit is concerned, clearly that has been formed for a specific task. It comprises persons seconded from other organisations and I think they would probably go back to those organisations. Other persons with individual personal expertise, for example, in relation to historical research, language expertise and so on, would go on to other employment in their careers. In other words, a lot of them were not transferred from other Commonwealth departmental duties. It is a bit hard to say exactly what will happen to all the personnel, except that the DPP's people will certainly go back to other duties within the DPP's office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My questions relate to my reservation which was with regard to the start-up date and various matters relating to the resourcing of the Australian Securities Commission in Western Australia. As the Minister knows, I have pursued this matter more than any other since I have been in the Parliament in the past six months, and I have raised with him a number of concerns I have had about the start-up date and how achievable it is, particularly in Western Australia. I have also raised matters of concern about the company number. A lot of the agitation that I caused led to the Government announcing some 10 days ago that there would be a moratorium on prosecuting people who did not comply with that particular part of the new legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening I want to run through matters that were discussed at the Estimates Committee hearings where the answers were incorrect, inadequate or just downright wrong and in some cases misleading. The position now in Western Australia is that the Attorney-General, Joe Berinson, in introducing the legislation in the Legislative Council in Western Australia-I think it was last Thursday-has now agreed with my proposition that it is impossible to have the Australian Securities Commission up and running in Western Australia prior to about March.

The assertions that I have made in the Senate during Question Time and at other times is that the office in Perth has no staff at this stage; that no offers have been made to Corporate Affairs Commission staff at the State level; and that the computer system is far from being at a stage where it could be expected to be operating by 1 January. The training of staff to use the new computer system actually commenced when one person was sent to Sydney to start training. When that person got to Sydney the computer system was in a state which did not allow that training to continue. That particular person, I believe, was going to be used to train some of the staff who have yet to be recruited in Western Australia. He has not been trained, so I doubt whether he is in a position to train the staff in Western Australia.

These are issues that I raised during Estimates Committee hearings in September. Broadly speaking, I was given assurances that the staff were being recruited and that they would all be recruited by 1 January; that the computer system would be set up in plenty of time for 1 January; and that the very existence of the company number-or the corporate ID card, as I like to call it-had been advised to professional groups in Western Australia and around Australia. That was the way in which the Australian Securities Commission intended informing the business community of the need to print this company number on all of its public documents, cheques, et cetera.

A number of months after that, by making inquiries of a range of accounting practices around Perth, from the very large organisations and the medium sized accounting firms to even one-and two-man accounting practices, I found out that not one of them had any idea of this simple requirement to have a company number. I was told only 10 or 11 days ago that inquiries made to a hot line set up to solve this problem-I believe it is called the Australian Securities Commission hot line-could not even help people by telling them where this company number would appear.

I have asked the Minister in the Senate about the cost-that is, the cost of printing these eight-or nine-digit numbers on people's public documents, cheques and company seals-of complying with just this small part of the legislative package. I was told in Question Time that the cost of compliance would be negligible. I think I have said on other occasions that if we estimate the cost at only $100 for each company and multiply that by 800,000 companies, we start getting into some pretty big numbers. This is a cost with which small business people do not really need to be burdened during these harsh economic times.

With that preamble, I will now move through some of the specific matters which have not been resolved since the Estimates. One of those is the question of whether there was any contingency plan if the Australian Securities Commission were not able to be set up by 1 January. The Western Australian Attorney-General, Mr Berinson, has now publicly said that he does not think it at all possible that the Australian Securities Commission will be up and running in Western Australia by that date.

During the Estimates hearings I was told that there were no contingency plans because this 1 January start-up date was absolutely imperative. Obviously it was decided not to have a contingency plan because it was thought that 1 January was totally achievable. I remind the Minister that the Australian Securities Commission in Western Australia has committed itself to leasing about 4,500 square metres of space at 66 St Georges Terrace. At this stage the plan is to fit out only one of the floors, possibly prior to 1 January, and to fit out the remainder of the floors possibly, if we are lucky, by March or April 1991. Clearly, one of the questions I would like answered today is how will the Government reassure the business community of Western Australia that continuity of service will be provided to it-continuity in prosecution and investigation and continuity in the general watchdog role of the new corporations scheme-when it has a dying Corporate Affairs Commission and an Australian Securities Commission which it seems logistically cannot be set up by 1 January.

The only announcement I have seen of the moratorium on the prosecutions for not using the new company number indicated a period of six months. I am not aware of any other announcement; there may have been. I believe that Ron Edwards discussed the matter during the second reading debate in the House of Representatives. I ask the Minister: in view of the assurances I was given by Australian Securities Commission people about their publicity campaign to make the business community aware of the company number-a publicity campaign that either was not happening or was extremely ineffective-what will be done to inform the business community of this moratorium? Can the Minister also tell me whether the moratorium applies to the implementation of the company number on all of the places and documents it is required by the legislation to be put onto, or does it exclude the company seal?

While the Minister is talking on that issue, can he also inform the Committee what has been done in the light of clear public perception to inform companies that they have to have this company number on their company seals prior to 1 January, if that moratorium does not apply to that company seal? If 800,000 companies have to run down to the rubber stamp shop between now and Christmas to get their stamps made, during my holidays I might go and set up a rubber stamp shop.

The other issue that was not answered in the Estimates Committee, and I do not believe I have been informed of subsequently, concerns the result of the Remuneration Tribunal's determinations about the salaries and remuneration of the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission.

Some other issues I would like to raise relate to an answer I was given by Mr Robinson at the Estimates Committee, which said that a consultative committee was being set up to look at all the issues relating to service levels in Western Australia. He said that the Corporate Affairs Commission in Western Australia was looking at some of the measures of service level that could be provided and some form of guaranteeing or putting those guarantees into an agreement that I believe will be annexed to the legislation after it has passed through this place, I guess.

My understanding is that the major group concerned with this matter in Western Australia, WAOG, or the Western Australia Opposition Group, which represents the Law Society of Western Australia, the Confederation of Western Australian Industry, the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Chamber of Mines of Western Australia (Inc), the Stock Exchange, the Western Australian branch of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia, the Western Australian branch of the Institute of Directors in Australia, the Western Australian Council of Trustee Companies Association and the Western Australian branch of the International Association for Financial Planning, has not been consulted one iota on this matter since September or even before that. Indeed, it put a very detailed letter to the Chairman, Mr Hartnell , on 8 June, which until about 6 o'clock eastern standard summer time last night had not been replied to. This letter was from the Chairman of that group, Mr Laurie Shervington, setting out a long list of concerns the group had, mostly recognising the inevitability of the new national scheme and hopefully providing some input to the Australian Securities Commission and to Mr Hartnell in particular as to how some guarantees about the service levels to the business community in Western Australia may be made.

If the assurances I was given at the Estimates committee hearings about encouraging the compliance of the business community with this new scheme are to be believed, I would have thought that some form of consultation with a group such as the Western Australia Opposition Group would have been desirable. That consultation has simply not taken place. I believe that the only discussion was at a cocktail party that Mr Hartnell attended in Perth some months ago, but there has been no formal consultation. Indeed, the entire process of consultation or public discussion about the formation of the Australian Securities Commission since the agreement was reached in Alice Springs five or six months ago has been non-existent. It seems that some boffins have been sitting around some rooms negotiating this legislative package, trying to figure out how they can get this new scheme up and running by 1 January and trying to keep it as quiet as possible because as each day goes by, we see a disaster looming. This disaster has been approaching for some three years.

I also raised the issue of the staffing levels and the recruitment program in Western Australia. I would like that addressed. If it is the case that recruiting of staff for Perth is on track and under way and will be completed on time-that was the assurance given at Estimates committees-why is there still no staff in Perth, except for I think one gentleman? Why has a director not been appointed in Perth? How the hell does the Government hope to get this up and running when it has no director, no staff, no computers and no office?

Could the Minister also explain to me the point I raised about the Senior Executive Service (SES) profile for the office in Perth? There are significant concerns in the Perth business community that the general level of professional competence within the regional offices will be much lower than exists in the Corporate Affairs Commission in Western Australia at the moment. This SES profile matter is a matter of some concern to my constituents. I will raise other matters once the Minister has had a chance to deal with that, if that is appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Campbell for his questions. It is true that Senator Campbell, since entering the Senate, has taken a particular interest in this matter, and to some extent his concerns have been justified. I say that because I have certainly answered him on several occasions in regard to the Australian company number (ACN) in a way which was more confident than the facts have allowed to transpire. As a result, the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) has announced that there will be a moratorium on the requirements that companies display their Australian company number on their business documents and eligible negotiable instruments. As has been noted, the moratorium will be for a period of six months from the commencement of the new national companies scheme, which is due to come into effect on 1 January, 1991. I will comment on that date later.

SPEECH.PARA: But to elaborate on some further questions Senator Campbell asked about that Australian company number moratorium, the six month period of grace will not apply to a company's requirement to display its ACN on its common seal, nor on any document it will by law be required to lodge with the ASC. Companies will be required to display their ACN on their common seal and on all documents required to be lodged with the ASC under the corporations law from the commencement of the new national companies scheme. But during the period of the moratorium companies need not display their common seal on other documents.
A media release has been put out which makes that clear. I do not know whether Senator Campbell has had an opportunity to see that. Perhaps I could seek leave to incorporate that in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
National Companies and Securities Commission
Media Release
From: The Office of the Chairman
Date: Thursday 15 November 1990
AUSTRALIAN COMPANY NUMBER

The Australian Securities Commission (ASC) today announced there will be a moratorium on the requirements (under s.219 Corporations Act) that companies display their Australian Company Number (ACN) on their business documents and eligible negotiable instruments.
The moratorium will be for a period of six months from the commencement of the new national companies scheme, which is due to come into operation on 1 January 1991.
The six month period of grace, however, will not apply to a company's requirement to display its ACN on its common seal nor on any document it will by law be required to lodge with the ASC.

Companies will be required to display their ACN on their common seal and on all documents required to be lodged with the ASC under the Corporations Law from the commencement of the new national companies scheme.
The ACN is a unique nine digit identifying number for each Australian company.
Under the Corporations Law, a company will be required to display its name, followed by the expression ``Australian Company Number'' (or a permitted abbreviation such as ``A.C.N'') and its ACN on
its common seal (s.219 (1) Corporations Act)
every public document that is signed, issued or published (s.219 (3) Corporations Act)
every eligible negotiable instrument that is signed or issued (s.219 (3) Corporations Act)
During the moratorium, the ASC will not be enforcing the requirements of s.219 (3) of the Corporations Act.

The period of grace will also apply to the requirements (under s.362 (4) Corporations Act) for foreign companies and other registrable bodies to display their Australian Registered Body Number (ARBN) on their public documents and eligible negotiable instruments.
During the moratorium, the ASC will not be enforcing the requirements of s.362 (4) of the Corporations Act.

ASC Chairman, Tony Hartnell, said the ASC will be commencing a major information campaign immediately following the enactment of the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 currently before the Australian Parliament.

``The period of grace and the ASC's information campaign will give companies some breathing space in which to become thoroughly conversant with all the requirements for displaying their ACN or ARBN under the new legislation,'' Mr Hartnell explained.
Mr Hartnell said: ``Companies will be able to utilise the moratorium period to take care of their new stationery requirements with the minimum of cost and inconvenience.''
``This moratorium has been decided upon by the ASC after consultation with and the full agreement of the Federal Attorney-General, Michael Duffy,'' Mr Hartnell said.
Issued by:
Jan Comley
Manager Corporate Relations
Australian Securities Commission

The question about the 1 January start up, particularly given West Australian concerns both of a logistic kind and in relation to the level of service that might be provided, is one that I think will be happily resolved. My confidence in saying that, although it is somewhat undermined by the experience of the Australian company number matter, lies in the fact that the Attorney-General of Western Australia has been perhaps the strongest advocate of the need for a proper level of service to be available to businesses trading and carrying on their legitimate activities in the regions of Australia away from the south east of the mainland. For him to introduce the legislation into the West Australian upper House, I think last week, indicates, I believe, that his concerns have been met and that he can confidently advocate the passage of that particular legislation. So I think that that is very reassuring.

The 1 January deadline is not an easy one to meet, but if I may go to some of the particular logistics which Senator Campbell raised, it is true that the ASC's new accommodation in Perth will not be ready, on latest advice, until the end of January. However, the ASC has made arrangements with the West Australian Government so that the ASC will use the existing West Australian Corporate Affairs Commission office accommodation until the staff move over to the new ASC office. In this way, neither the West Australian business community nor the staff will be unnecessarily inconvenienced and an appropriate level of service to the West Australian community will be maintained. I understand that the recruitment of new staff and the transfer of existing staff is in train for a 1 January commencement.

I believe Senator Campbell regards the appointment of a regional commissioner as being particularly important. The ASC expects to be in a position to announce the appointment of all new regional commissioners by the first week in December. Honourable senators may know that a committee of interview has been established and that interviews have recently been undertaken. I think that committee has concluded its task, but in any case it is intended that regional commissioners be appointed by the first week in December.

Offers of employment to all relevant West Australian Corporate Affairs Commission staff to transfer to the ASC are scheduled to be dispatched by the end of the first week in December, with a view to all those accepting the offers being transferred into their new ASC positions before the end of the month. So whilst it is very close to the deadline, I am advised that those logistical problems which Senator Campbell mentioned can be overcome to the extent that I have outlined.

I agree with Senator Campbell that consultative committees-I think they are formally called regional liaison committees-are going to play an extremely important role in gathering the support of the business communities, particularly in the regions of Australia. I am disappointed, if indeed it is the case, that a letter forwarded by the West Australian Opposition group concerned with service levels was not responded to in a timely way by the ASC. I believe that if that occurred that is an oversight which will not be the first swallow of the spring, as it were, or harbinger in the way in which the ASC will consult with the West Australian business community. I believe it is very important that the confidence of that business community in the provision of adequate levels of service is crucial and can only be secured by the sort of consultation which Senator Campbell and I and, I am confident, Mr Hartnell would regard as important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) for those answers. I think it is probably constructive-perhaps the answer can be proffered in the right spirit as well-to say that we still have this problem. Every time I raise this question in the Senate or get any publicity in any newspaper around Australia, I get a splurge of calls from large, medium and small size businesses saying, `What the hell is this company's number?'.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Australian Securities Commission is not able to more appropriately or effectively inform the business community of the requirement to have this number on their company seals within the next few days, before the silly season is really upon us, then the business community, bearing in mind there are 800,000 companies out there which have to get their common seals altered, will just not be able to comply. So I urge, as I have been for the last four or five months, that some sort of publicity campaign be waged. What will the Australian Securities Commission undertake to do? I do not think that sending out a press release-I am sure that my press releases do not get the same sort of coverage as the Australian Securities Commission press releases-will get a lot of coverage in the national media on the front page of the business pages.

In the dying moments before the dinner adjournment, I thank the Minister for his answer to my question about the making of offers to Corporate Affairs Commission staff in the States and recognise that those offers will be made at the end of the first week in December. What will the training program be for those Corporate Affairs Commission staff, not only in Western Australia but also around Australia, to enable them to operate the new computer system by the start-up date of 1 January?

The other matter, which the Minister has answered, is this matter of consultation at the business community level in the regions. I believe that as part of the Act there will be an advisory committee set up. It has eluded me why, in this fairly contentious stage of getting the legislation and the application of laws legislation through-indeed, those sections of the Act were not proclaimed earlier-an advisory committee was not set up. Perhaps the Minister could address this point, and also whether there will be people on that committee from each State.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner suspension Senator Campbell asked some questions and I have some answers in relation to the matters he raised. I was expressing some sympathy with the fact-I think I prefaced my remarks by saying `if it were true'-that the Western Australia Opposition Group (WAOG) had apparently written to the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) and not had a response. That seemed to indicate that there would not be the sort of consultation which would be so necessary to engender confidence in the business community in Western Australia as the services were provided by the ASC regional office.

SPEECH.PARA: During dinner, my officers spoke to Mr Hartnell concerning Mr Shervington's letter to him of 8 June concerning levels of service. Mr Hartnell has advised that the letter led to a continuous dialogue on the matters raised by it, both with Mr Shervington and other members of WAOG and, indeed, with the Western Australian Government. Mr Robinson, a member of the Commission, replied in writing to Mr Shervington on Mr Hartnell's behalf, though I do not have a copy of that letter. The levels of service agreed with Western Australia reflect, in large measure, matters raised in those Western Australia Opposition Group representations. If indeed that is the case-and I have no reason to suppose that it is not-it indicates not only that dialogue has taken place, but also that, as a result of that consultation, some of the concerns regarding levels of service have been dealt with.

I was then asked why an advisory committee is only now being established. I have already mentioned that regional liaison committees are to be established in all regions and will involve local business. One of the agreed functions of the liaison committees will be to consider reports by the ASC of its performance against performance indicators. Such indicators are to be formulated in consultation with the business community. I do not believe that any delay has been caused in the establishment of those committees. If Senator Campbell was referring to the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee established under the ASC Act, that Committee has been operating for some time. What the legislation now before the Parliament will do in relation to that Committee is recognise that there should be at least one person from each State and the Northern Territory on the Committee. I understand that there is already one member on the Committee from Western Australia-a Mr Richard Lester. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —If my memory from before the dinner suspension serves me correctly, some of the other matters I wanted to reiterate from my first opening statements included the fact that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) informed the Committee that the offers would be made to the appropriate staff of the Corporate Affairs Commission at the end of the first week in December. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for those responses. I recommend, as I have done before, particularly since in Western Australia I seem to have become the focal point for all complaints in relation to the establishment of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC), that--

. . . the ASC's national computer and imaging system was also not likely to be operational in Perth until March 1991.

I ask for the Minister's response to those various matters.

As to the question of the general computer and the imaging computer-I know nothing about computers, but apparently these are the terms-I am told that they will be operational on 1 January, though perhaps not with the full capacity and full range of operational activity which they will undertake when they are in full flight. I understand that Mr Hartnell will shortly be raising with State commissioners the need for cooperative action to enable business centre staff around Australia to be made available for ASCOT training in the second half of December. As the honourable senator would know, ASCOT is an acronym for something-but for what, I do not know. Apparently the rather hopeful and prophetic acronym stands for `ASC on time'. If the honourable senator can believe that, he has had a very pleasant evening meal.

I think the honourable senator has raised, quite rightly, the sorts of matters which have been brought to his attention by the business community of Western Australia. The Federal Government and all participating jurisdictions are desperately trying to meet the 1 January deadline. I understand that Mr Hartnell cancelled an overseas trip in order to be on hand to ensure that the 1 January date is met from his point of view. So all efforts are being made and I hope that the 1 January deadline will be met, given the tremendous support that is now coming from all around Australia. I was pleased that the honourable senator indicated that, having taken a stand on behalf of the Western Australian business community in relation to its concerns, he is now anxious to see that the ASC operates as efficiently and as well as possible. I am sure that we all share that wish and I hope that it can be realised from 1 January onwards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that response.
—That was a rhetorical end to the debate.

—It did not quite work. Obviously various computer systems are involved in the Australian Securities Commission. I would say my knowledge of computers is probably similar to the Minister's-quite negligible-but I am aware that there is an imaging system and a computer system, and there are obviously networking systems to allow people to search company records in Perth and get the information very quickly, we are assured, from the national database.

SPEECH.PARA: From the Minister's answer in relation to office space, I would not envisage the Australian Securities Commission installing a lot of hardware at the existing premises of the Corporate Affairs Commission in Perth and then in March, April or May-whenever the Australian Construction Service completes the fit-out-wheeling all that hardware down William Street, along St Georges Terrace and up the lifts to the new offices. I am now reading between the lines but does the Minister envisage that the old systems will be used until the new office space is fitted out or will the new hardware be established in the old premises of the Corporate Affairs Commission and, at some added expense, later be transferred down the road to 66 St Georges Terrace?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be that we are both quite ignorant of this modern technology but I understand the hardware, strictly speaking, will be in the eastern States and the communications to Western Australia and other regional centres will be by way of dedicated Telecom lines. In so far as the honourable senator is speaking of computer terminals and that type of thing, they can be readily moved in and out again. The actual working environment of the staff of the Australian Securities Commission will be such that this computer terminal equipment will be available to them pretty readily and it will also be easily transferable from one location to another. I cannot say much more than that. I do not think my officers here are well enough versed in the acquisition of computer equipment to go much further than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: — It remains an issue of concern to me. Although I do not know much about computers, I do know that if the Commission were to set up a new system which allowed people to get hard copies and facsimile copies of corporate records-and I imagine one would call terminals hardware-it will need some new terminals in Perth. The Commission will need quite a few of them if it is going to set up a staff of 190-odd people there. From the Minister's answer, it is clear he envisages having these new terminals put onto the national database system and then having them shifted physically in March, April or May when the new office space is fitted out. SPEECH.PARA: My next concern is that under the new national scheme the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) and the Australian Federal Police will take over total responsibility for prosecutions and investigations in regional areas. Would the Minister be so kind as to inform the Committee what additional appropriations will be required to upgrade the staffing levels of both Federal Police and DPP offices in regional areas? What role would the Minister envisage for the experienced State police-I think there are five or six of them in Perth-who have concentrated specifically on corporate affairs matters? Will there be any transfer of any of those State police? If not, what mechanism will be set up to ensure that the experience gained by those people over many years of investigating and prosecuting corporate affairs offences in the region will be made use of, or will that experience be lost when prosecutions and investigations move from a cooperative system between the State and Federal enforcement agencies to the exclusive use of Federal enforcement agencies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that extra resources were appropriated for the various downstream agencies, if one would like to call them that, accompanying agencies or collaborating Federal agencies working with the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) to regulate this area. For example, the Australian Federal Police (AFP) had an extra $1m allocated to it; the Director of Public Prosecutions, an extra $2m; the Federal Court, an extra $1.570m; the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, an extra $200,000; and the Australian Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, an extra $470,000. That gives some indication of the extra funding.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to Senator Campbell's very interesting question about the skills available in State fraud squads and the like and the sorts of investigations that might be undertaken by those concerned to regulate this area, as I recall, under the legislation where there is a matter, for example, which is mainly to do with fraud under the State criminal code and there are associated, what might be called, corporate law matters, then the State police force can undertake the investigation as a whole, and vice versa. There will be occasions where most matters are under the corporate law but impinge on State criminal code conditions now and again, in which case the Federal investigative agencies can take the whole lot. So there is a sort of knock-for-knock basis which keeps some of the skills applicable in the area.

I am further advised that there is an arrangement whereby State police officers can be made available on a paid for basis by both the ASC and the AFP to enable them to supplement their resources and to use the skills that the honourable senator mentioned. In that way, the particular expertise built up by some members of the State squads will be utilised and, as I say, a suitable payment will be made, I suppose, to the Commissioner of the police force concerned as these people are virtually seconded by him to the Federal agency for a period. I do not know the exact administrative arrangements, but I can get the honourable senator a more formal answer at some later point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other questions I have relate to the progression of the legislation from the date of the agreement made in Alice Springs back in June of this year to its final arrival into the Federal Parliament and into the Senate only in the last few days. I guess the parallel track of the legislation arrived in the Western Australian State Parliament only last Thursday. During the Estimates Committee hearing I asked what progress the legislation had made back in September. We were told that regular meetings were being held.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern about this is that we, as senators, and our upper House colleagues in the various States-except for Queensland, which does not have the benefit of an upper House-all find ourselves in the position of having what is a very complex piece of legislation before us. As the Minister knows, all of us now, with a great amount of goodwill, do want to see a national scheme up and running as long as there are significant guarantees about service levels in the States, but we are in the invidious position, because of the inordinate delays in getting this legislation here, that we cannot, as a House of review here in the Senate and, similarly, in each of the States, seriously contemplate giving this legislation the sort of scrutiny that it really requires.

Honourable senators will be aware that this massive package of legislation, which also relates to the 1989 package of Bills that has already passed through this place, was given less than an hour's debate in the House of Representatives the week before last. As my colleague the shadow Minister for justice, Peter Costello, said in the other place during the debate, roughly 12 seconds of debate was allowed on each page.

I am already personally aware of a number of mistakes and drafting errors in that legislation, having gone through it; and I think it would have been far more desirable had one of our committees been able to look through this legislation and, in a positive light, tried to ensure that when it was implemented, whatever the start-up date was, it indeed got off to a good start.

I note that the Government has provided itself in the legislation with a mechanism whereby it can amend it by regulation without any reference back to this Parliament, which I see as a very unsavoury part of that legislation. It clearly recognises the problem caused by putting together such a complicated package in this time.

I guess that I am not harsh enough to suggest that the public servants involved with the drafting of this legislation would have delayed it to the last minute so that the Senate and the Legislative Councils and upper Houses in the States did not have time to consider it. That would be a harsh judgment. But I do think that the Senate deserves to have information provided to it as to why it took five months to put together this package, bearing in mind that really the only alteration was in terms of overcoming the problem caused by the High Court case whereby the Federal Government was proved not to have the power over incorporations, and coming up with this application of laws mechanism which has been bandied around for the last three or five years-possibly even going back further to the Whitlam Government days.

Basically, it has now taken us five months to get this legislation. The House of Representatives was given one hour to debate it; the Senate really only has a few days to consider it and certainly does not have time to send it off to a committee for the thorough examination it deserves. It will affect the lives of millions of Australians and it will affect the way in which corporate life in Australia is conducted by 8,000 companies, yet this Senate will be denied the opportunity, either because of this delay or because of the Ascot principle of trying to get the Securities Commission set up by 1 January, which, I have already reached the conclusion, is not logistically sensible.

I guess that it would be seen as a backdown or a public failure by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and by the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Hartnell, if they failed to achieve this date. Clearly they have made the decision that it is better to get it up at all costs, get the signs up on the door, bash on through, try to solve the problems and put out the bushfires as they occur, rather than do the sensible and democratic thing, that is, to allow the parliaments of Australia to make sure that this legislation will work when it comes in. Perhaps that is asking too much, but I think the question that needs to be asked here in the appropriations debate is why it could not be brought before the Parliament in a more timely way so that at least the parliaments could have assisted in the process of making sure that the national scheme laws were going to work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The task of putting this legislative package together was given by the Attorneys meeting in Alice Springs to a steering committee. I might just mention that from the Commonwealth side, we had Mr David Edwards as convenor, principal adviser in business law; Dennis Rose, the Chief General Counsel; Ms Hilary Penfold, the second parliamentary counsel; and Mr Brian O'Callaghan, senior adviser in corporations law. From the States we had Mr John Doyle, QC, Solicitor-General, South Australia; Ms Rowena Armstrong, Chief Parliamentary Counsel of Victoria; Mr Dennis Murphy, Chief Parliamentary Counsel of New South Wales; and Ms Robyn Chapman, director of policy, Queensland Corporate Affairs Commission. I mention those people because I do not think one could put together a more high-powered committee, yet it took as many months as it did to get this legislation together. Whilst it looks formidable, when it comes down to it some basic peculiar constitutional principles are employed.

SPEECH.PARA: In effect, as I recall, if we get on top of the first 81 or 82 clauses of the Bill, we are almost there. The rest is taking up the more substantive provisions of the law. The really difficult task is to understand and to grasp those first 82 provisions. It took that very high-powered group that long to put it together. Now that it is in the various parliaments, I believe that there is a very good will towards its early passage, not only from the various governments and the parliaments in all houses now, but also from the business community itself which wants to get this ASC operation and the national companies and securities law up and running.

As to the regulation-making power, I think there has been something of a misunderstanding. It is a narrowly confined regulation power to deal with difficulties that might arise in the transition period. Its purpose is only to ensure, of course, that there is complete competence in the investigating, regulating, administrative and prosecution spheres. It ensures that nothing which was done wrongly prior to 1 January cannot be taken up and dealt with properly from 1 January onwards. If any difficulties arise in those transitional arrangements, they can be dealt with by way of regulation.

I would seek to have a conference with Senator Robert Hill, Senator Campbell and any other interested senator regarding the incorporated or foreshadowed amendments that Mr Peter Costello brought forward relating to those matters. I think it can be explained in a way which might relieve some of the misgivings which apparently were generated by the form of those provisions. In fact, they cover a very narrow compass to do with the necessity to ensure that the transition does not leave any gaps in the enforcement of the law. Of course, as they are regulations, it must be emphasised that they will be tabled before the Parliament. They can be dealt with by the Senate by way of its normal powers of disallowance in relation to the tabling of any regulations. Therefore, that will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny. I would not want the thought to be there that this was something the Executive could do without parliamentary scrutiny of the most intense kind, and of a kind which has the ultimate sanction of being able to disallow that regulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second last matter I wish to raise is the formal agreement which is referred to in the Bill. I would like to know from the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) what stage that formal agreement is at and when we are likely to see it. This is an agreement that is going to be annexed to the Act when it is passed through both Houses of Parliament. The other issue is something I forgot to raise in relation to the companies number on the moratorium. Even though there is a moratorium on enforcement of companies complying with the requirements in relation to all of the public documents, except for annual returns and other lodged documents, and the company seal, the fact of the matter is that the company number part of the legislation will indeed be law, as we all know, even though the fact that Joe's Deli Proprietary Ltd does not have a number stuck on his invoices will not make him liable to a fine.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the matters which is of concern to me is that if, for example, a company suffered some loss because another company had not complied with that section of the Act, civil action could ensue from the fact that Company B, for example, had not complied with the Act and Company A was going to take civil action against it. Can the Minister inform me, as a non-lawyer, whether the matter has been looked into? Is there anything that the Government can do about it? Does the Minister see that as a potential problem with this company number matter and the fact that a moratorium has had to be called?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the presence or absence of the Australian company number on a particular business document will not affect the legal status as far as civil action is concerned. Whilst there are some provisions in the proposed legislation which require the presence of certain information on various documents, and their absence will give rise to the possibility of the civil liability, that does not apply in the case of the actual Australian company number.

SPEECH.PARA: The other question you raised was about the formal agreement. That is another task which is being undertaken by the steering committee. It is meeting at the end of next week, but when the agreement will be formally available is uncertain. I cannot predict that it will be available in its final form during the course of the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for the answer in relation to the civil action regarding the absence of a company number. I take it from what he said that he does not think that some civil liability could flow from a company not having a company number. It is hard to envisage exactly what sort of action could be taken, and I am sure it will be a matter which will become clear once 1 January has passed, but one of the problems with the centralisation of the company names register is that there will be many companies in Australia which do share the same name and because the legislation and the logistics of the legislation do not allow for any great differentiation between companies, except for the fact that you will not allow any two companies with identical names to be registered, I would envisage that there is likely to be a great upsurge in passing-off actions around this country as larger companies try to move in and take over the markets of smaller companies with names that may not be identical but could be very similar to existing registered business names in the States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish now to give a brief answer to a question raised by Senator Harradine concerning Estimates Committee E. Senator Harradine asked me what role Australia had played in regard to the insertion of article 5 concerning parental direction and guidance in the Convention on the Rights of the Child. I have a document entitled, `Question of the Convention on the Rights of the Child: Report of the Working Group on a Draft Convention on the Rights of the Child'. The Chairman-Rapporteur was Mr Adam Lopatka of Poland. This document comes from the Commission on Human Rights in its forty-fourth session, dealing with agenda item 13. In paragraph 27 it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia, Austria, the Netherlands and the United States of America submitted the following proposals --
then some numbers follow. Article 5 follows in these terms:

The States Parties to the present Convention shall respect the rights and duties of the parents and, where applicable, legal guardians, to provide direction to the child in the exercise of his or her rights enumerated in the present Convention in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child, having due regard for the importance of promoting the development of the skills and knowledge required for an independent adulthood.
That was obviously an original proposal which was modified in later discussion. Paragraph 28 goes on to say:

In introducing this proposal, the observer for Australia stated that the proposed article would incorporate into the convention two important general concepts: (a) the evolving capacities of the child, and his or her rights as enumerated in the draft convention, and (b) the rights and duties of the parents who raised the child, who provided guidance to and took primary responsibility for the child.
I believe that that answers Senator Harradine's question and concludes our discussion of Estimates Committee E matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you wish to table the document?
—Yes, I table the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE D
Motion (by Senator Tate) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the report to the Senate of Estimates Committee D, the Committee showed concern about the increased use of trust accounts and the removal from Estimates committees and the Parliament of the ability to scrutinise as closely as before the activities of various subprograms. That is fairly clearly spelt out in the report of the Committee. I shall address my remarks briefly to that because the Department of Administrative Services could almost be called the flag bearer when it comes to the use of trust accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make it quite clear that I totally support efforts to genuinely commercialise those areas which lend themselves to commercialisation. I think the descriptive material about what has happened in the Department of Administrative Services has used the term `quasi-commercial operations' when referring to these various programs. I think it is the belief of everyone that the benefits and the changed attitudes, which should inevitably follow the commercialisation of these various areas, should introduce a completely new attitude and spirit within the public sector.

The principle is that instead of relying on direct appropriations, revenue must be earned from clients to cover expenditure. In the main, I think there are nine trust accounts within the Department of Administrative Services. Most of the revenue earned-by far the great majority-will, in fact, come from other government departments. Of course, this means that even though the revenue we are talking about is off budget as regards the Department of Administrative Services, it is on budget as regards other departments.

I would like to make the point that the system will only work, firstly, providing that there is genuine competition; secondly, providing that there is accountability to the Parliament; thirdly, providing that there is no political interference to frustrate genuine commercialisation; and, fourthly, providing that, with captive clients and thus monopoly charging, inefficiencies are not hidden.

As I mentioned at the beginning, trust accounts are probably the way to go and the introduction of proper accrual accounting plus the financial management improvement program will enable departmental heads to act, as closely as they possibly can within the restraints of the Public Service, as business managers and to make appropriate changes to ensure that they are responsible for a viable, efficient organisation.

With genuine commercialisation and genuine competition, it may well be that some of these quasi-commercial operations may not survive. All I can say is that if that is the case and if we do have this genuine approach, welcome to the real world. Thus my comment earlier that there must be no political interference to frustrate the general commercialisation.

If the decision-makers are prevented from carrying out rationalisation programs, the experiment will fail. Either there is to be management autonomy and responsibility, or there is not. In some cases, it will mean hard decisions. It is something no-one enjoys but, if allowed to proceed unhindered, I believe that it will be in the best interests of this nation, and that is something well overdue.

Some concerns have been expressed about trust accounts, and these concerns needs to be aired and clarified. Firstly, in respect of the creation of trust accounts, Estimates committees can only scrutinise those amounts of money appropriated from the Budget. It is probable that in the future there may well be no direct Budget appropriations to particular trust accounts within the Department of Administrative Services.

No-one would disagree with the proposition that departments should be accountable to the Parliament. If that is agreed-and I seek the Minister's assurance on that-to whom should they be accountable and when? They are the two questions I think we must address. I think it is very important that the questions I am raising here tonight are addressed and determined before next year when we address the Estimates again.

At a recent hearing of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, it was the general view of senators that trust accounts should be accountable to the relevant Estimates committee and at the same time as estimates are scrutinised. For instance, it would be totally inappropriate for trust accounts not to be scrutinised before the appropriations are passed in the Senate.

I might also say that it would add to the workload of both this chamber and of people within the departments if we had one Estimates committee which did not scrutinise trust accounts and, subsequently, some other committee that scrutinised them. It can be argued, I suppose, that as the majority of revenue generated for trust accounts comes from other departments, the appropriations can be tracked through those departments. I would submit that this would be a major task and beyond the time and resources of senators on those other committees.

With regard to the scrutiny of trust accounts, in the explanatory notes of the 1990-91 estimates of the Department of Administrative Services, there was no detailed information on trust accounts. A simple three-line table gave details of revenue, expenditure and surplus or deficit. The Department, in response to questions, said that with accrual accounting, standard profit and loss balance sheets and explanatory notes, the same as are available in company reports, would be produced. The samples provided as a result of that question were of no value to any senators either at that Committee or any subsequent committee hearing. The examples given indicated revenue sales less cost of sales, gross operating profit less general administrative expenses, an operating profit or a loss and, after subsidies received from the Commonwealth, a final figure.

Subsequently, however, at the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration hearing on 1 November, a proper statement of accounts was provided for the Transport and Storage Group. This was accompanied by a letter from the Australian National Audit Office to Mr McAlister, the executive general manager, Transport and Storage Group, Department of Administrative Services. This was an excellent, first class document. I notice a few congratulatory notes on the covering letter, and I would like to add my congratulations to those responsible for it. But I would appreciate the Minister providing the chamber with a timetable for the provision of similar financial reports for all other trust accounts within the Department of Administrative Services. I think it is vital that such reports are provided. I repeat that what was provided for the Transport and Storage Group was a first class document that should be used as a role model for all other trust accounts within the Department.
With regard to audits, one of the principles for the operation of the Department of Administrative Services on a quasi-commercial basis was that:
Service Agencies operating in competition with the private sector should not be subjected to audit or disclosure requirements entailing disclosure of information of potential benefit to competitors.

I understand-and this was discussed at the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration hearing-that this principle is to be looked at and amended. It is clearly intolerable and would, I imagine, be used as a convenient excuse for non-disclosure. It is hard to envisage a situation where disclosure would be of benefit to a competitor. One of the things one learns in the private sector is that, no matter how hard one tries, there are few secrets when it comes to pricing or, in fact, any other information within a public company.

Another concern is that of marginal costing. There is concern in the community that fixed costs can be fully paid for by captive clients, thus enabling business to be picked up in the private sector on a marginal cost basis. Examples were given in Estimates committee hearings of this occurring within both the Australian Construction Services and the Australian Government Publishing Service. I seek the Minister's assurance that this will not continue. If it does, it means that other departments, and hence the taxpayers, are funding a corrupted price structure. This is the very principle that we as a nation are fighting to stop in overseas countries where subsidies or high domestic prices are used to dump surplus products on markets where we compete with our rural and mineral products. To make the Australian taxpayer do the same thing for goods or services on our domestic market is even more reprehensible.

In summary, I ask the Minister to assure the Committee that the trust accounts will be subject to scrutiny at normal Estimates committee hearings; to provide a timetable for the provision of financial statements in the same form as that produced by the Transport and Storage Group; to ensure that full disclosure will be provided to the Auditor-General and the Parliament; to ensure that cross-subsidisation will not continue; and to ensure that those responsible for commercialisation through trust accounts will be given the autonomy and responsibility to do so without the political interference which would absolutely frustrate their efforts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer at the start of his contribution managed to portray the issue that we are facing with this particular part of the Estimates when he mentioned the need to have management autonomy and responsibility to the fullest extent. In respect of this current Estimates process Senator Parer is right. We did, in response to questions by him, produce profit and loss statements on the trust accounts for the Estimates Committee. He also mentioned thereafter the Transport and Storage Group (TSG) section 41 D statement.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to Senator Parer's second last question, on full disclosure, disclosure will be made to the Auditor-General. The point, though, that Senator Parer would recognise in the context of commercialisation is that one has to be very sensitive about publicly disclosing information through the audit which would help competitors of the particular organisations involved. That is obviously a matter to keep in mind. There is no intention to keep from the Auditor-General anything but full disclosure.

In terms of a time frame for statements similar to the Transport and Storage Group one, that is the only one that has been available in this particular year. The other organisations will be producing similar statements about this time next year, once they have had a full 12 months operation on a commercialised basis. Although the audited statements produced by TSG may not be available in the early stages of Estimates committees, they should be available by this time every financial year.

There was another question in respect of cross-subsidisation. As the organisations move on to trust accounts on a commercialised basis, it will be quite patent from the financial records disclosed where organisations are making profits and where they are making losses, and the transparency principle will be applied in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I should clarify the matter of cross-subsidisation. What I meant was that with a particular trust account, and I do not mean within the whole of the Department of Administrative Services, I guess the major clients will always be other government departments. To some extent we have captive clients, even though I appreciate the fact that to some degree this is being freed up. But where there are captive clients there is an ability to charge on a monopoly pricing basis. That can pick up, even through an accrual accounting system, all the fixed costs and that then enables branches such as Australian Construction Services and the Australian Property Group to operate on a marginal cost basis to compete in the private sector. A number of examples were given to the Estimates committee where it was claimed that that had been done. So it was not cross-subsidisation across the various sectors within the Department, but within a particular trust account.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just a couple of points in response to that. First of all, as Senator Parer would know but I probably need to restate the point, there are fewer and fewer areas where there are tied client arrangements. Secondly, in respect of commercialisation, which has been proceeding quite substantially over recent years and which will continue to proceed, the transparency of the records and the accounts is the greatest safeguard in terms of protecting competitors of these organisations against subsidisation. When this process is implemented, I think that Senator Parer will find that his fear is not well-founded.

—The other question I would like again to raise relates to the provision of the financial statements produced in much the same form as those of the Transport and Storage Group. As the Minister will be aware, with most commercial organisations under an accrual system figures are produced so that management can see where the company is going on a monthly basis. I am not suggesting that we in the Parliament want to see figures produced on a monthly basis. I was a little disturbed to hear the Minister state that he did not expect the other eight trust accounts to be able to produce their figures in the same form as those produced for Transport and Storage until about this time next year. I hope that we will have those in place by the time we come to the mini-Estimates in March or April next year, if not for the benefit of this Parliament then certainly for the benefit of people who are trying to operate the trust accounts within the Department.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no intention to conceal anything.
—I did not suggest that.

—I accept that Senator Parer is not suggesting that. The Transport and Storage Group (TSG) has already moved much further down the road than the other trust account operations that Senator Parer talked about. As Senator Parer would know, there is also an arrangement whereby the aid organisations have a year's grace to get their systems in place and their accounting systems on a financial basis. That year's grace basically meant that up to the end of the last financial year we worked in a mongrel situation. But at the end of this current financial year the other account organisations will be in the same position as TSG and will be producing the same level of information for auditors as TSG.

—I make a final point on the matter. I think the Minister quite properly commented-I think the point was also made by the Auditor-General at the meeting on 1 November-that one of the problems might well be that when the normal Estimates committees meet we will not have a complete audit from the Auditor-General. I think that the matter needs support. Perhaps the other Committee needs to report first. In asking this question, I make this plea: notwithstanding the final audit report, is it the Minister's view-it is certainly the view that I am promoting-that when we look at the estimates at the normal time we can also look at the trust accounts rather than have two bites at the cherry?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Next year we could probably provide draft statements which have been put to the Auditor-General. I think that would provide sufficient information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a number of issues that have been alluded to by Senator Parer in his reservation about the operation of Australian Construction Services (ACS). I am sure that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) will recall that on 13 September, when these matters were being considered by the Estimates Committee, I pursued a number of questions about the supervision of construction projects during the construction of the Royal Australian Air Force base at Tindal in the Northern Territory. I raised a series of questions relating to the supervision by Australian Construction Services and to possible charges of fraud being brought in these matters. In looking again at the Hansard of 13 September, I accept responsibility for not having been vigilant enough on that occasion to pursue some of my questions, because when I read the answers I find that in a number of places they were only part answered.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, I asked a number of questions which linked the questions of liquidations and bankruptcies of contractors with any suggestion of impropriety in the supervision of the Department. I find that the answers given related to the matters of bankruptcy and liquidation but did not address whether the Department accepted responsibility for the impropriety in the supervision of those very important Tindal contracts. I have ascertained through answers given by the Defence Housing Authority to another Estimates committee that there is an acceptance by the Defence Housing Authority that there were considerable defects inherent in the construction contracts at this particular time, responsibility for which must be sheeted home to Australian Construction Services and its supervision.

In fact, the Defence Housing Authority in its answers indicated that, of course, further action will need to be taken. Considerable expenditure will now be incurred in the future by the Defence Housing Authority, and it alluded to a figure of $2m to repair defects in this financial year. In subsequent questioning in those Estimates, I ascertained that probably considerably more than $2m would be required. The Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, in the committee stage of the appropriations debate also acknowledged that additional funds would have to be found this year to make good many of those defects to the nearly 400 homes which require remedial action to be taken.

I find this particular matter of great concern in that the answers that were given to me on 13 September would almost imply that Australian Construction Services could wipe its hands of any responsibility. Obviously there was a great deal of professional incompetence and contractual mismanagement through this situation, which has now been brought out in the fact that, I understand, a number of fraud cases against officers or former officers of the Department and other employees are currently proceeding.

I would therefore ask the Minister to acknowledge the role of Australian Construction Services in having to make good to the Defence Housing Authority and the budget implications for the long term the issues relating to these professional inadequacies. What action is being taken by the Department? In particular, I should like to be acquainted with the work that is taking place within the Department of Administrative Services own fraud control unit. To what extent has that unit been engaged in investigating all of these contracts that are under review? What cooperation is there between the Department's fraud control unit and the Northern Territory police fraud squad? To what extent will disciplinary action be taken against existing officers, or what police prosecutions are intended to be lodged against former officers or contractors, who have been engaged in this very major problem?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding generally to Senator Tambling, the advice from my Department is that the major defect in the project was the failure of tiling, and this does appear to have been an industry-wide problem. As a consequence, the tile manufacturer, I am informed, has provided free replacement products, while the Defence Housing Authority has provided funds to Australian Construction Services (ACS) for other costs of remedial works. ACS has provided and supports some of the component estimates of the $2m claim that Senator Tambling talks about, but we are not in a position to adequately comment upon the actual figure as being accurate.

SPEECH.PARA: One inference that has been drawn is that additional expenditure has run into millions of dollars to rectify the air-conditioning problem. I am advised that that has no basis as the modifications are minor and are made to match off-the-shelf components to the particular operating parameters briefed by the Royal Australian Air Force for this site.

In respect of the complaint in relation to the quality of workmanship, I am advised that it is not founded. In fact, the quality of the workmanship in the houses is generally of a very high standard. I am further advised that there is no reason to expect that there will be any continuing maintenance problems or significant costs once the current round of problems is addressed.

I think Senator Tambling referred to impropriety. I am informed that one former member of the Department is currently charged with fraud. That has involved work by the Department's fraud control unit. Officers of the unit have visited Darwin, as Senator Tambling would probably know, and investigated the scene with members of the Defence Housing Authority. I am advised that at this stage only one person is being prosecuted and there are no others under suspicion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very obviously, the brief that was written for the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) was written by Sir Humphrey Appleby. The advice that was given to me here by the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, recently acknowledged a much greater extent of problems in that regard. I understand that a number of engineering consultancies have been given to the Defence Housing Authority which do in fact implicate the Australian Construction Services in much more than the $2m defect. Minister Ray acknowledged in this chamber only a week or so ago that where funds would need to be sought they would be provided.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister now acknowledges that there is a minor problem with regard to air-conditioning. Let me inform the Committee that the minor problem that is supposedly put about relates to air-conditioning control units. The fact is that the control unit was designed by Australian Construction Services to operate at a temperature reading in the order of 27 degrees. Anyone knows that for the comfort of an evening in a tropical environment people will want to operate their air-conditioning units at 20 to 22 degrees. Sure, the control units on 300 homes can be changed for $60,000, but that will not stop people turning the units to as low as they can possibly get them and, in effect, then not being able to operate satisfactorily any of the air-conditioning units. The basic problem is a design one that goes much further than that. It means that the homes themselves cannot satisfactorily serve their purpose. This, of course, is sheeted home to the inherent design problem that was put into the buildings by Australian Construction Services.

The Minister also acknowledges that there is one fraud case currently continuing, but he does not address the question that I put to him as to how many departmental officers have been disciplined, counselled or transferred within the Department; how many of them have been operating at different branches; and what sort of staff redundancies, changes and redeployments are currently happening within the Department that chase their problem areas back to the Tindal contracts?

There are problems not only with the design but also with the contracting areas. The Minister does not acknowledge how many contractors are currently being prosecuted by the fraud squad and for which court cases will start in the very near future that also compromise officers of the Department in this regard. How many contractors are currently under prosecution? I asked the question as to what liaison there had been between the Department's fraud control unit and the fraud squad of the Northern Territory police. How many more cases are pending? How many officers of the Department have been interviewed internally by their own fraud squad or by police officers and have been either subpoenaed or may well be subpoenaed in the near future with regard to these fraud cases? It will obviously be a very messy situation, one that will compromise the Department.

I am concerned about some other issues that I will raise in a minute with regard to the operation of the regional offices in Darwin and Adelaide and the head office in Canberra. A number of officers seem to be playing with checkerboards with regard to trying to hide and camouflage the problem under many other structural changes.

I would like the Minister to address the problems that I have raised with regard to fraud in particular, the number of departmental officers who have been and will be counselled, disciplined and charged in this regard, and what the Department anticipates in the longer term will be its financial obligation to make good comments in the Defence Housing Authority reports that acknowledge obvious major design criteria problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite apparent that we will be dealing with the report of this Estimates Committee tonight and tomorrow. Senator Tambling has asked for a whole set of detailed information. I will attempt to answer some of his questions now. For the sake of a full response, it is best that we take questions on notice until tomorrow.

SPEECH.PARA: I can say something in response to Senator Tambling's general questions.
