In respect to the engineering consultancies that the Department of Defence is supposed to have contracted, I am advised that my Department knows nothing of that. In respect to air-conditioners and temperatures of 27 degrees, my advice is that the brief from the Royal Australian Air Force mentioned the 27 degrees level. I am further advised that the air-conditioners can go down to temperatures of 19 degrees.

Senator Tambling made some comments about those who have been disciplined, counselled, transferred, redeployed, made redundant, filtered through the system, or whatever. I am advised that there is no-one in that position. For the sake of a full answer, we will come back to him tomorrow on that.

In respect of the number of contractors being investigated, I am advised that there is one. Currently, none has been prosecuted. I am further advised there has been contact between the fraud control unit and the Northern Territory fraud squad.
They are the general answers to Senator Tambling's questions. I think he would understand that it would be best if the information could be provided tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept the Minister's acknowledgment that there needs to be considerably more information provided. In that regard I will certainly hold over any further comments until tomorrow.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the issue of design of air-conditioners, particularly the 27 to 19 degrees, I think it is most important to point out that the client, the Royal Australian Air Force, is a defence department. Australian Construction Services is the professional arm that provides the professional engineering, architectural and design services. It should have been competent enough to know that one does not design something for 27 degrees even if the client's original design brief specifies such a requirement. It should surely have returned to that client department and advised it professionally and properly that that was inappropriate.

This should have been particularly the case if that body had any long term design sympathy or experience in the Northern Territory, as it was supposed to have had. These units were probably designed in Adelaide. The Department continues to follow this practice rather than properly using the professional services that are available to it in the Northern Territory. If it has to it could use the private sector. However, this seems to be anathema to the Department.

That brings me to the other point that I wanted to address. I refer to the regional office reorganisation and restructuring between the Department in Darwin and Adelaide that has taken place recently. I ask the Minister to acknowledge that the Department and the Australian Construction Services have recently distributed a document headed Principles for Co-operation between Northern Territory and South Australia. This document sets out the relationships between the South Australian and Northern Territory regions and the way in which they will operate.

Why in such a document would it be acknowledged that the South Australian region will be the preferred agent for the Northern Territory region? Why is there no acknowledgment in an internal departmental document of any contribution that could be made by the private sector-professional engineers, architects, quantity surveyors, survey draftsmen-any of the people who are obviously well established, well entrenched, within the commercial environment of the Northern Territory, and why instead would there be a client preference given to South Australia to undertake this work? I can only presume it is because the Department has more of its own officers sitting on their backsides in the Adelaide office with nothing to do.

I would be very interested if the Minister could provide a list of the amount of work, however he measures it-whether it is by money value or works program-that is undertaken by the South Australian region within the South Australian office for the South Australian constituency, as opposed to what those officers in South Australia do for the Northern Territory constituency. I would bet-I would take a bet very gladly with the Minister on this-that the amount of work that is done for the Northern Territory by Adelaide is out of all kilter compared with anything that can be done in South Australia.

We have only to look at the major civil works programs of recent years-whether it is Tindal, the 2nd Cavalry Regiment or the naval base at HMAS Coonawarra. All those major projects which should have been carried out in the Northern Territory, utilising the resources of engineering, architectural and other professional services in the Northern Territory, have in effect been transferred to prop up an inefficient and costly exercise of the Department in South Australia.
The document headed Principles for co-operation between Northern Territory and South Australia mentions several things that have to be covered. Among them, it says :
It is important that the Regional Managers in the NT are adequately informed so that they can deal with political and media queries.

That sort of acknowledgment was put in. Maybe the journalists or politicians of the Northern Territory will be asking questions and therefore the regional managers must be adequately informed, but there is no relationship whatsoever with the professional organisations, with the people who are qualified and competent in the community to carry out the particular works. I would like the Minister to tell us why, in this regional reorganisation of the Department, it has to be acknowledged that there has to be a works transfer to his own State of South Australia. I would hope that there are no implications that since he assumed this important portfolio more work has been transferred than was necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just a couple of points in response to Senator Tambling. Senator Parer probably understands, as do others, that we are going through a transition period with the Australian Construction Services (ACS). There is-and it has been signalled-a fair degree of downsizing of the organisation. In those circumstances one has to share out the work, particularly in the transition period. Honourable senators will understand that downsizing cannot be done quickly. I ask Senator Tambling to note that, for example, the contracting work for HMAS Coonawarra has been let out to Northern Territory contractors and we are further advised that Northern Territory consultants are used where they are cost effective.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the statement of principles, I think once again it is best for us to look at those overnight and see whether there is anything further I can add. The principle that it is important that regional managers be well informed in order to handle political and media queries, of course, does not have to imply what Senator Tambling indicates it implies. I think that is a long bow to draw. Politicians throughout the country often go to ACS with a wide range of inquiries. I, for one, do not want a continuation of the situation where I put down the telephone and am frustrated at the lack of information that I might obtain. Likewise, I think the media also has a right to know as much as is possible. To that extent, well informed regional managers can satisfy inquiries immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last issue that I wish to raise with regard to Australian Construction Services is also related to the reorganisation of office structures. I wish to inquire as to what extent there is a redeployment of staff going on between various offices and the extent to which this redeployment is in effect discriminating against any officers of long standing at particular regional offices. Has the redeployment of any officers in fact impinged on personnel who have been involved with the Tindal contracts, of which I was so critical earlier? Various officers involved with the Tindal contracts have moved in and out of the Department and in and out of branches of the Department interstate, and there are those who have perhaps left the Department to avoid prosecution for fraud and other matters. Has there been any relationship between these people and officers who are currently under threat of redeployment or redundancy?

SPEECH.PARA: I am certainly seeking information and assurances that officers of the Department, who are located in the Northern Territory, who wish to remain there and who have the professional competency to do so, are not being transferred at a time when very obviously the South Australian office is not giving the same sort of extension of abilities to other employees at that particular office. I want to be assured that all officers are being dealt with properly and that there are no suggestions of any impropriety concerning any officers of the Department who are currently facing redeployment or redundancy packages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is a basic principle that would suffice to answer Senator Tambling's question. Officers are being encouraged to relocate and to be redeployed. I think Senator Tambling would understand that in some areas that is easy but in technical and professional skilled areas, for instance, it becomes a bit more difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the Tindal aspect of the matter, I do not think that necessarily impinges on this particular issue. But I reiterate that the fraud control unit of the Department has been involved in investigating this particular issue. I think it is fair to say that if there is any evidence against any current or former employee-as has been instanced by the case that I mentioned earlier-we will not be tardy in pursuing those allegations and investigating them fully.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister aware of any cases that have currently been reported to the Merit Protection Review Agency with regard to the redeployment or redundancy of any officers? Have any of the issues involving staff members brought out the points that I raised concerning officers who have been involved in the various projects? I want to ensure that no officer is discriminated against in relocation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there are none but, once again, for the sake of a full answer if we can drag up anything overnight I will let the honourable senator know tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer to the reservations that I put into the Committee report. The item to which I wish to refer concerns the tender for the uninterrupted power supply for the Department of Social Security (DSS) office park at Tuggeranong. This was raised in Estimates committee hearings and put into the report as a reservation because the replies to the questions took a long time to come. But even so, the responses themselves left a lot to be desired. The background to this matter was that the DSS office park at Tuggeranong was being constructed by Civil and Civic Pty Ltd and, as part of that construction, tenders were requested for an uninterrupted power supply.

SPEECH.PARA: When the ordinary power supply fails this uninterrupted power supply (UPS) will come into play and stop a whole lot of awful things happening such as, I suppose, the computer programs being lost. The problem was that Civil and Civic went to tender for the components for this contract and the successful tenderer was supposedly a company called Liebert Corporation Australia Pty Ltd. After it was advised by Civil and Civic that it had been successful, it was subsequently advised that another company-a company called Thycon Systems Pty Ltd-had received the tender. When I raised the matter in the Estimates Committee the response I got was amazing. Firstly, the officers of the Department of Administrative Services said they believed that it was not an Australian Construction Service (ACS) project. In response to a question I asked, Mr Setchell said:
It is not our project at all.
I pursued the matter and Mr Woonton said:
That surprises me. We may have been advising the Australian Property Group, which has an arrangement with Civil and Civic.

On three occasions officers answered that the ACS really had no role in the construction of the building and had nothing to do with it. The Managing Director of Liebert wrote a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-and I told the Estimates Committee where it could get the letter-indicating that he suspected there had been some interference in the tendering process. These are fairly serious allegations. Subsequently, the Department responded that ACS was not aware of any personal involvement by the Prime Minister in the process relating to the awarding of the UPS tender-although Thycon Systems Pty Ltd is located in the Prime Minister's electorate of Wills-and that Civil and Civic initially recommended the Liebert unit. The basis of the recommendation was that it offered increased load capacity and a five degree higher operating temperature.

Civil and Civic also advised the Department of Social Security (DSS) of its recommendation of 13 July that the cost difference was negligible between the two offers. Civil and Civic verbally advised the Australian Property Group on 18 September that the tender prices received were-and these are the prices given to me-Liebert, $365,250, and Thycon, $366,808. The prices were very close. The information given by Civil and Civic to DSS on 13 July was simply that both were suitable tenders, that the price difference was negligible and that neither company offered 100 per cent Australian manufacture, the difference being approximately 15 to 20 per cent in favour of Thycon.

This smells of interference. The job was given; the company responsible was Civil and Civic; and, as I mentioned earlier, on the three occasions I first raised this in the Estimates Committee the officials denied any knowledge of it. On subsequent pursuit they indicated they were acting in an advisory role. I ask some additional questions on this matter. Why was the Australian content raised as an issue when the Liebert equipment was considered technically superior by Civil and Civic, the main contractor? Who instructed or suggested to Thycon that it should manufacture a unit with an 800 KVA capacity at 45 degree centigrade ambient? Why was it given the opportunity to do so after the tenders had closed? Was any response ever forthcoming from the Prime Minister or his Department about the concerns raised by the Managing Director of Liebert in his letter to the Prime Minister?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Three questions were asked by Senator Parer. The first question was in respect of the Australian content. I am advised that Australian content considerations were part of the initial contract and they were not, as indicated, raised merely at the last stage. I would like Senator Parer to repeat his second and third questions so that we can get a full answer for him.

—I think I should explain a little because I was not as detailed in my explanation as I should have been. I understand that when the initial tenders went in the Liebert tender offered a machine that was technically superior in that it had a higher capacity. As a result of that, Civil and Civic recommended the purchase of the Liebert unit. The questions are: who instructed or suggested to Thycon Systems Pty Ltd, the opposition, the unsuccessful tenderer at the initial stage, that it should manufacture or offer a unit for 800 KVA capacity at 45 degrees centigrade ambient? Why was it given the opportunity to do so after the recommendation had been made to purchase the Liebert equipment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised, and I think Senator Parer will understand this, that the negotiations were with the contractor, Civil and Civic. I am further advised that there was no indication by Australian Construction Services of those matters suggested by Senator Parer.

—I would prefer a more detailed answer. In the response given to me to the questions on notice it was stated that Civil and Civic, which was responsible, initially recommended the Liebert unit and the basis of that was that it offered increased load capacity. Following my question, Civil and Civic verbally advised the Australian Property Group (APG) of the prices that had been received. Somewhere in the middle of all this-Civil and Civic being the main contractor responsible for this, with APG and Australian Construction Services overseeing the purchase of equipment-someone instructed Civil and Civic not to go along with its own recommendation but to switch to another tenderer. What was the basis of that? Who initiated it, and for what reason?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the last paragraph of the advice given to Senator Parer needs to be repeated. Australian Construction Services (ACS) did not make known to Thycon any information relating to the Liebert tender. ACS has not seen tenders from either company and did not discuss the tenders with Civil and Civic. ACS is not aware of any information on the Liebert tender being made known to Thycon or of any tender process having been interfered with. That is worth repeating. I think it is also worth repeating that we are talking about a contract to Civil and Civic whereby it would make its own decision. It has already been indicated that the question of Australian content was put to Civil and Civic by ACS and was obviously in the contract.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is that some illogical comments are made in the response given to the question on notice. One was that Civil and Civic initially recommended the Liebert tender. Liebert had offered an increased capacity unit with the price differential being within a few dollars; there was very little in it. It offered a piece of equipment that had an increased capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequently, with Civil and Civic itself being responsible-and this is the one it recommended-someone intervened. The opposition tenderer suddenly found that, if he could match the technical speci- fication that was offered by the successful tenderer, he had a chance of winning. It is not just a matter of Australian manufacture-that was not the point-there is another reason why that occurred.

What I am trying to do is flesh out the real background to this. As the Minister responded-and I know that he is acting on the advice of some of the departmental officials and did not make the decision himself in this instance-someone intervened to ensure that the original requirement by the main contractor was changed. To do that, information had to be given to the initially unsuccessful tenderer to enable him to lift his specification to that of the initially successful tenderer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is probably not much more I can add. Senator Parer has already asked this question in a number of ways and is doing so quite persuasively now again. The point is, as has been indicated already, that Senator Parer is talking about Civil and Civic making a decision and, as already advised, the Australian Construction Services (ACS) has indicated that it was not involved in any redirection of the tender. The only extent of its involvement was the question of the Australian content in the process.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that Civil and Civic-and this appears in the answers already given to Senator Parer-did indicate to the Department of Social Security that Liebert Corporation Australia Pty Ltd had a certain advantage, but I am further advised that there was no formal decision to accept Liebert as the contractor.

We are talking about a situation which is twice removed from ACS in terms of the actual negotiation of the contract and the decision making involved in the contract. Once again, I refer Senator Parer to the last paragraph of the response to him which spells out the involvement of ACS together, of course, with the emphasis given by ACS on Australian content.

TALK.START.PARA: —Civil and Civic initially recommended the Liebert unit. Somehow, over a period of time, for reasons that I cannot determine, the contract was changed. Did Australian Construction Services have any involvement whatsoever in the changing of that decision by Civil and Civic, or did Civil and Civic of its own accord decide to change its decision as to whom that contract was awarded to?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the first question is no, Australian Construction Services was not involved. The answer to the second question is yes, Civil and Civic made the decision.

—I hoped that we had come to the end of questioning there, but my recollection of the Estimates Committee as I pursued that matter is that, after a lot of questioning, after I had had the three initial denials of any involvement at all, a comment was made to this effect, `Yes, we do have an overseeing right on the determination of equipment'. If that is the case, it means that the Minister has now been given different advice from that which the officers gave in response to me at the Estimates Committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that we do have an overseeing role in respect of quality auditing, but not in respect of the actual decision made in this case as to who would get the tender. If Senator Parer were to go back through the Hansard records, I think he would find that that advice would stand up.

—I have one final question to clarify the matter once and for all. I think I should indicate that my understanding is that there is an officer who is known to certain people within this industry who did in fact have an influence on the change of that decision. Again, I ask the Minister to check with his officers. Can he assure me that at no stage did any person within the Australian Construction Services have anything to do with Civil and Civic changing its initial decision or have discussions with the alternative tenderer, which was ultimately successful, by providing to it technical information on the original tender.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have already answered the question. As I said, I have been advised that the answer is no. I think that what we should do for Senator Parer as well is come back to this matter in the morning if there is anything further to add.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will go on to a couple more reservations. I will touch very briefly on my reservation on the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. The cost to the taxpayer of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody highlights the need for a clear and sensible policy on the appointment of royal commissions. Since the Estimates hearings, the Premier of Queensland has agreed to the extension of the Royal Commission for another three months, thereby adding to the further costs and time overrun. The original budget of $2.2m is now projected to be of $30m.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Commission was set up in October 1987, its final report was due in December 1988. Its original staff numbered twelve, but by September this year, it had grown to 151. The second date for finalisation was 30 December 1990, with the final report by 31 December 1990. As one will appreciate from reading the press, Aboriginal leaders have described the Commission-to use the terms of Mr Bob Weatherall-as a picnic for white lawyers. They said that the $10m which had been spent in Queensland so far had been a waste. Mr Charles Perkins, who would be well known to honourable senators, has the view that examining the underlying causes was a lot of rubbish. `They know exactly what the underlying causes are', he said. I ask: why is not possible for commissioners to be engaged on an annual contract, rather than paid on daily rates? Why is it necessary to increase the staff of the Commission so dramatically? Will there need to be a further extension of time before the Commission is able to finalise its business?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Parer was asking his questions, the relevant officer was just moving into the chamber. For the sake of his information, could Senator Parer go through those three questions again?

—I will not go into the lead-up. I discussed briefly the quite substantial increase in costs of the Royal Commission. I asked why commissioners could not be paid on annual rates rather than daily rates. Why was it necessary to increase the staff numbers so dramatically? Will there be a need for a further extension of time before the Commission is able to finalise its business?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the third question, I am advised that there will not be any further increase. In respect of the second question regarding an increase in the number of staff, at quick notice it is hard to give full details, but I ask the Committee to note that we went from one commissioner to five. Of course, that has consequent flow-on effects. In respect of the first question as to why we do not employ commissioners on annual salaries, I am advised that all but one-Commissioner Wyvill-are employed on annual salaries. Commissioner Wyvill was recruited as a practising barrister at the Queensland Bar and that was the arrangement reached with him.

SPEECH.PARA: I also ask the Committee to note that this is not an unusual situation. Commissioners have been appointed by governments in this place and in other parliaments on arrangements which take daily hire fees into account. Of course, it varies from that sort of arrangement to an annual fee. From memory, I think even Commissioner Costigan was appointed on a daily fee and I think Commissioner Fitzgerald in Queensland was also appointed on the same arrangement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise another matter and to make some comments about parliamentarians' entitlements and facilities, which were the subject of a reservation by Senator Parer in Estimates Committee D. Senator Parer and Senator Kemp in particular asked questions during the Estimates Committee hearings. I refer to the issue of the postage allowances for members of parliament which were announced by the Government in August 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: To refresh the Committee's memory of those events, it was in August 1989 that the then Minister for Administrative Services suddenly and without any prior notice announced that postal entitlements for members of the House of Representatives would become $30,525 annually. That was a 3 1/2 fold increase from the previous level of $9,000. That decision did not come as a result of any Remuneration Tribunal recommendation-indeed, the Remuneration Tribunal had, shortly before then, recommended the $9,000 figure; instead, it came from an arbitrary political decision taken by the Executive Government.

The Opposition, as the Committee will recall, through the then shadow Attorney-General, Neil Brown, QC, took the Government's decision to the High Court, which subsequently found that the moneys were illegally paid by the Government, contrary to the Constitution. The Government has never attempted to recover those moneys illegally paid, despite offers by at least two members of parliament to repay the amounts they spent over and above their $9,000.

There is one exception to that: on 3 May the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) directed members of parliament to cease spending from the additional allowance. Despite the fact that members and senators may have been asked to repay expenditure after 3 May, no information is available as to whether they did. In any event, that related to payments after the High Court decision.

Very briefly, that is the history of the subject. The matter is still in the courts, with the then shadow Attorney-General, now shadow Minister for transport and communications, Mr Brown, and Senator Parer having taken further action. The legal aspects of this matter will be dealt with in the Committee debate by Senator Durack in particular.

I was very surprised that the Government took so long to release the Solicitor-General's report on which the decision not to recover-not even to attempt to recover-the amounts that had been illegally paid out was apparently based. The Opposition has always opposed the Government's extraordinary, quite bizarre, blatantly extravagant political and high-handed action in making the increases in the first place. We unhesitatingly decided to test the legality of the Government's action. That resulted in the final decision by the High Court to declare the payments illegal and invalid according to the Constitution. At the time, the then Leader of the Opposition, Andrew Peacock, wrote to coalition members asking them not to spend the increase until the legal position had been resolved. It was the coalition's action that led to the High Court decision which found the payments unlawful.

There were various aspects about that High Court decision which were very important. I think it is essentially important to note the statement in the High Court decision concerning the basic constitutional issue and the basic constitutional principle that was involved in all of this. That decision stated:
. . . no money can be taken out of the Consolidated Fund into which the revenues of the state have been paid, excepting under a distinct authorisation from Parliament itself.
The Government's action in fact contravened section 83 of the Constitution. That section states:
No money shall be drawn from the Treasury of the Commonwealth except under appropriation made by law.
The Government's decision was obviously-and found by the High Court to be so-contrary to that basic principle and, indeed, that section of the Constitution.

The significance of the Government's action is quite profound. It is not the quantity of money involved that is the problem-I will come back to that later in my remarks-but rather the way that the Government is now attempting to get away with what was deemed by the High Court to be an illegal action by virtue of a deliberate non-decision not to recover the funds that were paid out.

Let it be quite clear; everyone knows it: the 3 1/2-fold increase in the postage allowance, from $9,000 to $30,500 a year for members of the House of Representatives, not for senators, came about for one reason only-to allow the many Labor members of parliament in the House of Representatives, particularly those in highly marginal seats, to rort the public purse in a desperate bid to retain their seats at the recent Federal election. The Australian taxpayer is now being asked to meet the cost of that political rort.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the Leader of the National Party.

—If Senator Faulkner would stop rabbiting on and took a serious attitude towards this debate, which relates to a basic fundamental constitutional principle, I will listen to him. I have never heard one sensible thing out of him in this place. It is about time he sat up and tried to make a proper contribution.
—Order! Senator Short, refer your remarks through the Chair, please.
—I am sorry. The Government's action undermined the basic tenet of our parliamentary and constitutional system that was so clearly stated by the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: An editorial appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald shortly after the coalition announced that it was going to take the action that we are now proposing to take tonight, and which I foreshadowed in my speech in the second reading debate on the appropriation Bills. Let me quote some parts of that editorial:
The Federal Government and the Democrats-
I will come back to them-

have not emerged with any credit from the row about the illegal expenditure on postal allowances by MPs during the last election campaign...The Federal Government, which benefited significantly from the increased allowances, has consistently refused to accept any responsibility for what was done. The Democrats, by dismissing the Opposition's continuing concern over the matter as a case of ``flogging a dead horse'', have made a mockery of Don Chipp's instruction that their task in Canberra is ``to keep the bastards honest''.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't be serious. Move on to your next point. This is an embarrassment to you.

—If Senator McLean listened-and if he and members of his Party, including his present leader, Senator Powell, had a bit of consistency in the way they voted in May this year-he might regret having said those words. The editorial continues:

SPEECH.PARA: According to the Democrat Leader, Senator Powell, the issue is not of great economic or social importance. But this can only be true if it is a matter of no importance to politicians or the public when MPs act in defiance of the law. Senator Powell, it seems, is confusing the amount of money involved with the gravity of the principle involved. It must always be a matter of concern, surely, when MPs are allowed by the Government to rort the system.
If time permits, later in my remarks I will come back to some of those points. The editorial concludes by making the following remarks:
It's about time, too, that the Federal Government acknowledged it has mishandled the issue. Instead of ensuring that repayments are never made-
and that is what this is about-

it should be encouraging those of its MPs who spent their allowances to pay the money back. There is an issue of political integrity involved here. How can the Federal Government expect people to respond to its calls for restraint in spending when it allows MPs to spend money to which they had no legal right?

It is basically for that reason that I, on behalf of the Opposition, circulated in the chamber yesterday an amendment to be moved to the motion that the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted. The coalition moves the following amendment:
At end of motion, add:

``, subject to the following request for amendment to the House of Representatives: That the House of Representatives be requested to amend the Bill by reducing the vote for the Department of Administrative Services by $1,028,596, because of the decision to write off as irrecoverable money which the High Court has ruled was unlawfully paid out as postage entitlement for certain members of the Parliament.''.

No wonder the electorate has become despairingly cynical of the hopeless, politically and morally corrupt Government which is in power in this country when it has engaged in this sort of totally unprincipled behaviour. The coalition's actions may be seen by some as purely symbolic because $1m is a small amount of money when taken in the context of annual government expenditure of more than $90,000m, but a million dollars to most people is a lot of money, particularly in the recessed Australian economy of today.

Australia's economy is recessed as a result of the policies of this Government-a government which says that average Australians must pull in their belts and accept lower living standards while still paying exorbitant levels of taxation to a government which spends without inhibition, even if this spending is illegal and unconstitutional, as is the case in this instance.

It is much more than symbolism. What is at stake here is a basic issue of principle. The Government has shown its true colours in this matter. It ignores principle. It regards itself as outside the law and the Constitution. That is what the Government is doing. It pays no regard to the basic rights of taxpayers who expect their government only to spend their taxpayers' dollars legally. The Government quite obviously is beyond redemption on this matter, but the Australian Democrats may not be-although, given Senator McLean's comments, that appears not to be the case. Several Democrats, including the now leader, Senator Powell, supported the coalition in May by throwing out a disgraceful Bill designed to circumvent the decision of the High Court of Australia.

I would urge the Democrats to support the coalition again, as they did in May, in this matter of principle concerning legal and political morality. But if the Democrats in fact support the Government by opposing the amendment, then they will have to bear the consequences-and the consequences will be very far reaching, because it will mean that the Democrats' much vaunted cry of `We'll keep the bastards honest' means nothing whatsoever. They will stand condemned by their own actions before the electorate because this matter is about honesty. The Government has acted dishonestly, and it has acted illegally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I think the most amazing thing about this last contribution is that Senator Short has actually made it without any embarrassed look on his face. It is quite incredible. This bizarre little exercise proposed by Opposition senators-of stopping Supply Bills without stopping Supply; of requesting an amendment and indicating they would not pass this particular Supply Bill but at the same time saying they were not stopping Supply-was a joke.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. It is only to be expected, surely, that in this chamber the Minister at the table will not--
—What is the point of order, Mr Chairman?

—I am trying to say it politely. My point of order, Mr Chairman, is that surely it is required of the Minister at the table that he does not dissemble the truth, and that is what he is doing. He has told a falsehood and I ask him to withdraw.
—Order! You would know, Senator Short, that there is no point of order. There are ways for you to counter an argument later, if you so wish.

—As I was saying, this was a bizarre joke from day one. From the time the Liberals made their decision; from the time that their ghosts of 1975, Senator Durack and Senator Short, announced it; from the time that, in Inspector Clouseau fashion, Senator Durack, having made this grand announcement, managed to walk into cupboards and closets and locked doors at a press conference, it was a bad, bad joke. As I said, the most amazing thing tonight is that there is not a sign of embarrassment on their faces. They made this grand decision, a cheap political trick, to stall a Supply Bill but at the same time claim that they were not stopping or stalling Supply.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short cannot have it both ways; and Senator Durack knows better than that. The honourable senator cannot associate himself with this sort of chicanery, even though he did in 1975-and we all remember that. But as I say, it was a joke from the announcement-a joke because, having made that grand decision, they went out and someone said, `Well, you've got to stop the Supply Bills, but have you got the numbers?' And what did they say? `We haven't thought of that; we haven't asked the Democrats yet.' It was a cheap trick from the first moment it was raised in their party room a few weeks ago.

So, having made that decision, they went out and announced to the world that they would stop a Supply Bill but not stop Supply. Of course Dr Hewson, not able to understand the implications of what he was doing, had his staff running around to members of the press gallery explaining to them legal technicalities that they, his staffers, had no idea about, let alone himself. They were sprung when Senator Powell said, `Well, we see this as flogging a dead horse'-and that is precisely what they are doing tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fairies at the bottom of the garden.
—Cocaine Walters-she cannot resist. Do you know why they call you Cocaine, Senator Walters? Because you get up everyone's nose-and you have done it again tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: We have continuation again; the Opposition knows that it has not got the numbers. It knows, because of intervening effects, that it is not looking all that good on this particular issue. But having committed itself to going down this track, to going over the hill, with this particular issue, the Opposition does not know when to stop. If anyone out in the community wants any proof about how marginalised the Opposition in this place is and how irrelevant it is to the critical debate of this country--

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the polls.

—I looked at the polls this time last year; I looked at the polls this time four years ago in 1986 when I was absent along with Senator Hill; and I look at the polls now. But when the final poll comes we will still be on this side of the Parliament and the Opposition will still be on the other side, and that is because the community out there thinks that the Opposition is irrelevant.

SPEECH.PARA: Even now, the Opposition should talk to the leaders of business. The Opposition has no authority, no relevance and no competence. It has got a worse batting line up than the England first eleven. That is what the Opposition comes in here with and that is what it goes out to the community with. It is batting on the wrong pitch. The world is going on around the Opposition without it participating.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no use telling him to go to his branches. He hasn't any.
—Order! Senator Walters!

—While we are playing on the right oval, the Liberal Party of Australia is out in the nets with the National Party of Australia and any other trivial marginalised group that it can find. Another example is when the Opposition came up with this decision. The Opposition knows full well that we have had advice from the Solicitor-General that payments made in excess of the $9,000 entitlement are irrecoverable either from Australia Post or from individual senators or members. The Opposition also knows full well that Senator Parer and the relentless Mr Neil Brown-who seems to be moonlighting as a politician and working full time as a lawyer these days-have exercised their rights fairly under section 5 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act to review the decision with the Secretary to my Department to write off the overpayments. I will not go into the merits or otherwise of that particular decision because it is not appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: On the political level I return to the big issues facing this country. Let us remember that the Opposition allowed this country to stagnate for years by not being able to face up to a decision. The Opposition goes into its party room now wanting to slash billions off government spending but not being able to cut back $37m. The Opposition had no guts at all to face the big issues in the 1960s, the 1970s or the 1980s, or even now. We have the politics of recycling in this place with Dr Hewson's economic policies. We have now the ghosts of 1975. Senator Durack thought it was a great idea in 1975, which worked for the Opposition, but it was not being led by a mug then. Whatever is said about Malcolm Fraser, he had the brains and the plans, and he put them into effect. But Opposition senators are amateurs compared to even Malcolm Fraser. Senator Hill can sit back there and laugh-he does that pretty well, and we all enjoy it-but the reality is that we are talking about serious issues facing this country.

Opposition senators come in here at 10 o'clock on a Tuesday night and drag out this old dead horse that has been flogged and flogged. The Opposition should change its batting line up, start scoring a few runs out there when it counts and make itself relevant to the community.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not started yet, and when we start we will cream the Opposition. In the next two years we will do the Opposition right over-and it knows that-as we did last time and the time before. One reason why we will do that is that the Opposition will waste the time of the Australian community on all these minor issues.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that this issue was pursued, and that it was pursued quite productively by those opposite. But they now have this legal advice and this court process and a few other intervening circumstances. The reality is that this is a farce. Those opposite are wasting the time of this place, the time of the gallery and the time of anyone who might be listening to or watching these proceedings. Those opposite know that they do not have the numbers. They have been exposed; they are flogging a dead horse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Principles aren't important now, are they?

—Principles are important, and the major principle for me is that we on this side and those on the other side have a responsibility to good government, to relevant government. I will pursue any case such as this in the same manner. I have already indicated that. But after a while in politics a person finds that he may get done over. He also finds out that the more he pursues dead horses out there in the community, the more irrelevant he becomes.

SPEECH.PARA: The public does not think that the Opposition is up to it. For as long as those opposite continue with farces such as this, with Inspector Clouseau characters dragging out, as I said, the ghosts of 1975-Mr Williams reappears; Senator Durack is there as well; it is a wonder John Kerr has not been brought back-and until they get out of that groove, they will be as irrelevant at the next election as they were during the previous four.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not really see how the Minister's comments responded in any meaningful way to my point. But, to have it clarified, I will ask a couple of questions. My understanding is that the High Court, in the case of Brown v. West, ruled that the Government's decision to pay the additional 3 1/2-fold increase in postage allowances was in fact illegal or invalid. Is that the case?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know about the term `illegal'. I think the ratio decidendi of the case was that the Government did not have the authority to supplement the recommendation of the Remuneration Tribunal which had been brought down the previous year.
—Did the decision state, in effect, that the Government's decision was contrary to section 83 of the Constitution?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fair to say a couple of things. I have read the decision and different judgments within it.
—There is only one judgment.

— I am sorry; I have read different aspects of it which relate to Senator Short's point. I also indicate that I will not, as is the custom in this place, give legal advice on the basis of any question asked.
—I'll bet.

—Senator Walters would probably get some good advice from me if she listened sometimes, but maybe not tonight. I think it is fair to say that the effect of the decision was that the Government's decision was ultra vires.

—So it is fair enough to say that it was ultra vires? If that is the case-and that was my understanding as well-how does the Minister find it possible to describe the matter, as I understand he did in response to my initial comments, as a `minor issue'? I would have thought that a decision that is ultra vires the Constitution is far from being a minor issue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —If one goes back to Hansard, it can be seen that I made the point that yes, the Opposition did use the issue to its advantage. Of course, it was an issue and is recognised as such, but the point I am making now is that it is a dead issue.

—I assume that the Minister means that it is politically a dead issue. Am I correct in understanding the Minister as saying that a matter which involves a decision ultra vires the Constitution, which involves the denigration of a basic tenet of democratic parliamentary government, is a minor issue and a dead issue? Is that how I should interpret what the Minister is saying? If not, where am I wrong in such an interpretation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have in Australia something like 90 years of Commonwealth Law Reports. If one were to look at those law reports, one would find time and time again cases where individuals, corporations and States have challenged governments and challenged each other. The basis of those challenges has been the question of whether governments have had the power or authority, or have acted properly in exercising whatever power or authority they have had, in implementing legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not need to recite other cases but it is a fair point to make that the court system is in place to adjudicate on the power of the States and of the Commonwealth and to protect the rights of individuals, particularly as we have in Australia a Constitution which provides for a separation of powers. The High Court of Australia has often been called upon to decide whether governments have acted within their constitutional or legal authority or otherwise. Courts have also made decisions, and have been asked to make decisions, on whether governments, in pursuance of validly passed legislation, have acted properly or ultra vires. They have also been asked to make decisions about whether regulations are in accordance with either the legislation in question or the Constitution.

In this situation the High Court was asked to give a ruling on whether the Government's decision in 1989 was within the authority of the Government to make. It is a question that has been asked of the High Court consistently over its years of existence-asked of any court, State or Federal-about the exercise of power of any government. The point I make is that what the High Court did here was something that it has done quite often in other cases. As a consequence, we have a situation where the postage entitlement was reduced quite substantially.

Another thing that Senator Short appears to forget to mention is that I sought advice from the relevant legal officers and got advice from the Australian Solicitor-General. The advice I sought was whether we could recoup the excess payments. As I have already indicated a number of times, both by press statement and in this place, the Solicitor-General has advised that payments made in excess of the $9,000 entitlement for the provision of postal items of service are recoverable either from Australia Post or from individual senators or members.

Having said that, as late as tonight I went on to recognise that that decision, or a write-off consequent upon that advice, has been challenged under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act of 1977. It has been challenged by Senator Parer and Mr N.A. Brown. As a legal issue, therefore, it still has currency. As it is a legal issue with currency, I obviously have a responsibility not to comment further upon it, and I have made that clear already. In the context of its being a political issue, I offered my advice a little earlier, and I do it again, that, given the fact that we have had that advice; given that the Australian Democrats have indicated that they see Senator Short's pursuing this particular matter as flogging a dead horse and that he does not have the numbers; given the embarrassment I would have anticipated in the honourable senator bringing this matter up at this particular time, in light of the allegations--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman leave the chair and report to the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly want to add a few remarks to those I made last night about the lack of funding for the Canberra City Opera. I have received a note under the heading, `Opera ACT', which claims that I had uttered a disgraceful lie and said something unbecoming of an experienced public figure like myself. I am reported in Hansard as saying that Opera ACT did get a grant of $50,000 to produce one production, Tosca, for three nights while the Canberra City Opera, which produces a whole range of productions over many days, got nothing. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . its productions-
that is, the Opera ACT productions-
usually are largely made up of people who come from outside the ACT area.

Obviously, that word `people' should have been `principals'. The chorus, the orchestra and all those other groups come from local people. In fact, many of them are the people who are being trained by the Canberra City Opera in its regular chorus work, which is kept going throughout the year.

If Opera ACT is upset by the fact by the word `people' was accidentally used instead of `principals', I apologise to it. Frankly, if that is all it has to whinge about, it is doing pretty well. The facts are that Opera ACT has relied heavily on principals and people like the musical director and producer who come from outside Canberra. Those who are used from inside Canberra for principal roles are generally the same people year after year. The Canberra City Opera has new talent all the time, as is natural from a company which is providing opportunities for young graduates from the Canberra School of Music. These young people are coming through the Canberra City Opera and are then going to the leading opera houses of the world.

Quite frankly, my `correction' of a wrong word, where the import was clearly evident anyway, gives me the opportunity to note that in effect there are not really two opera companies in Canberra. When the appropriate Minister, Mr Gary Humphries, says that it would be impossible for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Administration to fund two opera companies, he is clearly missing the point. Apart from the fact that if it is good enough to fund two choirs, two theatrical companies and two of quite a few different artistic areas in the ACT, his logic is not too good.

But his facts are even worse. Opera ACT, to which he has given $50,000, is not in fact a continuing company in the ACT. It is not an opera company in the generally accepted use of the word. It is an organisation which springs into life, at this stage once a year, to provide one operatic production by drawing on people from within Canberra-as I said, if they are local principals, they are basically the same people every year-and people from outside. That is not a continuing company. It is even funded on a project basis.

In the ACT Administration list of successful project grant recipients Opera ACT is listed as having received $50,000. The Canberra City Opera is a continuing company. It is in constant rehearsal. It provides opportunities all the time for people coming through. It is certainly not a once-off situation. It is ready to provide at instant notice a chorus, for example, like the one that was provided as a very dramatic backing to the Tiananmen Square massacre service that was held in the Great Hall of Parliament House. Because it is a continuing company it can provide that kind of chorus and singing work all the year round, and is providing a continuing service to the people of Canberra.

I suggest that if it is Mr Humphries's view that he can fund only one company there is only one company to fund, and that is the Canberra City Opera. I have been very disappointed with the nature of the response that I have had today from Opera ACT and the nature of Mr Humphries's response. His view is that Federal politicians have a hide to complain about the Canberra City Opera not getting any money; after all, it is the Federal Government which has cut funds to the ACT. I remind Mr Humphries that even when funds were not cut the ACT Administration has never given a grant to the Canberra City Opera.
Talking about the word `grant', I should mention that, appropriately enough, two of the people who have complained to me from Opera ACT are named Grant. What appropriate names!
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.37 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Public Service Act-Determinations 1990 Nos 86, 131, 139, 140, 142, 149, 151, 157, 182, 184, 201-203, LES 7, LES 11 and LES 14.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 2 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has there been any change to the Federal Government's policy in sending troops to Papua New Guinea, in view of the previous serious consequences of Australia becoming involved in the Bougainville crisis.
(2) How many members of the Australian defence forces have been sent to Papua New Guinea or Bougainville and in what capacity are they acting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government's view that the Bougainville situation is an internal matter for the PNG Government to resolve remains unchanged. As the Prime Minister has publicly stated, there will be no direct involvement of Australian troops in response to the dispute.
(2) There are currently 103 ADF personnel in PNG, comprising:
85 personnel in loan or exchange positions, formed units or project teams;
4 Diplomatically Accredited personnel at the Australian High Commission, Port Moresby;
14 non-Diplomatic personnel attached to the Australian High Commission.
During the period of the Bougainville crisis there were:
2 ADF officers, with diplomatic accreditation, posted to the High Commission to assist with the increased workload generated by the crisis;
40 personnel posted to PNG to replace personnel already in country; and
54 personnel who made visits (ranging from 4 days to 6 weeks) in relation to routine Defence Cooperation activities.

Five members of the ADF, either on loan or exchange with the PNGDF have made visits to Bougainville Island in the course of their duties. These personnel provided specialist technical assistance to the PNG security forces but did not participate in any security force operations. The Australian High Commission in Port Moresby maintained a consular presence on Bougainville during the period of the security forces' operations against the militants. Members of the Australian Defence Staff attached to the High Commission were involved in this activity in their capacity as diplomatically accredited representatives of the Australian Government.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Grants to Australian Council of Trade Unions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 11 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What grants has the Minister's department issued to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) during 1990-91.
(2) What grants, if any, does the Minister's department anticipate issuing to the ACTU during the remainder of 1990-91.
(3) What grants were paid by the Minister's department to the ACTU from the period April 1983 to June 1990, inclusive.

(4) For (1), (2) and (3) above, what were the details of the amount of each grant made, or anticipated to be made; the purpose for each of the grants made, or expected to be made; and the date that each of the grants was made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (4) Nil
(2) and (4) 1990-91 Application for a grant of $55,000 under the Industry Training Services Program is currently under Ministerial consideration.
Purpose: To employ a research officer to investigate the effects of award restructuring on women in the retail industry and the clerical occupations.
(3) and (4) 1989-90 Grant of $50,000 to ACTU on 22-10-89, under the Industry Training Services Program ($30,000) and Women's Research Employment Initiative Program ($20,000).
Purpose: To employ a research officer to investigate the effects of award restructuring on women in the retail industry and the clerical occupations.
